description: Late medieval and early modern European expansion into the Atlantic and Indian oceans, with particular attention to European, Asian, African, and American contexts within which that expansion took place. Topics include the transatlantic slave trade; technology adoption and adaptation; convergence of trade, racial ideology, imperial expansion, and imperial identity construction; piracy and settlement; historiographical legacies and later imperialism; and decolonization of contemporary understandings.

name: AMST3568
catalogName: Hip Hop, Politics and Youth Culture in America
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of hip-hop, its musical antecedents and its role in popular culture. Race, class, and gender are examined as well as hip-hop's role in popular political discourse.

name: AMST3570
catalogName: History and Theory of Digital Art
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Investigates forms of digital and Internet art and the mostly forgotten histories of the technologies behind them. Forms and themes to be explored include games/gaming, surveillance art, cyberfeminism, data visualization, and crowdsourced art. CA 1. CA 4.

name: AMST3699
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Supervised reading and writing on a subject of special interest to the student.  May be repeated for credit with a change of topic.

name: AMST3807
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The role of the Supreme Court in interpreting the Bill of Rights. Topics include freedoms of speech and religion, criminal due process, and equal protection.

name: AMST3822
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Exploration of themes in the study of law and courts by contrasting scholarly work against representations of such themes in movies, televisions, and other media of popular culture.

name: AMST3822W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Exploration of themes in the study of law and courts by contrasting scholarly work against representations of such themes in movies, televisions, and other media of popular culture.

name: AMST4897
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ANSC1001
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The biological, physical, and social factors that influence animal production and utilization.

name: ANSC1111
catalogName: Principles of Animal Nutrition and Feeding
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing ANSC 4311.
description: Digestive anatomy of various species and the classes of nutrients including their digestion, metabolism and sources. Nutrient requirements and feeding standards for livestock, companion animals, exotics and aquatics for purposes of reproduction, lactation, growth, work and maintenance. Classes of feedstuffs, their characteristics, proper utilization, formulating rations and nutritional programs for animal enterprise. Taught with SAAS 113.

name: ANSC1602
catalogName: Behavior and Training of Domestic Animals
prerequisites: Open to Animal Science, Pathobiology and Veterinary Science, Agriculture and Natural Resources majors; others by consent. Recommended preparation: ANSC 1001.
description: Application of behavior of cattle, horses, sheep, goats, swine, poultry, and companion animals to their management, training, and welfare. Basic principles of genetics and physiology of behavior, perception, training, learning, motivation, and stress with consideration of integrated behavioral management and animal welfare. Students are required to have access to an animal that they will train throughout the semester; the Department of Animal Science will not necessarily provide animals for training. Taught concurrently with SAAS 202.

name: ANSC1645
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An introductory level course for students interested in the application of science to food. Nutritional and functional attributes of various food constituents are discussed. Issues concerning food processing and food safety are covered. CA 3.

name: ANSC1676
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Basic concepts of the nutrition, physiology, health and management of companion animals. Taught with SAAS 276.

name: ANSC1693
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Variable topics. May be repeated for credit.

name: ANSC1695
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Credits, prerequisites and hours as determined by the Senate Curricula and Course Committee. May be repeated for credit with a change in topic.

name: ANSC2251
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing ANSC 3456.
description: Valuable to animal science majors and includes horse types and breeds and their nutrition, breeding, evaluation, behavior, care and management with attention given to detailed studies of the problems and practices of horse production and use. Taught with SAAS 251.

name: ANSC2271
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The application of the basic scientific principles to the management of poultry, egg and meat production systems.

name: ANSC2690
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A multiple day field trip format. Students in this course will travel with the instructor to visit and tour agri-businesses that represent commercial aspects of different animal science activities. Students will interview agri-business personnel and gain an understanding of how agricultural principles are applied in the field. Each student must submit a formal written report for evaluation and meet all other course requirements as specified by the instructor. Field trip is required. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory). May be repeated for credit with a change in topic.

name: ANSC2695
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Contact Department Main Office for list of current topics and instructors.  May be repeated for credit with a change of topic.

name: ANSC2699
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated for credit. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: ANSC3121
prerequisites: BIOL 1108; open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: BIOL 1107.
description: Principles of Mendelian and molecular genetics. Biosynthesis and function of DNA, RNA, and protein. This course also includes introductions to population and quantitative genetics. Information on molecular methods of genetic analysis and examples of genetics in animals of agricultural significance are also provided.

name: ANSC3122
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A study of the reproductive anatomy and physiology of domestic animals. Laboratory will include macro and micro anatomy, hormone action, and techniques used in reproductive management of domestic animals.

name: ANSC3194
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: A discussion of current employment opportunities in animal agriculture.  In addition, students will prepare resumes and make oral presentation.

name: ANSC3261
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Management of dairy cattle including milking procedures, sanitation, selection, nutrition, reproduction, physiology and anatomy of milk secretion and record keeping. Field trips required. Taught with SAAS 261.

name: ANSC3272
prerequisites: BIOL 1107.  Recommended preparation:  BIOL 1108 or equivalent.
description: Principles and practices of laboratory animal care and management in relation to animal characteristics, handling and restraint, animal house design, reproduction and nutrition and legal regulations. Various laboratory animal techniques will be covered.

name: ANSC3273
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The production and management of beef cattle, sheep, and swine. Laboratories involve theory and practice in livestock management, skills, and techniques. Taught with SAAS 273.

name: ANSC3311
prerequisites: PVS 2100 or PNB 2265 or 2275; open to juniors or higher.
description: A comparative study of the effects of exercise on the body, focusing on the three primary athletic species (canine, equine, human). Particular emphasis will be placed on the physiological mechanisms which allow for adaptation to exercise and inactivity.

name: ANSC3312W
catalogName: Scientific Writing in Comparative Exercise Physiology
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800; open to juniors and higher. Co-requisite: ANSC 3311
description: A writing intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 3311.

name: ANSC3313
catalogName: Growth Biology and Metabolism in Domestic Livestock
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.  Recommended preparation: PVS 2100.
description: Focuses on the embryonic and postnatal growth and development of domestic livestock with emphasis on metabolic and hormonal regulation of processes that influence growth and development. Discussion period will focus on methods used to measure growth and metabolism.

name: ANSC3314W
catalogName: Scientific Writing in Growth Biology and Metabolism of Domestic Livestock
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; must be taken concurrently with ANSC 3313; open to juniors or higher.
description: A writing intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 3313.

name: ANSC3316
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.  Recommended preparation: PVS 2100 or equivalent.
description: Focuses on endocrine systems and endocrine function in farm animals with emphasis on hormones involved in metabolism, growth, lactation, feed intake and digestion in cattle, pigs, horses and poultry.

name: ANSC3317W
catalogName: Scientific Writing in Endocrinology of Farm Animals
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; Open to juniors or higher. Corequisite: ANSC 3316
description: A writing intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 3316, Endocrinology of Farm Animals.

name: ANSC3318
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: MCB 2610 or equivalent (can be taken concurrently)
description: Biology, uses, effectiveness and safety of probiotics and prebiotics. Molecular mechanisms underlying the health benefits attributed to the consumption of pre and probiotics. Application of pre- and probiotics to promote human and animal health, including safety and regulation.

name: ANSC3323
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.   Recommended preparation: ANSC 3122 or MCB 4219.
description: Introduction to recent research in animal embryology and related reproductive biotechnologies. Basic principles, methodology and state of the technology for numerous established and emerging animal biotechnologies such as transgenesis and cloning.

name: ANSC3324W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher. Corequisite: ANSC 3323.
description: Writing intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 3323 Animal Embryology and Embryo Biotechnology.

name: ANSC3343
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: A study of the food products derived from animal agriculture, including dairy, meat, poultry and fish. Emphasis will be placed on inspection, grading, processing, biochemistry, nutritive value and food safety concerns of these products. Taught with SAAS 243.

name: ANSC3344W
catalogName: Scientific Writing in Animal Food Products
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; must be taken concurrently with ANSC 3343; open to juniors or higher.
description: A writing-intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 3343.

name: ANSC3452
prerequisites: ANSC 2251.  Open to juniors or higher.
description: Designed to develop technical and managerial skills necessary for operating horse breeding farms. Programs for herd health, hoof care, nutrition, breeding, foaling, and record keeping will be included.

name: ANSC3453
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed ANSC 3456.
description: Open to all University students interested in pleasure horses. The principles of horse management and horsemanship.

name: ANSC3454
prerequisites: Not open for credit to graduate students.
description: Comparative evaluation, classification and selection of horses according to conformation, breed characteristics and performance. Judging skills including justification of placings through presentation of oral reasons will be developed. The Intercollegiate Horse Judging Team may be selected from this course. Field trips are required. Taught with SAAS 254.

name: ANSC3455
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Techniques related to training the driving horse will be described. Prior working experience with horses is recommended.

name: ANSC3456
prerequisites: ANSC 2251.
description: The theory, fundamentals and practice of breaking, training, fitting, showing, and the use of horses for riding. Primarily for Animal Science majors.

name: ANSC3457
prerequisites: ANSC 3452; instructor consent required.
description: Management of the pregnant mare and neonatal foal, including foaling practices, foal handling, and postpartum care of the mare.

name: ANSC3551
prerequisites: Instructor consent required.
description: Fundamental ground work and techniques used to train young horses. Prior working experience with horses recommended.

name: ANSC3552
prerequisites: Instructor consent. Recommended preparation: Intermediate level riding skills.
description: Theory, fundamentals and practice of backing a horse, training horse to accept the rider, and the natural aids. Intermediate level riding skills required. May be repeated once for a maximum of four credits.

name: ANSC3553
prerequisites: Instructor consent. Recommended preparation: Advanced level riding skills.
description: Training horses for riding, showing, and lessons using the Dressage Training Scale.  Advanced level riding skills are required. May be repeated once for a maximum of four credits.

name: ANSC3621
prerequisites: ANSC 3121 (or equivalent); SPSS 3210 (or equivalent).  Recommended preparation: ANSC 3122 or equivalent.
description: Laboratory techniques used in agricultural biotechnology research, including embryo manipulation, immunofluorescence, real-time PCR, karotyping, SNP analysis, high throughput sequencing, RNA-seq, genome construction and gene database searches.

name: ANSC3641
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Production and processing of milk and milk-products from a food science perspective including chemical, physical and microbiological components. Technological aspects of the transformation of milk into various food products. Public health regulations, good manufacturing practices, cleaning and sanitizing procedures. Unit operations in dairy food manufacturing, packaging, labeling and quality control procedures.

name: ANSC3642W
catalogName: Scientific Writing in Animal Food Products: Dairy Technology
prerequisites: ANSC 3641, which must be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800.
description: A writing intensive course integrated with course content in ANSC 3641.

name: ANSC3663
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Participation in all phases of dairy herd management including decision-making activities, with particular emphasis on impact of decisions on financial health and stability. Course requires participation beyond specific semester calendars. May be repeated twice for credit.

name: ANSC3664
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: An introduction to the evaluation of dairy cattle on the basis of conformation. Breed classification and type improvement programs, score card criteria in relation to longevity, physiological efficiency and performance are included. Attention is also given to fitting and showing methods. Field trips may be required.

name: ANSC3674
prerequisites: Not open for credit to graduate students.
description: Classification, form to function relationships, grades and value differences of livestock are included. Objective and subjective methods of appraisal are used to evaluate beef cattle, horses, sheep and swine. Taught with SAAS 274.

name: ANSC3675
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.  Not open for credit to graduate students
description: Intensive training in the evaluation of selected species of farm animals or their products. Type standards and the relation of anatomical features to physiological function are emphasized. Evaluation skills including justification of decisions will be developed. Intercollegiate dairy cattle, horse, livestock, poultry judging teams will be selected from this course. Field trips are required, some of which may occur prior to the start of the semester.  May be repeated once for credit. Taught with SAAS 275.

name: ANSC3681
prerequisites: Open to students who have earned a minimum of 24 credits and instructor consent.
description: Practical experience, knowledge, and professional skills in a work environment related to animal science. Based on a contract and learning experience syllabus. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory). May be repeated.

name: ANSC3691
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory). Credits and hours by arrangement.

name: ANSC3693
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Variable topics. May be repeated for credit.

name: ANSC3695
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Credits and hours by arrangement.  May be repeated for credit with a change of topic. Contact Department Main Office for list of current topics and instructors.

name: ANSC3698
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Contact Department Main Office for list of current topics and instructors. May be repeated with a change of topic.

name: ANSC4311
prerequisites: ANSC 1111; open to juniors or higher.
description: A comparative study of nutritional, physiological, microbiological, immunological and biochemical aspects of digestion and metabolism in the non-ruminant and ruminant animal, particularly livestock and companion animals. Topics include digestive system structures, utilization of nutrients, energy metabolism, control of nutrient metabolism, and experimental techniques used in the study of animal nutrition.

name: ANSC4312W
catalogName: Scientific Writing in Advanced Animal Nutrition
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher. Corequisite: ANSC 4311.
description: Writing-intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 4311.

name: ANSC4341
prerequisites: Biology 1107;  open to junior or higher.  Recommended preparation: a one semester course in organic chemistry.
description: Current topics in food safety will be discussed, with special emphasis on microbial and chemical contamination of food. Specific topics including the safety of natural versus synthetic chemicals, food additives, irradiation and other practices, basic microbiology and toxicology, current regulatory practices and risk assessment will also be included. The Hazard Analysis Critical Control Points (HACCP) approach to food safety will be discussed.

name: ANSC4342W
catalogName: Scientific Writing in Food Microbiology and Safety
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800; open to juniors or higher. Corequisite: ANSC 4341
description: A writing-intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 4341.

name: ANSC4457
prerequisites: Intermediate II or above riding experience required.
description: The techniques and procedures of teaching equitation including the theories of riding and teaching methods. Practice teaching will be required under the supervision of the instructor. Taught with SAAS 257.

name: ANSC4642
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.  Recommended preparation: MCB 2610.
description: An introductory laboratory course in sampling of foods for microbiological analysis, enumeration of microorganisms in foods, and isolation and identification of major foodborne pathogens from foods.

name: ANSC4662W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; ANSC 3261; open to juniors or higher.
description:
Dairy farm management practices with emphasis on business and economic decision making. The effects of various programs in selection, nutrition, facilities, reproduction and herd health on overall business health will be evaluated. Each student will manage a computer simulated herd during the semester.  Field trips are required.
GEOC;

name: ANSC4697W
catalogName: Undergraduate Honors Thesis Writing in Animal Science
prerequisites: Three credits of ANSC 2699 or 5692, which may be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Writing of a formal thesis based on independent research conducted by the student. Thesis proposal and final thesis must follow guidelines developed by the department.

name: ANTH1000
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: An introduction to the anthropological understanding of human society through ethnographic case studies of selected peoples and cultures, exploring the richness and variety of human life. Encourages students to learn about different cultures and to apply their knowledge to make sense of their own society. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH1000
catalogName: Peoples and Cultures of the World
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: An introduction to the anthropological understanding of human society through ethnographic case studies of selected peoples and cultures, exploring the richness and variety of human life. Encourages students to learn about different cultures and to apply their knowledge to make sense of their own society. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH1000W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: An introduction to the anthropological understanding of human society through ethnographic case studies of selected peoples and cultures, exploring the richness and variety of human life. Encourages students to learn about different cultures and to apply their knowledge to make sense of their own society. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH1000W
catalogName: Peoples and Cultures of the World
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: An introduction to the anthropological understanding of human society through ethnographic case studies of selected peoples and cultures, exploring the richness and variety of human life. Encourages students to learn about different cultures and to apply their knowledge to make sense of their own society. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH1001W
description: An introduction to cultural anthropology, approached through the medium of ethnographic film. Particular attention is given to how films represent humans' varied beliefs and behavior.  CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH1006
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: The biological and cultural development of humans from their origin to the present. A brief survey of human evolution is followed by a comparative study of behavior and beliefs of our own and other societies. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH1010E
catalogName: Global Climate Change and Human Societies
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A multidisciplinary examination of the nature, anthropogenic drivers, range of expressions, and impacts of contemporary and future global climate change as well as cultural understandings of this significant environmental process and diverse human responses to it. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH1093
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 17.

name: ANTH1095
prerequisites: Determined by the Senate C&C Committee
description: May be repeated with a change in topic.

name: ANTH1500
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of important discoveries in archaeology spanning the whole of human prehistory across the globe. Current issues, methods, and techniques in the field of archaeology. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH2000
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing ANTH 4001.
description: A comparative study of social structure including an analysis of kinship, marriage, community organization, political and economic institutions, and the role of the individual in these institutions.  CA 2. CA 4.

name: ANTH2000W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Not open to students who have passed ANTH 4001.
description: A comparative study of social structure including an analysis of kinship, marriage, community organization, political and economic institutions, and the role of the individual in these institutions. CA 2. CA 4.

name: ANTH2400
prerequisites: Recommended for first-year and sophomore students in the Honors Program.
description: An introduction to religion from interdisciplinary and cross-cultural perspectives. Theories, analytic frameworks, and critiques. Religious orientations. Components of religion. The science-and-religion debate. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH2501
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing ANTH 3521 or 3704.
description: The concepts, methods and practice of anthropological archaeology.

name: ANTH2502
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The processes and events leading to the origin of human beings. Human physical and cultural development from its beginning to the dawn of settled life, through the approaches of physical anthropology and archaeology.

name: ANTH2510
prerequisites: Recommended preparation:  ANTH 2501.
description: Methods and techniques in underwater archaeology covering both maritime (ships, ports, etc.) and submerged settlements archaeology. Overview of the aqueous environment, underwater archaeological methods, geophysical/geotechnical surveying and data interpretation, diver and ROV-based documentation and excavation techniques survey methods.

name: ANTH2600
description: Introduction to research trends in archaeobotany and use of microscopy tools. Design and execution of a research project. CA 3-LAB.

name: ANTH3002
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Anthropological contributions to the study of language, culture, and their relationship. Topics include the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis and the application of cognitive anthropological methods and theory to the study of folk classification systems.

name: ANTH3003
prerequisites: ANTH 1000 or 1006.
description: Methods and techniques of field research in social settings, including observational procedures, interviewing, and the construction and use of questionnaires.

name: ANTH3004
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The theoretical foundations and basic methods used to collect and analyze cultural data.

name: ANTH3021
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of anthropological contributions to the study of contemporary Mexico, Central America, South America, and the Hispanic Caribbean. Special focus on the comparative analysis of recent ethnographic case studies and local/regional/national/international linkages.

name: ANTH3026
catalogName: Peoples and Cultures of North America
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A survey of representative Native American cultures as they existed prior to the twentieth century, together with a view of the changing life of modern Native Americans.

name: ANTH3027
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Analysis of Native American reservations and urban communities and their relationship to the larger U.S. society. Special focus on federal policy and economic development, cultural identity, and  politics of Native Americans.

name: ANTH3028
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: ANTH 2000.
description: An introduction to the study and understanding of Aboriginal ways of life and thought. An exploration of the complexity of contemporary indigenous social orders and land rights issues. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH3028W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: ANTH 2000.
description: An introduction to the study and understanding of Aboriginal ways of life and thought. An exploration of the complexity of contemporary indigenous social orders and land rights issues. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH3029
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Comparative perspectives on the cultural formation of Caribbean societies; the region's demographic, economic and political links with the wider world.

name: ANTH3030
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of the indigenous societies and cultures of the Pacific Islands, from the first settlement to the postcolonial period. Topics include prehistoric canoe voyaging, modes of subsistence, political forms, ritual and religion, ceremonial exchange, gender ideologies, European colonization, and modern indigenous nationalism. Ethnographic examples will be drawn from Polynesia, Melanesia, and Micronesia. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH3038
catalogName: Peoples and Cultures of the Middle East
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Selected social and cultural features of past and contemporary Middle Eastern social forms, and the origins and varieties of Western perceptions of these features.

name: ANTH3041
catalogName: Latin American Minorities in the United States
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Emphasis on groups of Mexican, Puerto Rican and Cuban origin, including treatment and historical background, social stratification, informal social relations, ethnic perceptions, relations and the concept of Latino identity.

name: ANTH3042
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Analysis and interpretation of interrelated economic, political and cultural processes in the contemporary social life of Mexico and the U.S.-Mexico borderland. Draws broadly on the social science literature with a special focus on anthropological contributions.

name: ANTH3081
prerequisites: ANTH 1000 or 1006 or 1500; instructor consent required.
description: Practical experience, knowledge, and professional skills in a work environment related to anthropology. Based on a contract and learning experience syllabus.

name: ANTH3090
prerequisites: ANTH 3003 or consent of instructor.
description: The investigation of a sociocultural and/or archaeological problem in some domestic or foreign field location. May be repeated for a maximum of 12 credits.

name: ANTH3091
prerequisites: Instructor consent required; ANTH 1000 or 1006 or 1500. Corequisite: Must be taken with ANTH 3081.
description: Directed study, analysis, and reflection on internship experience.

name: ANTH3093
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor. May be repeated for credit.

name: ANTH3095
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change of content, may be repeated for credit.

name: ANTH3096
prerequisites: Instructor consent.
description: The investigation of a sociocultural and/or archaeological problem in a non field-based setting. Hours by arrangement.

name: ANTH3098
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: Prerequisites, required preparation, and reccomended preparation vary.  With a change of topic,  may be repeated for credit.

name: ANTH3099
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change of content, may be repeated for credit.

name: ANTH3120
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Ethnographic approaches to classic and contemporary debates about capitalism's transformation of sociocultural dynamics.

name: ANTH3150
prerequisites: Recomended preparation: ANTH 1000 or 1006.
description: The social, cultural and economic causes and consequences of internal and international migration in the modern era. Topics include migrant selection, social adaptation, effects on home and host societies, and cultural identity. CA 4.

name: ANTH3150W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: ANTH 1000 or 1006.
description: The social, cultural and economic causes and consequences of internal and international migration in the modern era. Topics include migrant selection, social adaptation, effects on home and host societies, and cultural identity. CA 4.

name: ANTH3152
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Popular and scholarly theories of human group identity and diversity, in cross-cultural and historical perspective. Topics include: an overview of 'race' and 'ethnicity' in Western thought, ethnic group formation and transformation, political mobilizations of group identity, and systems of inequality. CA 2. CA 4.

name: ANTH3153W
description: Human rights, political violence, political and legal anthropology, prosecutions of human rights offenders, truth and memory, reconciliation, international justice. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH3155
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An exploration of the racial, political, and social similarities and differences within and between the communities constituting the African Diaspora from an anthropological perspective.

name: ANTH3200
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The application of the theory of natural selection to the study of human culture and behavior, with emphasis on the interaction between humans and their environment.

name: ANTH3202W
description: Cross-cultural analysis of ethnomedicine, major medical systems, alternative medical systems, curing and healing illness and social control, gender and healing, and the role of traditional and cosmopolitan medical systems in international health. CA 4.

name: ANTH3230
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed ANTH 3098 when offered as Propaganda, Fake News and Hate Speech
description: Draws on current social science research to understand the effects of false information and hate speech on our politics and culture and to evaluate various private and public initiatives to regulate speech. CA 2.

name: ANTH3230W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Not open for credit to students who have passed ANTH 3098 when offered as “Propaganda, Fake News and Hate Speech.”
description: Drawing on recent social science research, this course will seek to understand the effects of false information and hate speech on our politics and culture, and evaluate various private and public initiatives to regulate speech. CA 2.

name: ANTH3250
prerequisites: Recommended preparation:  ANTH 3002.
description: The study of how the content of thought or knowledge is created, organized, and distributed in human communities. Topics include cultural models of the mind, emotions, personality, and relationships.

name: ANTH3251
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Cross-cultural overview of critical issues regarding the relationship between individual personality and sociocultural systems, and mental health and illness.

name: ANTH3300
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An introduction to the theory, method, and content of medical anthropology.

name: ANTH3302
prerequisites: Recommended preparation:  ANTH 3300.
description: Anthropological perspectives on the interrelationships among culture, biology, environment, and disease. Major topics include ecology and adaptation, population dynamics, nutrition, reproduction, disease in sociological context, health seeking behavior, and the complexity of the interaction of western and non-western medical systems.

name: ANTH3304
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Uses the anthropological lens to examine the intersection of societies, cultures and psychoactive substances based on a historically informed, cross-cultural, ethnographic and political economic perspective on drug use and related behaviors.

name: ANTH3309
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Violence and human rights as cultural constructs; human rights claims; war, genocide, terrorism, street crime, domestic violence; deterrence and intervention policy.

name: ANTH3320
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An examination of the reproductive health experiences of women in the United States, including those focused on sexuality, birth, and motherhood. An exploration of the complex relationship between women’s reproductive experiences and their contemporary racial and socioeconomic locations in American society.

name: ANTH3325
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Anthropological perspectives on public health in a globalized world, health inequalities within and across countries; diverse social, cultural, and other determinants of global health; pressing global health issues; organizational players involved in addressing global health issues.

name: ANTH3326
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Theories, methods and controversies in the interconnected fields of global health and human rights.

name: ANTH3327
catalogName: Power and Health in Latin America and the Caribbean
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: History, theories, and concepts about the human right to health and structural inequalities in the region.

name: ANTH3339
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Correspondences among cultural institution design, collective action failure and success, and cultural resilience.

name: ANTH3340E
description: Interdisciplinary analysis of conservation and the human-environment relationship from a cross-cultural perspective. Major topics include sustainability, environmental ethics, climate change, natural disasters, health, and environmental justice. CA2. CA4-INT.

name: ANTH3350
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Major conceptual and historical problems in the study of gender in anthropology. Women's roles in different historical and contemporary settings, and new understandings of family, kinship, power, and cultural ideologies.

name: ANTH3351
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Cross-cultural and interdisciplinary analysis of biological sex, gender, sex roles, and sexuality.

name: ANTH3400
prerequisites: ANTH 1000 or 1006.
description: Major theories and approaches in the study of religion as a social institution and cultural system. Topics include myth, ritual, taboos and pollution beliefs, shamanism, magical practices, fundamentalism and religion in modern society.

name: ANTH3401
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A survey of religious belief systems, both polytheistic and monotheistic, from around the world. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ANTH3402
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An introduction to Biblical interpretation from a feminist perspective, examining how women are represented in the Hebrew Scriptures and the New Testament.  Issues of authorship, translation, point of view, cultural context and language.

name: ANTH3403
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Gender issues in the world's religions. Survey of women's theological standing, ritual activities and participation in a cross-cultural sample of religions, both monotheistic and polytheistic.

name: ANTH3405
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Cognitive and evolutionary anthropological perspectives on the mental underpinnings of religious thought and behavior.

name: ANTH3450W
description: Approaches to cultural creativity and aesthetics in the graphic and plastic arts of prestate societies. Examples from North America, Oceania, and Africa. CA 1.

name: ANTH3503
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The origin of humanity in Africa, hunters and gatherers of the Paleolithic, the origins of agriculture and the transition to settled life, and the emergence of civilizations in Africa, Asia and the Near East.

name: ANTH3506W
description: The analysis, interpretation, and presentation of archaeological data sets including lithics, ceramics, floral and faunal remains and spatial information from excavated sites.

name: ANTH3512
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An archaeological perspective on more than three million years of human social and behavioral change in Africa, from Stone Age societies that are the earliest in the world to sweeping changes brought about by the development and spread of cattle and crops, sophisticated metallurgy, and the later rise of kingdoms and complex polities situated at a global crossroads of trade and interaction.

name: ANTH3513
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: From the earliest hunter-gatherers to the rise of the state: the transition from food-gathering to food-production and the development of complex societies in the Near East.

name: ANTH3514
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Interdisciplinary survey of the archaeological, biological, cultural, and behavioral evolution of prehistoric humans and their societies across Europe and portions of western Asia.

name: ANTH3515
catalogName: Ancient Civilizations of the Old World
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: ANTH 1006 or 1500.
description: Examination of early civilizations in Mesopotamia, Egypt, the Indus Valley, and sub-Saharan Africa. Theories explaining the development and collapse of early state-level societies are critically considered.

name: ANTH3522
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Interdisciplinary study of the ecology of humans, integrating ecological and anthropological theory with archaeological, historical, and contemporary case-studies.

name: ANTH3522W
description: Interdisciplinary study of the ecology of humans, integrating ecological and anthropological theory with archaeological, historical, and contemporary case-studies.

name: ANTH3523
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The origins and spread of agriculture worldwide. Economic, social and ideological ramifications of the agricultural transition. Processes of plant and animal domestication.

name: ANTH3531
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: ANTH 1500, ANTH 2501, ANTH 2510 or HIST 3544.
description: Archaeological and historical sources to examine the development of seafaring practices, exploration, waterborne trade and economic systems, naval warfare and shipbuilding in the Americas from the fifteenth to the beginning of the twentieth century.

name: ANTH3532
catalogName: Archaeology of the Age of Sail
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: ANTH 1500, ANTH 2501, or ANTH 2510.
description: Overview of archaeological and historical sources on the development of seafaring and navigation, exploration, waterborne trade and economic systems, colonialism and empire building, naval warfare and shipbuilding in Europe, Asia and Australia from the fifteenth to the beginning of the twentieth century.

name: ANTH3555
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Survey of scientific methods used to answer archaeological questions. Methods, applications and lab demonstrations.

name: ANTH3560
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Investigation of ecological, anatomical, and physiological aspects that shaped the biological and cultural evolution of humans from the Pliocene to the Anthropocene.

name: ANTH3701
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The properties of stone tools - the primary evidence of human behavior for humanity's first 2.5 million years - and the processes of their manufacture. Analysis of prehistoric tools and tool replication.

name: ANTH3702
prerequisites: Recommended preparation:  ANTH 2502.
description: Human skeletal anatomy from an evolutionary and functional perspective. Identification and interpretation of bones of the human skeleton, methods for aging, sexing, and identifying pathologies.

name: ANTH3703
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Method and theory of archaeological faunal analysis, including training in the identification of skeletal materials, the formation of the zooarchaeological record, and  the interpretation of zooarchaeological data.

name: ANTH3704W
description: Method and theory of experimental archaeology, including hands-on study of past human behavior through experimentation with modern material culture, and the execution of an experimental research project addressing an archaeological question.

name: ANTH3705
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: ANTH 2501, 2502 or 3503.
description: Fossil evidence for the evolution of the human family, Hominidae. Anatomical features, behavior, and evolutionary relationships of extinct hominids; the use of biological, geological, and archaeological evidence to reconstruct past hominid adaptations.

name: ANTH3706
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Method and theory of studying archaeological plant remains in the laboratory, including sampling, identification, and interpretation of data.

name: ANTH3720
catalogName: Lab Methods in Archaeological and Forensic Science
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Introduction to scientific lab methods used in archaeology and forensics. Includes three stand alone modules, each dedicated to a different method. Each module consists of 15 contact hours comprised of labs and lectures and takes place during a single weekend. Repeatable to a maximum of three credits.

name: ANTH3902
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Prehistoric cultures of North America from the earliest traces to European contact, with emphasis on the region east of the Mississippi. CA 4.

name: ANTH3904
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Combines archaeological and ethnohistorical data to reconstruct the lifeways of the Native Americans of New England from the prehistoric period to the present. CA 4.

name: ANTH3980
prerequisites: ANTH 1000 or 1000W or 1006 or 2000 or 2000W; department consent required. Recommended preparation: ANTH 3003 or 3004 or 3340.
description: A field-based course examining the relationship between the diversity of environmental settings and human cultures, based out of the Organization of Tropical Studies in Costa Rica. Students will examine the interactions with and the uses of natural resources in human communities surrounding OTS field stations. Students will also review the ethical considerations of conducting scientific research involving human populations. Taught in Costa Rica.

name: ANTH3990
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Training in the techniques of archaeological site excavation; mapping; recording; field conservation, and preliminary analysis of materials.

name: ANTH4001W
prerequisites: English 1010 or 1011 or 2011; ANTH 2000. Recommended for seniors.
description: Historical and contemporary theories in social and cultural anthropology.

name: ANTH4097
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; Instructor consent required.
description: Open to students within the Honors program.

name: ANTH4097W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only with consent of instructor.
description: Research and writing of major project exploring a topic within anthropology, with close supervision and production of multiple written drafts.

name: ANTH4510
prerequisites: Recommended preparation:  ANTH 1500 or 2501 or 2502.
description: An interdisciplinary consideration of the biological, cultural, technological, and behavioral evolution of the Neanderthals and their societies.

name: ANTH4801
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Quantitative  methods appropriate to the analysis of artifact data, radiocarbon dating, and the spatial distribution of sites.

name: ARAB1001
prerequisites: Not open to students who have had three or more years of Arabic in high school.  Cannot be taken for credit after passing ARAB 1101 (equivalent), 1102, 1103, 1104, 1112, 1113, 1114.
description: Beginning Modern Standard Arabic. Basic conversation in formal Arabic. Development of basic reading and writing skills.

name: ARAB1002
prerequisites: ARAB 1001 or instructor consent; not open to students who have had three or more years of Arabic in high school. Cannot be taken out of sequence after passing ARAB 1003, 1004, 1102, 1103, or 1104.
description: Development of ability to communicate in Modern Standard Arabic, orally and in writing. Not open for credit to students who have had three or more years of Arabic in high school.

name: ARAB1003
prerequisites: ARAB 1002 or instructor consent. Cannot be taken for credit after passing ARAB 1004, 1113, or 1114.
description: Lower to upper intermediate level in Modern Standard Arabic. Development of ability to communicate orally and in writing. Taught in English and Arabic.

name: ARAB1004
prerequisites: ARAB 1003 or instructor consent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ARAB 3212. Not open for credit to students who have passed ARAB 1104.
description: Development of ability to communicate in Modern Standard Arabic. Lower to upper intermediate skills in speaking and writing. Taught in English and Arabic.

name: ARAB1193
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ARAB1751
catalogName: Traditional Arab Literatures, Cultures, and Civilizations
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Representative works from the cultures of the Arab world. Pre-Islamic poets to later writers and thinkers. Relation of literary and artistic forms to their historical contexts.  Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ARAB1771
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Introduction to modern Arabic culture from Napoleon's Egyptian Campaign to modern Islamism. Survey of institutions, philosophy, and social customs seen through the medium of literature. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ARAB2170
prerequisites: One year of Arabic or instructor consent
description: Effective communication in Levantine colloquial Arabic. Introduction to words, expressions and grammatical structures used frequently in everyday life. Taught in Levantine Arabic and English.

name: ARAB2751
catalogName: Arabic Folk Tales and Mirrors for Princes
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Folk tales and advice to princes and rulers of the Muslim World: Arabic, Persian and Moghul texts read in translation, such as The Thousand and One Nights, the Qabusname, and Jahangirname. Comparisons with European frame-tales and advice literature (Chaucer, Boccaccio, Machiavelli). Manuals for rulership from India to Andalusia. Ethics, conduct, and political philosophy in folk literature and elite prose. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ARAB3100
catalogName: Advanced Arabic: Composition, Style, and Vocabulary
prerequisites: ARAB 1004 or instructor consent.
description: Topics include advanced Arabic texts by writers from around the Arab world, covering a range of political, social, religious, and literary themes and that represent a range of genres, styles, and periods. Taught in Arabic.

name: ARAB3102
prerequisites: two years of formal Arabic or equivalent proficiency
description: Modern standard Arabic of the media: television, press and internet. Taught entirely in Arabic.

name: ARAB3212
prerequisites: ARAB 1114 or by instructor consent.  May be repeated for up to 6 credits.
description: In-depth development of speaking and writing skills.

name: ARAB3293
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: ARAB3295
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit. Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: ARAB3299
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: ARAB3550W
description: Survey of Classical Arabic Literature from pre-Islamic Arabia to the Late Middle Ages, from the Fertile Crescent to the Iberian Peninsula. Recent scholarship and theory in the field of Arabic literature. Taught in English (Arabic readings optional). CA 1.

name: ARAB3551
prerequisites: two years of formal Arabic or equivalent proficiency
description: Travel accounts by medieval and modern Arab writers. Transcultural encounters: the Volga Vikings, Norman Sicily, al-Andalus, China, Africa and France. Development of advanced reading and translation skills. Review of grammar and syntax through textual analysis.

name: ARAB3559
prerequisites: two years of formal Arabic or equivalent proficiency
description: Selected Arabic poems from pre-Islamic times to the Middle Ages, from Iraq to the Iberian Peninsula. Modes, genres, periods and authors of the Arabic Classical poetic canon. Arabic poetic terminology, criticism and theory. Development of advanced reading, writing and translation skills. Taught in English and Arabic.

name: ARAB3570
prerequisites: two years of formal Arabic or equivalent proficiency
description: Survey of fundamental texts in modern and contemporary Arabic Literature. Textual criticism in Arabic. Development of advanced oral and written skills in Modern Standard Arabic. Taught in Arabic.

name: ARAB3751
catalogName: Al-Andalus: Music, Literature, and Science in Muslim Spain
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The cultural heritage of Muslim Spain through literature, music, philosophy, medicine, art, and architecture. Christian, Jewish and Muslim interactions in medieval Europe. Religious and ethnic coexistence in medieval Iberia. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ARAB3771
catalogName: Cinema in the Middle East and North Africa
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Film in the Arab World. Historical, social, religious and political phenomena that shape contemporary cultural discourse, analyzed through film screenings and readings. Gender, radicalization, war and displacement; key historical events such as the Arab-Israeli conflict, the Lebanese civil war, decolonization, and Islam in the 21st century. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ARAB3772
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Representations of Muslims in medieval textbooks, 18th- and 19th-century Western travel accounts. Their influence on stereotypes of Arabs and Muslims in Western cinema and media from early Hollywood films to the present. Taught in English.

name: ARE1110
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ARE1110E
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: The role of agriculture in the growth and development of societies throughout the world. Economic, social, and environmental problems of food production and resource needs in developing and advanced societies. CA 2.

name: ARE1150
catalogName: Principles of Agricultural and Resource Economics
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed ECON 1201.
description: An introduction to microeconomic analysis with applications to food, nutrition, health, natural resources, and the environment. Topics include consumer and firm behavior, supply, demand, markets, and economic policy. CA 2.

name: ARE2150
prerequisites: ARE 1150 or ECON 1200 or ECON 1201. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ARE 3223.
description: Applications of intermediate level microeconomic theory to problems and policy issues in agriculture, natural resources, and the environment. Topics include supply, demand, market equilibrium, consumer and producer behavior, perfect competition, and welfare economics. Emphasis will be placed on using the theory in applied and computational exercises.

name: ARE2210
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An analysis of basic business principles, fundamentals and concepts for agribusiness entrepreneurs. Taught with SARE 460.

name: ARE2235
prerequisites: Recommended preparation:  ARE 1150 or ECON 1200 or ECON 1201.
description: Fundamental theory, methods, and policy implications of environmental and resource economics, with an emphasis on coastal and marine environments. Topics include pollution policy, fisheries, water quality and allocation, international trade, wildlife and biodiversity, land use, and economic valuation. Designed for students with diverse departmental affiliations. CA 2.

name: ARE3215
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Analysis of marketing, management, and financial decision-making tools in agribusiness.

name: ARE3221
prerequisites: ARE 1150 or ECON 1200 or ECON 1201. Recommended preparation: MATH 1071Q or 1110Q or 1120Q or 1131Q or 1151Q; or STAT 1000Q or STAT 1100Q.
description: The application of microeconomic analysis to decision-making techniques of businesses and management units with a particular focus on the food industry covering topics such as electing or developing products, deciding on product output and pricing, organizational design, promotional strategies, worker hiring and training, and investment and financing.

name: ARE3222
prerequisites: ARE 1150 or ECON 1200 or ECON 1201.
description: This course focuses on principles of contemporary marketing, including consumer behavior, social media, product, promotion, distribution and pricing strategies, with special emphasis on food and health.

name: ARE3223
description: Analytical tools that economists use to evaluate the organizational and hiring decisions of firms. Emphasis on the effect of government policies and programs on how many workers are hired, how much they are paid, and how other forms of compensation are structured. Specific areas of consideration may include: minimum wages, federal income tax, payroll and self-employment taxes, unemployment insurance, immigration, health insurance, retirement account contributions, the use of contractors in place of employees (the so-called "gig economy"), legal form of organization, and business liability. Special emphasis on using original sources, including federal statistical agency data products, reports from federal oversight bodies, US Code, and IRS publications.

name: ARE3225
prerequisites: ARE 1150 or ECON 1200 or ECON 1201; STAT 1000Q.
description: Principles and applications of market price determination, with special emphasis on the use of futures markets for profit and price risk management. Includes food and energy case studies, internet applications, and a futures simulation exercise.

name: ARE3260
description: Analysis of food and agricultural policies in the United States and abroad. Designed for students with diverse departmental affiliations.

name: ARE3261W
prerequisites: ARE 3260 must be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to Resource Economics majors, others with instructor consent; Not open to students who have passed ARE 3260W.
description: A writing intensive course on issues related to food policy, integrated with course content in ARE 3260.

name: ARE3333
prerequisites: STAT 1000Q or STAT 1100Q, or similar; laptop computer in class. Recommended preparation: ECON 1200 or ECON 1201 or ARE 1150.
description: Learn fundamental concepts of statistics and economics through analysis of economic data using computer spreadsheets.

name: ARE3434
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ARE3434E
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Economic and policy aspects of natural resource use and environmental quality issues. Designed for students with diverse departmental affiliations.

name: ARE3436
catalogName: The Economics of Integrated Coastal Management
description: Explores the theory and practice of integrated coastal management (ICM); introduces major concepts, processes, tools and methods of ICM; and analyzes United States and international experiences with ICM.

name: ARE3437E
description: Explores the various natural, human and management components of the fishery system and presents the application of economic and policy analysis for the optimal allocation of resources to a fishery.

name: ARE3440W
catalogName: Writing in Environmental and Resource Policy
prerequisites: Must be taken with ARE 3434; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to Resource Economics majors, others with instructor consent. Not open to students who have passed ARE 3434W.
description: A writing intensive class integrated with course content in ARE 3434.

name: ARE3462
catalogName: Measuring Impact of Programs that Raise Human Well-being
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: ARE 1150 or ECON 1200 or 1201. Not open to students who have completed ARE 3464.
description: The theory and practice behind measuring impacts and costs of programs that raise human welfare through poverty alleviation, economic development, and social and environmental justice. Case studies will show how governments and organizations can best optimize programming. Examples include how to increase incomes and farm productivity, how to decrease disease and child mortality, and how to improve resilience to climate change. Topics include survey design, performance indicators, the logical framework and results matrix, sample design, impact evaluation methodologies and project appraisal.

name: ARE4205
catalogName: Market Planning and Survey Research in the Food Industry
prerequisites: ARE 1150 and 3333.
description: Overview of market planning in the food industry, with emphasis on survey design and implementation. Student groups will work with clients to develop tailored market plans.

name: ARE4217
prerequisites: ARE 1150 or ECON 1200 or 1201; open to juniors or higher.
description: Theory and practice of business finance and investment management, including sources of funding, the capital structure of corporations, the actions that managers take to increase the value of the firm, and the tools and analysis used to allocate financial resources. Emphasis on investment decision-making, corporate risk management, capital flow management, and mergers and acquisitions. Use of real-world applications to provide students with a solid background in the economic theory of business finance and investment management in food and resource industries.

name: ARE4279
prerequisites: Recommended preparation:  ARE 1150 or ECON 1200 or 1201.
description: The basic principles of international commodity trade and market institutions. Applications to current problems of international commodity trade and policy.

name: ARE4305
prerequisites: ARE 1150 or ECON 1200 or ECON 1201; MATH 1071Q or 1110Q or 1120Q or 1126Q or 1131Q. Credit may not be received for both ARE 4305 and 5305.
description: The role of sustainable economic development of less developed economies.  Microeconomic dimensions of agricultural development, food security, agricultural production and supply, foreign assistance, and government programming.

name: ARE4438
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ARE4438E
prerequisites: ARE 1150 or ECON 1200 or ECON 1201
description: Conceptual and practical understanding of main methods used to evaluate economic  benefits of environmental protection and damages from degradation.  Methods include: change in productivity, hedonic pricing, travel cost method, contingent valuation, defensive expenditures, replacement costs, and cost-of-illness.  Topics covered include: recreation, soil-erosion, energy, forestry, hazardous waste, air pollution, deforestation, wetlands, wildlife, biodiversity, noise, visibility, water, and water pollution.

name: ARE4444
catalogName: Economics of Energy, Climate, and the Environment
prerequisites: ARE 1150 or ECON 1200 or ECON 1201; open to juniors or higher.
description: Economics of energy issues with special reference to local and regional environmental quality, global climate change, and energy markets. Environmental and economic implications of developing alternative sources of energy. Regulatory policies in relation to transportation, industry, commercial and residential energy use.

name: ARE4462
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ARE4462E
prerequisites: ARE 1150 or ECON 1200 or ECON 1201; MATH 1071Q or 1110 or 1120 or 1126 or 1131Q; open to juniors or higher. Credit may not be received for both ARE 4462 and 5462.
description: Natural resource use and environmental quality analysis using economic theory. Reviews of empirical research and relevant policy issues.

name: ARE4897
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to seniors; open only with consent of instructor to students in the Honors Program.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ARE4991
prerequisites: Open to junior or senior Applied and Resource Economics majors with Independent Study Authorization.
description: Provides students with a meaningful experience in a formalized applied resource economics program under supervised conditions. Each student taking this course must submit a formal written report for evaluation and meet all other course requirements as specified by the instructor. May be repeated for a total of 6 credits. Requires Independent Study Authorization with consent of department head and advisor.

name: ARE4993
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit. Consent of department head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure.

name: ARE4994
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Participation in staff conferences and discussions, reviews of important books, and reports on recent developments in economic theory and research. Credits and hours by arrangement. May be repeated for credit with a change of topic.

name: ARE4995
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Topics and credits to be published prior to the registration period preceding the semester offerings.  May be repeated for credit with a change of topic.

name: ARE4999
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Designed primarily for Resource Economics majors.  Open to students with Independent Study Authorization.

name: ARIS1170
catalogName: Women's Writing in the Contemporary Arab World
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Fiction and non-fiction by women writers from the Arab world. Texts include feminist texts, literary texts, and popular fiction, in addition to films based on literary writings and works from the visual arts. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ARIS1170W
catalogName: Women’s Contemporary Writing in the Arab World
description: An exploration of feminist texts, literary texts, and popular fiction. Topics may include: the role of women’s writing from the nineteenth century to the present in public life; women’s writing in social and political movements such as the Arab Spring; the intersectionality of class, race, gender, and nation in Arabic literature; and the unique challenges faced by Arab women writers. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ARIS1211
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An introduction to the study of Islam as an intellectual and lived religious tradition. Revelation, literature, aesthetics, philosophy, theology, and law in relation to faith practices in diverse Muslim societies across time. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ARIS2200
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Arabic films from Morocco to the Levant. Topics include identity, gender, war and displacement, Islamic heritage, pluralism, decolonization, terrorism, and the Arab-Israeli conflict. Taught in English.

name: ARIS3000
prerequisites: ARAB 1114 or instructor consent
description: Review of Arabic grammar through Qur'an and literary texts. Practice in translation and composition leading to command of idioms and vocabulary. Taught in English and Arabic.

name: ARIS3293
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of department head required, normally to be granted before the student's departure

name: ARIS3295
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary
description: With a change of topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: ARIS3298
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: ARIS3299
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ARIS3710
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.
description: A survey of the arts associated with Islam from the life of Muhammad in the seventh century through the early modern period, with an emphasis upon the Middle East, North Africa, and the Iberian Peninsula. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ARIS3710W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: A survey of the arts associated with Islam from the life of Muhammad in the seventh century through the early modern period, with an emphasis upon the Middle East, North Africa, and the Iberian Peninsula. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ART1000
prerequisites: Not open to ART majors. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: Introduction to the visual arts, past and present. The visual language of artists, historical and cultural significance of works of art. Intended primarily for students who are not art majors. CA 1.

name: ART1010
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Introduction to key concepts and practices in art making.

name: ART1020
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An introduction to various current critical approaches to the producers, contexts, audiences, and histories of contemporary visual culture.

name: ART1030
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 1040, 2011, 2110, 2310, 2410, 2510 or 2610.
description: Fundamental principles of drawing based on observation.

name: ART1040
prerequisites: ART 1030. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 2010, 3350.
description: Observational drawing; emphasis on spatial organization and structure.

name: ART2010
prerequisites: ART 1040. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 2210, 3010, or 3370.
description: Introduction to figure drawing.

name: ART2011
prerequisites: ART 1010 and 1030. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3130, 3132, or 3420.
description: Introduction to digital media.

name: ART2110
prerequisites: ART 1010 and 1030. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3170.
description: Introduction to the methods of design thinking and the process involved in translating that thinking into form. Content, meaning, form, typography, layout, structure, craft and process in graphic design, emphasizing conceptual analysis, visualization, and skillful making through the adept use of analog and digital tools.

name: ART2120
prerequisites: ART 2110; portfolio review; consent of instructor. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3130, 3131 or 3132.
description: Introduction to typographic terms, technology, and the foundations and fundamentals of typography and visual structure as a medium for expressive, conceptual, and intellectual communication.

name: ART2210
prerequisites: ART 2010 and 2310. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3210.
description: Introduction to principles of illustration, media, and techniques.

name: ART2220
description: Fundamental skills required for animation.

name: ART2310
prerequisites: ART 1010  and ART 1030.
description: Introduction to the principles and techniques of painting media.

name: ART2410
prerequisites: ART 1010 and ART 1030. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 2420, 3410, 3420 or 3440.
description: Introduction to techniques and aesthetics of photography, with emphasis on the camera.

name: ART2420
prerequisites: ART 2410. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3430, 3450, 3455, 3460, 3465, 3470, 4410.
description: Principles and techniques of black-and-white photography in fine-art applications, with emphasis on darkroom work.

name: ART2510
prerequisites: ART 1010 and 1030. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3510 or 3520.
description: Introduction to practice and principles of printmaking, including intaglio, relief and lithographic processes.

name: ART2610
prerequisites: ART 1010 and 1030.  May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3610, 3620, 3625, 3630, 3640, 3650, 3655, 3660, 3670.
description: Introduction to principles and techniques of sculpture.

name: ART2993
prerequisites: Department consent required.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Department Head required, normally before the student's departure to study abroad. May be repeated with a change in course content.

name: ART2995
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Credits and hours as determined by the Senate Curricula and Courses Committee.  This course may or may not count for credit toward graduation.  Students should consult the course syllabus and the Dean's Office of their School or College. May be repeated with a change in topic.

name: ART3010
prerequisites: ART 2010. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3020, 3030 or 3210.
description: Drawing from the figure.

name: ART3020
prerequisites: ART 3010; open to juniors or higher.  May be repeated to a maximum of 6 credits.
description: Advanced studies in figure drawing.

name: ART3030
prerequisites: ART 3010; open to juniors or higher.  With change of course content ART 3030 may be repeated to a maximum of 9 credits.
description: Advanced studies in drawing. Course content varies with instructor.

name: ART3110
prerequisites: ART 2120; open only to Art majors, others with instructor consent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 4120.
description: Investigate creative and effective visual design systems through the use of visual structure, typography, image, grid, information hierarchy and architecture.

name: ART3120
prerequisites: ART 2120 and ART 3110; open only to Art majors, others with instructor consent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 4110 or 4130.
description: Exploration of form, content, function, strategy; collaborative and integrative thinking in problem solving; using diverse communication design methodologies.

name: ART3130
prerequisites: ART 2011 and 2120 or instructor consent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3131.
description: Introduction to basic HTML web page design using Cascading Style Sheets.

name: ART3131
prerequisites: ART 2120 and 3130 or instructor consent.
description: Introduction to the design of interactive screenbased experiences.

name: ART3132
prerequisites:
ART 2011 and 2110 or instructor consent;
open only to majors, open to non-majors with instructor consent.
description: Introduction to the multi-faceted diversity of motion design - including film and television title sequences, data visualizations, web-based animations, and sound branding with an emphasis on typography in motion. Students develop competency in producing Motion Graphics via ideation and conceptualization, sketching, storyboarding and animatics, using both analog and digital methods, leading to final animations.

name: ART3170
prerequisites: ART 2110; open to sophomores or higher; open only to majors, open to non-majors with instructor consent.
description: Survey of contemporary graphic design practice as an artistic and professional discipline in visual media. In addition to critical readings, presentations, and discussions, field trips are planned to engage in dialogues with practicing professional designers and studios.

name: ART3210
prerequisites: ART 2210 and ART 3010; open to juniors or higher.  With a change in content ART 3210 may be repeated to a maximum of 9 credits.
description: Continuing problems in illustration. Projects may include book, editorial, reportage, or self-promotion illustration.

name: ART3220
prerequisites: Open only to Art majors, others by instructor consent; open to juniors and higher
description: Experimental approaches to the translation of still media into time-based form, informed by the student's prior studio art coursework and media approaches. Smart phone technology is employed to capture, organize, edit, and animate images.

name: ART3235
prerequisites: ART 2210; instructor consent required. Recommended preparation: ART 3210.
description: Exploration of techniques for the development of still and animated graphics for use in science education and scientific publications and presentations. Project-based coursework with involvement from scientific experts and close collaboration between student illustrators and animators.

name: ART3250
catalogName: Stop and Go: Explorations in Stop-Motion Animation
prerequisites: ART 2220
description: A survey of stop-motion animation techniques.

name: ART3270
