description: Representative works of German literature in English, especially from the 20th and the 21st centuries. Development of close reading and critical thinking skills, improvement of student composition, and the development of a conceptual framework for understanding another culture. CA 1.

name: GERM1169
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: Familiarizes students with contemporary German society and the cultural and historical aspects that shape everyday life in Germany in the 21st century. Students will explore a range of topics, including reunification, minorities, education and youth, the arts, and gender. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: GERM1171
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: Weekly showings of German films from the twenties to the present. Introduction to film history, analysis and interpretation of films, outside readings, term papers. Reading and lectures in English. May not be used to meet the undergraduate language requirement. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: GERM1175
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Study of philosophical discourse on human rights from the Enlightenment to the present and analysis of related ethical problems in conjunction with an examination of relevant literary texts, film, and other art forms. Study of Germany's role in the development of international human rights instruments. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: GERM1193
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure.

name: GERM1295
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 credits with a change in topic.

name: GERM1920
catalogName: Cyborgs, Robots, and Androids in the German Imaginary
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An examination of the figure of the nonhuman-human and representations of artificial beings in the German imaginary with a focus on issues of technology, art, philosophy of subjectivity, and culture. Discussion of imaginary and real robots, cyborgs, homunculi, and automata as representations of humanity’s understanding of futurity and innovation. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: GERM2400E
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Ecological thinking in German culture from the Greeks (Plato) to the Greens (Amery). The second half of the semester consists of student projects on current environmental policies in the European Union. CA 1.

name: GERM3200
prerequisites: GERM 1003, which may be taken concurrently, or equivalent.
description: Two or three weeks of concentrated study in Europe. Exclusive use of the language, with three to four daily contact hours. Practice in all active and passive language skills, combined with periodic review sessions during the rest of the semester.

name: GERM3220
prerequisites: GERM 1003, which may be taken concurrently, or equivalent.
description: Technical German in engineering through the basic concepts and problem solving techniques used in applied mechanics.

name: GERM3221
catalogName: Introduction to the Sciences in German
prerequisites: GERM 1004; CHEM 1128; PHYS 1502 or equivalent, all of which may be taken concurrently.  May not be taken out of sequence after passing 3222.
description: A series of lectures and discussion periods about basic concepts in the physical sciences presented in German. Topics will be primarily from the various engineering disciplines, chemistry, physics, and mathematics.

name: GERM3222
prerequisites: GERM 3220 and 3221.
description: A series of lectures and discussion periods on special topics in science and engineering.

name: GERM3231
prerequisites: GERM 1004 or equivalent.  Recommended preparation: GERM 3233 - 3234
description: Development of oral and written skills using a content-based methodology and drawing on authentic documents in a variety of formats that convey the language and culture of professional environments in the German-speaking countries. Preparation for the Goethe Institutes's test of German for Professional Purposes (Deutsch f\r den Beruf).

name: GERM3232
prerequisites: GERM 3231.
description: Development of oral and written skills using a content-based methodology and drawing on authentic documents in a variety of formats that convey the language and culture of professional environments in the German-speaking countries. Preparation for the Goethe Institutes's test of German for Professional Purposes (Deutsch f\r den Beruf).

name: GERM3233
catalogName: Building Language Skills Through Culture I
prerequisites: GERM 1004. Not open to students who have passed GERM 2201, 2202, 2204, or 2205. May not be taken out of sequence after passing GERM 3234.
description: Development of oral and written skills using a content-based methodology and drawing on texts that deal with issues in contemporary culture of German-speaking countries. Emphasis on acquisition of a sophisticated understanding of cultural differences while building vocabulary, improving accuracy, and increasing facility in self-expression and communication.

name: GERM3234
catalogName: Building Language Skills Through Culture II
prerequisites: GERM 3233.  Not open for credit to students who have passed GERM 2202 or 2205
description: Development of oral and written skills using a content-based methodology and drawing on texts that deal with issues in contemporary culture of German-speaking countries. Emphasis on acquisition of a sophisticated understanding of cultural differences while building vocabulary, improving accuracy, and increasing facility in self-expression and communication.

name: GERM3245
prerequisites: GERM 3233, which may be taken concurrently, or consent of instructor.
description: German grammar and etymology for advanced students. A conceptual foundation for communicative language skills and comparison with English.

name: GERM3251
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An interdisciplinary course on the German-speaking countries, analyzing cultural life and past and present development. Period or thematic emphasis may vary. Discussion of selected non-fictional and fictional readings, films, slides and recordings. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: GERM3252W
prerequisites: GERM 3233, which may be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011.
description: Study of a cohesive group of texts that mark the periods of the Middle Ages, Humanism, Reformation, and Baroque. Emphasis may vary. Attention will be given to the relevant socio-historical context and, when possible, to the visual and performing arts. Taught in German. CA 1.

name: GERM3254W
prerequisites: GERM 3233, which may be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011.
description: Study of a cohesive group of texts that mark the periods of Late Romanticism, Vormärz, Realism and Naturalism. Emphasis may vary. Attention will be given to the relevant socio-historical context and to the visual and performing arts.  Taught in German. CA 1.

name: GERM3255
prerequisites: GERM 3233, which may be taken concurrently, or consent of instructor.
description: Study of a cohesive group of texts that mark the period. Attention will be given to the relevant socio-historical context and to the visual and performing arts.  Taught in German. CA 1.

name: GERM3255W
prerequisites: GERM 3233, which may be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011.
description: Study of a cohesive group of texts that mark the period. Attention will be given to the relevant socio-historical context and to the visual and performing arts.  Taught in German. CA 1.

name: GERM3258
catalogName: Germans in Africa, Blacks in German-Speaking Countries, Colonial and Post-Colonial Perspectives
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Interdisciplinary study of former German colonialism in Africa and Blacks in German-speaking societies, past and present. Construction of intercultural and interracial power and dialog in historical perspective. Diversity of black and white experiences and perspectives across class, racial-ethnic groups, gender, cultures, religions, and national borders. Discussion of selected literary and non-fictional readings, films, other visual images, and recordings. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: GERM3261W
prerequisites: GERM 3233, which may be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011.
description: Critical analysis of artistic issues in writing screenplays and making movies. Dynamic interplay between German film, the other arts, their socioeconomic context and the cinematic traditions of other cultures. Taught in German. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: GERM3264W
description: Cross-cultural comparison of film genres using examples from German film history and other cinematic traditions. Taught in English. CA 1.

name: GERM3265
prerequisites: GERM 3233, which may be taken concurrently, or consent of instructor.
description: An analysis of the cultural trends of a selected period or theme in a German-speaking country, taking into account the historical, political, and socioeconomic background, aspects of daily life, philosophical trends, major literary works and other artistic achievements in art, music, and architecture. Specialists from other departments will be invited as guest lecturers.  With a change of topic, this course may be repeated for credit.

name: GERM3292
prerequisites: Three years of college-level German or the equivalent.  Open only to juniors and seniors.
description: Placement of students as trainees in business, industry and social or government agencies where foreign language skills can be put to use.

name: GERM3293
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of advisor.

name: GERM3294
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Intensive investigation of selected problems in German literature and/or German studies.  May be repeated for credit.

name: GERM3295
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: With a change in content, this course may be repeated for credit.

name: GERM3298
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: With a change of topic, this course may be repeated for credit.

name: GERM3299
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: GERM4246
catalogName: The Finishing Touch: A Capstone in German Studies
prerequisites: GERM 3234; Six additional 2000 level or above credits in GERM.
description: Advanced students assess and polish their German language skills, consolidate their learning in German Studies, and demonstrate that learning in a final project.

name: GPS3081
prerequisites: BGS students only.
description: Open only with consent of instructor and BGS mentor/advisor. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: GPS3099
prerequisites: BGS students only.
description: Open only with consent of instructor and BGS mentor/advisor. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: GPS4278
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Integrates the fields of general and interdisciplinary studies. Traces emergence of interdisciplinary studies and compares different academic disciplines. Future of interdisciplnary studies is assessed. With a change of topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: GPS4278W
description: Integrates the fields of general and interdisciplinary studies. Traces emergence of interdisciplinary studies and compares different academic disciplines. Future of interdisciplnary studies is assessed. With a change of topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: GSCI1000E
catalogName: The Human Epoch: Living in the Anthropocene
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Introduction to geoscience focusing on human activities as agents of geologic change. Examines human planetary processes in our current epoch, the Anthropocene. Provides a novel frame for contemporary environmental issues such as climate change, sustainability, mass extinctions, land use, and waste disposal. Interaction between earthly processes and human affairs. CA 3.

name: GSCI1010
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed GSCI 1050, 1051, 1055, or 1070.
description: A reconstruction of the Mesozoic world of the dinosaurs based on paleontological and geological evidence. Past and present environmental catastrophes leading to mass extinctions and changes in biodiversity. Fundamental concepts of geology, stratigraphy, historical geology, and paleoclimatology. CA 3.

name: GSCI1050
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed GSCI 1010, 1051, 1055, or 1070.
description: Origin and history of planet Earth, emphasizing how rock, air, water, and life interact at different scales to produce the earth's crust, landforms, life systems, natural resources, catastrophes, and climatic regimes. Provides a scientific context for human-induced global change. CA 3-LAB.

name: GSCI1051
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed GSCI 1010, 1050, 1055, or 1070.
description: Origin and history of planet Earth, emphasizing how rock, air, water, and life interact at different scales to produce the earth's crust, landforms, life systems, natural resources, catastrophes, and climatic regimes. Provides a scientific context for human-induced global change. Students who complete both GSCI 1051 and 1052 may request that GSCI 1051 be converted to a CA 3 Laboratory course. CA 3.

name: GSCI1052
prerequisites: Corequisite: GSCI 1010.
description: Laboratory complement to GSCI 1010, 1051, 1055, and 1070. Provides an opportunity to work with specimens (minerals, fossils, rocks), terrain images, maps, physical models, and simulation experiments. Includes local field trips. Students who complete both GSCI 1052 and one of GSCI 1010, 1051, 1055 or 1070 may request that the prerequisite be converted to a CA 3 Laboratory course.

name: GSCI1053
catalogName: Discussion Earth and Life Through Time
prerequisites: GSCI 1050 or 1051 or 1052 (must be taken concurrently) or instructor consent.
description: Faculty-taught weekly discussions to enhance GSCI 1050 and 1051. Emphasis and approach will vary, but all sections will track the lecture syllabus. May be repeated for credit with instructor consent.

name: GSCI1054
catalogName: Field Trips Earth and Life Through Time
prerequisites: GSCI 1050 or 1051 or 1052 (must be taken concurrently) or instructor consent.
description: Two or more faculty-led weekend field trips to nearby sites of interest, designed to enhance GSCI 1050 and 1051.

name: GSCI1055
prerequisites: Open only to Honors students. Not open for credit to students who have passed GSCI 1010, 1050, 1051, 1070.
description: An Honors Core course. Foundation course in geology linked to the American Landscape through readings from American history and literature. Students who complete both GSCI 1055 and GSCI 1052 may request that GSCI 1055 be converted to a CA 3 Laboratory course. CA 3.

name: GSCI1070
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed GSCI 1010, 1050, 1051, 1055.
description: Climate change, global warming, natural hazards, earth surface processes, and the impact these have on human populations now and in the past. Students who complete both GSCI 1070 and GSCI 1052 may request that GSCI 1070 be converted to a CA 3 Laboratory course. CA 3.

name: GSCI2050W
description: An exploration of different aspects of Earth and environmental science involving human planetary impacts that hones the writing skills used for different modes of communication. Geoscience topics will involve climate change, natural hazards, natural resources, earth history, geo-education, and landscape interpretation. Modes of communication will include some combination of field notes, oral presentations, interviews, videos, podcasts, websites, essays, opinions, reviews, and technical articles.

name: GSCI2310
catalogName: National Parks Unearthed: Geology and Landscapes through Time
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: GSCI2310E
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Geologic processes that create the Earth’s iconic landscapes through the study of National Parks, Monuments, and Seashores. Plate tectonics, climate and biotic change, natural hazards, Earth materials and resources, environmental conservation, and the interactions between human society and the natural world.

name: GSCI2500
prerequisites: GSCI 1050 or both GSCI 1052 and one of GSCI 1010 or GSCI 1051 or GSCI 1055 or GEOG/GSCI 1070.
description: Introduction to earth system science, geoscience research methods, and professional practice through lab work, field work in UConn Forest, visits to faculty labs, and culminating project.

name: GSCI2800
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed NRE 3145 or 3146.
description: An introduction to atmospheric science, including a history of the field, features of the atmosphere, weather forecasting, and a geologic history of climate change. CA 3

name: GSCI3010
prerequisites: GSCI 1050 or both GSCI 1052 and one of GSCI 1010 or 1051 or 1055 or 1070 or GEOG 1070
description: Reconstruction of earth history from geological data. Processes and events responsible for the stratigraphic record, and techniques used to decipher it.  An integrated survey of earth history. One or more weekend field trips may be required.

name: GSCI3020
prerequisites: GSCI 1050 or both GSCI 1052 and one of GSCI 1010 or 1051 or 1055 or 1070 or GEOG 1070
description: Processes responsible for the formation of the unconsolidated materials, landforms, and soils which constitute the Earth's surface. Introduction to surface-water and groundwater hydrology, geological hazards and the effects of climatic change. One or more weekend field trips may be required.

name: GSCI3030
prerequisites: GSCI 1050 or both GSCI 1052 and one of GSCI 1010 or 1051 or 1055 or 1070 or GEOG 1070
description: Description and interpretation of geological structures; stress and strain; contractional, extensional, and strike-slip tectonics; survey of New England geology; and application of principles of structural geology to environmental issues. One full-day field trip on a weekend may be required.

name: GSCI3040
prerequisites: GSCI 1050 or both GSCI 1052 and one of GSCI 1010 or 1051 or 1055 or 1070 or GEOG 1070. Recommended preparation: CHEM 1124-1126 or 1127 and 1128.
description: Principles of symmetry and crystal chemistry and the identification of minerals by hand sample, petrographic and x-ray methods. Description of the mineralogy and texture of igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks and the application of contemporary petrogenetic models to the interpretation of the geologic environments they record. One or more weekend field trips may be required.

name: GSCI3230
prerequisites: MARN 1002 or MARN 1003 or GSCI 1050 or GSCI 1051, or consent of instructor.
description: Introduction to the processes that form and modify coasts and beaches, including tectonic setting, sediment supply, coastal composition, energy regimes and sea level change; tools and techniques utilized in marine geologic mapping and reconstruction of submerged coastal features; field trips to selected coastal features.

name: GSCI3710
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: GSCI 1050 or 1051.
description: Application of geological principles to engineering and environmental problems. Topics include site investigation, geologic hazards, slope processes, earthquakes, subsidence, and the engineering properties of geologic materials. Course intended for both geoscience and engineering majors.

name: GSCI3990
prerequisites: GSCI 1050 or both GSCI 1052 and one of GSCI 1010 or 1051 or 1055 or 1070 or GEOG 1070
description: A field-based introduction to the integration of geological and biological observations and processes.  Field trip during and weekly meetings before and after spring break.  May be repeated for credit with change in field venue or permission of the instructor.

name: GSCI4050W
prerequisites: GSCI 1050 or 1051; at least two 2000-level or above GSCI courses one of which may be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; or instructor consent; open to juniors or higher.
description: Application of fundamental geological principles to issues of concern to society such as global climate change; wildfires; drought and water resources; earthquake, volcano, and tsunami hazards; medical geology; energy resources; sustainability; and coastal processes.

name: GSCI4110
prerequisites:
GSCI 1050 or both GSCI 1052 and one of GSCI 1010 or 1051 or 1055 or 1070 or GEOG 1070.

Recommended preparation: GSCI 3020.
description: Basic principles of sedimentology with an emphasis on the description of sedimentary texture and structure. Physicochemical and biological processes that characterize depositional environments. Diagenesis. Examination of modern systems to interpret ancient sedimentary environments. One or more weekend field trips may be required.

name: GSCI4120
prerequisites: GSCI 1050; or both GSCI 1052 and one of GSCI 1010 or 1051 or 1055 or 1070 or GEOG 1070; or BIOL 1108.
description: Ancient life, including the preservation of organisms as fossils, evolution, ecology, geobiology, biostratigraphy, and major events in the history of life. Includes microorganisms, animals, and plants.

name: GSCI4130
prerequisites: CHEM 1124Q, 1125Q and 1126Q; or CHEM 1127Q and 1128Q; or GSCI 2500; or permission of instructor.
description: Microbial diversity and biogeochemistry in aquatic ecosystems, microbe-mineral interactions, fossil record, atmospheric record, microbialites, and research methodology in geomicrobiology. A weekend field trip may be required.

name: GSCI4140
prerequisites: GSCI 1010 and 1052, or GSCI 1070 and 1052, or GSCI 1051 and 1052, or GSCI 1050
description: Tectonic and environmental controls on the development and evolution of sedimentary basins. Emphasis on mechanisms of formation, characteristic depositional patterns, and sediment composition in modern and ancient tectonic settings. Basin analysis methods include sedimentology, stratigraphy, geochemistry, provenance and paleocurrent analysis, subsidence modeling, and interpretation of geophysical data.

name: GSCI4150
catalogName: Applied Data Analysis in Earth Science
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: STAT 1000Q or 1100Q, GEOG 3500Q; open to juniors or higher.
description: Multivariate spatial analysis methods and statistical inference in earth science, emphasizing how to translate conceptual understanding into computer code.

name: GSCI4210
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: GSCI 3020.
description: The climates and dynamics of glaciers, the geologic processes responsible for the materials and landforms of glaciated regions, and the applications of glacial geology to paleoclimatology, paleoecology, land use history, hydrology, engineering, and natural resources. Includes two weekend days of field trips to be scheduled.

name: GSCI4230
catalogName: GIS and Remote Sensing for Geoscience Applications
prerequisites: GEOG 2300; or GSCI 1050 or both GSCI 1052 and one of GSCI 1010 or 1051 or 1055 or 1070 or GEOG 1070.
description: Application of Geographic Information Systems, remote sensing, and image interpretation to problems in geoscience. Data acquisition, processing and analysis of Digital Elevation Models and satellite imagery. Geologic materials, processes, landforms and landscapes.

name: GSCI4240
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: GSCI 3020.
description: Introduction to watershed processes, lake systems, late Pleistocene to present environmental change, the environmental impacts of dams, and the application of sediment coring. Includes field trips to lakes and reservoirs in eastern Connecticut.

name: GSCI4330
prerequisites: GSCI 1050; or both GSCI 1052 and one of GSCI 1010 or 1051 or 1055 or 1070 or GEOG 1070; or GEOG 2300; or consent of instructor. Recommended preparation: GSCI 3020 and 3030.
description: Tectonic processes that shape the Earth's surface, particularly its landforms.  Emphasis on short-term processes that produce disasters and catastrophes and affect human society.

name: GSCI4390
prerequisites: GSCI 3030, which may be taken concurrently.
description: Mapping techniques and map interpretation using concepts developed in GEOL 3030. Emphasis on mapping moderately deformed rocks in which sedimentary features can be differentiated.

name: GSCI4430
prerequisites: CHEM 1127Q.
description: Fundamentals of stable isotope biogeochemistry. Origin of elements and stable isotopes; equilibrium and kinetic fractionation; isotope systematics of carbon, nitrogen, hydrogen, oxygen, and sulfur; biogeochemical systems; isotopes as a forensic tracer; and isotopes in paleoclimate and paleoenvironmental research.

name: GSCI4510
prerequisites: PHYS 1230 or 1402Q or 1502Q or 1602Q, which may be taken concurrently; MATH 1122Q or 1132Q or 1152Q, which may be taken concurrently.
description: Principles of imaging the Earth's interior using observations of electric, magnetic, and gravity fields, with applications to environmental problems.

name: GSCI4520
prerequisites: PHYS 1230 or 1402Q or 1502Q or 1602Q, which may be taken concurrently; MATH 1121Q or 1131Q or 1151Q, which may be taken concurrently.
description: Principles of seismic methods for imaging the interior of the earth, with applications to resource exploration and environmental problems.

name: GSCI4550
prerequisites: PHYS 1230 or 1402Q or 1502Q or 1530 or 1602Q, any of which may be taken concurrently; MATH 1122Q or 1126Q or 1131Q any of which may be taken concurrently.  Recommended preparation: MATH 1132Q.
description: The composition, structure, and dynamics of the Earth's core, mantle, and crust inferred from observations of seismology, geomagnetism, and heat flow.

name: GSCI4560
prerequisites: PHYS 1230 or 1402Q or 1502Q or 1530 or 1602Q, any of which may be taken concurrently; MATH 1122 or 1126Q or 1131Q, any of which may be taken concurrently.
description: Evolution of the solar system, celestial mechanics, tidal friction, internal composition of planets, black-body radiation, planetary atmospheres.

name: GSCI4710
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed GSCI 4998 when offered as "Environmental Site Assessment."
description: Introduction to hydrogeological environmental site assessments (ESAs), emphasizing southern New England. Identification of areas of concern; determination of sources of groundwater pollution; and characterization of contamination extent, sampling, modeling, and interpretation.

name: GSCI4720
prerequisites: CHEM 1127Q. Prerequisite or Corequisite: MATH 1110Q or 1131Q or 1151Q.
description: Introduction to geochemistry of terrestrial and aqueous environmental systems. Chemical weathering and water-rock interactions; geochemistry of natural waters; chemical systems of the geosphere, biosphere and atmosphere; and geochemistry and climate.

name: GSCI4735
prerequisites: GSCI 1050, or both GSCI 1052 and one of GSCI 1010, 1051, 1055, or 1070; open to juniors or higher.
description: Basic hydrologic principles with emphasis on ground water flow and quality, geologic relationships, quantitative analysis and field methods. Occasional field trips.

name: GSCI4810
catalogName: Modeling the Changing Atmosphere and Ocean
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: MATH 1060 or MATH 1131, or PHYS 1201 or PHYS 1202.
description: Modeling past and future climate, with an emphasis on conceptual understanding of the earth system and simulation results from climate models of different complexities.

name: GSCI4850
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: GSCI 1010, 1050, 1055, or 1070.
description: Introduction to the geological evidence, research methods, and hypotheses associated with major climatic events in Earth's history through a combination of lectures, discussions of scientific papers, and a climate modeling project.

name: GSCI4989
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Independent research for the advanced undergraduate student interested in investigating a special problem involving field and/or laboratory observations in geoscience. The student is required to give an oral presentation in a departmental seminar at the end of the semester.

name: GSCI4990
prerequisites: GSCI 3010 and 3020 and 3030 and 3040, all of which may be taken concurrently. Must be taken concurently with GSCI 4991.
description: An internship program under the direction of Geoscience faculty. Students will be placed with government agencies or businesses where academic training will be applied in a program of activities to be planned and agreed upon in advance by the job site supervisor, the faculty coordinator, and the intern. One credit may be earned for each 42 hours of pre-approved activities up to a maximum of three credits. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory.)  May not be repeated.

name: GSCI4991
prerequisites: GSCI 3010 and 3020 and 3030 and 3040, all of which may be taken concurrently. GSCI 4990 must be taken concurrently.
description: Preparation of written report and oral presentation to Department summarizing internship experience and evaluating the applicability of academic experience to job situations and the impact of the internship experience on academic and career plans.  May not be repeated.

name: GSCI4995
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Investigation of special topics related to, but not ordinarily covered in the undergraduate offerings; emphasis on laboratory projects.  May  be repeated for credit.

name: GSCI4996W
prerequisites: GSCI 4989; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Writing of a formal thesis based on independent research conducted by the student.

name: GSCI4998
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: With a change of topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: GSCI4999
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated for credit.

name: HCMI3221
prerequisites: Open only to Business and Mathematics-Actuarial Science-Finance majors of junior or higher status. Not open to students who have passed FNCE 3221.
description: A study of the concept of risk and its treatment by insurance. It covers why the individual or corporation purchases insurance, what constitutes an intelligent insurance plan and what products are available in the insurance marketplace.

name: HCMI3240
prerequisites: Open to Business students and Allied Health students in the Healthcare Administration concentration of sophomore or higher status. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HCMI 4225, 4243, or 4250.
description: This course demonstrates how basic economic concepts, principles, and theories can be used to think about and illuminate various health care issues. Rather than focus on a few current health care problems, attention is directed toward an array of health-related topics. Students are provided with a set of economic tools to evaluate a theoretical or empirical argument relating to health or medical care. The course culminates with an in-depth analysis of the structure, conduct, and performance of the markets for physician services, hospital services, pharmaceutical products, and long-term care.

name: HCMI3243
prerequisites: HCMI 3240 or ECON 1201; open only to Business majors and Allied Health majors in the Healthcare Administration concentration of junior or higher status.
description: This course demonstrates how basic economic concepts, principles, and theories can be used to think about and illuminate various health care issues. Rather than focus on a few current health care problems, attention is directed toward an array of health-related topics. Students are provided with a set of economic tools to evaluate a theoretical or empirical argument relating to health or medical care. The course culminates with an in-depth analysis of the structure, conduct, and performance of the markets for physician services, hospital services, pharmaceutical products, and long-term care.

name: HCMI3243
prerequisites: HCMI 3240 or ECON 1201; open only to Business majors and Allied Health majors in the Healthcare Administration concentration of junior or higher status.
description: This course demonstrates how basic economic concepts, principles, and theories can be used to think about and illuminate various health care issues. Rather than focus on a few current health care problems, attention is directed toward an array of health-related topics. Students are provided with a set of economic tools to evaluate a theoretical or empirical argument relating to health or medical care. The course culminates with an in-depth analysis of the structure, conduct, and performance of the markets for physician services, hospital services, pharmaceutical products, and long-term care.

name: HCMI4225
prerequisites: HCMI 3240, or permission of instructor; open only to business majors of junior or higher status.
description: Addresses various business practices associated with providing private health insurance such as underwriting, medical claims cost control, pricing, and marketing. In that context, managed care techniques and benefit package designs including consumer directed health plans, and value-based insurance design, are discussed. Attention is also paid to design and functioning of various social insurance programs such as Medicare, Medicaid, unemployment compensation, disability insurance, workers compensation, and social security.

name: HCMI4243
prerequisites: HCMI 3240 or instructor consent; open only to business majors of junior or higher status.
description: Introduction to the United States legal system as it relates to health care, public health and ethics. Sessions represent important applications of law to health including the powers of the state governments; privacy and confidentiality in health care; the right to privacy; the right to refuse treatment and end of life issues; hospital, physician and managed care liability; the Americans with Disabilities Act; and public health policy and advocacy. Structured to encourage lively and interesting in-class discussions of legal and ethical principles as they relate to the health care system.

name: HCMI4250
catalogName: Cost-Benefit Analysis for Healthcare Business and Policy
prerequisites: HCMI 3240; open only to business majors of junior or higher status.
description: This course provides students with cost-benefit analysis tools to enhance healthcare business and policy decision making. The following topics will be covered: methods to estimate the monetary equivalence of costs and benefits; interpretation of research findings; simulation methods to derive the aggregate effects of firm and policy interventions; time value of money and discounting; hypothesis testing; cost-effectiveness analysis; causal inference concepts to differentiate descriptive associations from cause-and-effect studies. In addition to course lectures, the instructor will present research articles providing credible input for business- and policy-level cost-benefit analysis.

name: HCMI4325
prerequisites: HCMI 3221; open only to Business and Mathematics-Actuarial Science-Finance majors of sophomore or higher status.
description: Focuses on the basic principles underlying life insurance, pensions, and other methods of insuring for financial security. Emphasis is given to the following general topics - the need for life insurance and annuities, individual retirement planning, employer provided group insurance and pensions, types of life insurance and annuity contracts, deferred compensation plans, the mathematics of life insurance, company operations, regulation,  settlement options and life insurance programming.

name: HCMI4326
catalogName: Risk Management: Property and Liability Exposures
prerequisites: HCMI 3221; open to juniors or higher. Not open to students who have passed FNCE 4326
description: Critically examines the risk management process introduced in HCMI 3221. Emphasis is on identification and treatment of pure loss exposures faced by commercial and institutional entities. Available risk management treatment techniques are identified and discussed. Analysis of applicable commercial property and liability insurance coverages is stressed.

name: HCMI4448
catalogName: Clinical and Social Issues in Health Care
prerequisites: Open only to business majors of junior or higher status.
description: Covers clinical and social issues affecting health care provider organizations, such as the health needs of special population groups, public health concerns, epidemiological issues, and health care quality. Discussion will include how health care organizations address such issues through methods including clinical studies, disease management, partnership between private and public sectors, and legislative initiatives.

name: HCMI4881
prerequisites: Open only to Business majors of junior or higher status; consent of instructor and Program Director required prior to beginning the internship.
description: Supervised internship in a health care organization where students work with health care professionals to expand their expertise in solving health systems problems and increase their awareness of the issues involved in the day to day operations of a health care institution. Student performance will be evaluated on the basis of an appraisal by the field supervisor and a detailed written report submitted by the student. Formerly offered as HCMI 4891.

name: HCMI4891
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HCMI4895
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open only to business majors of junior or higher status.
description: Classroom course in special topics in health systems management as announced in advance for semester.  With a change in content,  may be repeated for credit.

name: HCMI4899
prerequisites: Open only to business majors of junior or higher status.
description: Individual study of special topics in health systems management as mutually arranged between a student and an instructor.

name: HCMI4997W
catalogName: Senior Thesis in Health Care Management and Insurance Studies
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to Health Care Management and Insurance Studies majors enrolled in the honors program; instructor consent required.
description: Individual study of special topics on health care management and insurance.

name: HDFS1060
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: Theory and research on topics in the close relationship literature including attraction, relationship development and maintenance, friendship and social support, love, sexuality, intimacy, power, communication, conflict, dissolution and divorce, and bereavement. CA 2.

name: HDFS1070
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing HDFS 3250 or 4133. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: Human development throughout the life span, with emphasis upon the family as a primary context. CA 2.

name: HDFS1083
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Credits and hours by arrangement. Consent of Director of Undergraduate Studies required, preferably prior to student's departure. With a change in content, this course may be repeated for credit. Special topics taken in a foreign study program.

name: HDFS1095
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: Credits, prerequisites and hours as determined by the Senate Curricula and Course Committee.  May be repeated for credit with a change in topic.

name: HDFS2001
catalogName: Diversity Issues in Human Development and Family Sciences
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: HDFS 1070.
description: Critical issues in diversity and multiculturalism in human development, family relations, and professional practice. CA 4.

name: HDFS2001
catalogName: Diversity Issues in Human Development and Family Studies
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: HDFS 1070.
description: Critical issues in diversity and multiculturalism in human development, family relations, and professional practice. CA 4.

name: HDFS2004W
catalogName: Research Methods in Human Development and Family Sciences
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; HDFS 1070, which may be taken concurrently; open only to HDFS majors, sophomores or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HDFS 3092, 4004, or 4007.
description: Overview of research methods with emphasis on the social context in which research occurs and is used, and strengths and limitations of social science research methods. Includes topics such as hypothesis formation, measurement of social variables, research ethics, data collection techniques, and interpreting results.

name: HDFS2004W
catalogName: Research Methods in Human Development and Family Studies
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; HDFS 1070, which may be taken concurrently; open only to HDFS majors, sophomores or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HDFS 3092, 4004, or 4007.
description: Overview of research methods with emphasis on the social context in which research occurs and is used, and strengths and limitations of social science research methods. Includes topics such as hypothesis formation, measurement of social variables, research ethics, data collection techniques, and interpreting results.

name: HDFS2083
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Credits and hours by arrangement. Consent of Director of Undergraduate Studies required, preferably prior to student's departure. With a change in content, this course may be repeated for credit. A maximum of six credits can be used to meet major requirements. Special topics taken in a foreign study program.

name: HDFS2100
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HDFS 3341 or 4181.
description: Individual development and behavior from prenatal period through adolescence; impact of peers, school, other social agencies, and especially the family.

name: HDFS2142E
catalogName: Exploring Conservation and Sustainability with Preschoolers
prerequisites: Instructor consent. Recommended preparation: HDFS 1070.
description: Introduction to the broad fields of sustainability and conservation through place-based learning experiences. Explores the importance of environmental stewardship by actively engaging with preschool children in project-based learning related to conservation and sustainability throughout the semester. CA 2.

name: HDFS2200
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Individual development and behavior from young adulthood through later life with special attention given to family and social influences. Physical, cognitive, social and personality changes, role transitions, and interpersonal and intergenerational relationships.

name: HDFS2300
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HDFS 3319 or 3420.
description: Family interaction: communication processes, bonding behaviors, management of conflict and aggression, negotiation of family crisis.

name: HDFS3042
catalogName: Baseball and Society: Politics, Economics, Race and Gender
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Baseball in historical, political, sociological, and economic contexts. Topics may include: impact on individuals and families; racial discrimination and integration; labor relations; urbanization; roles of women; treatment of gay athletes; and implications of performance-enhancing drugs.

name: HDFS3080
prerequisites: GPA of 2.5 in HDFS courses and at least 15 credits of 2000 level or above HDFS courses. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HDFS 3090.
description: Supervised participation in settings where purposes and functions are related to the development and welfare of individuals and families. May be repeated up to a maximum of six credits.

name: HDFS3083
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit. A maximum of six credits can be used to meet major requirements. Consent of Director of Undergraduate Studies required, preferably prior to student's departure.

name: HDFS3087
prerequisites: Open only with consent of instructor to students in the Honors Program. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HDFS 4097.
description: Overview of the Human Development and Family Studies Honors Programs and the opportunities available through University Honors. Includes presentations by HDFS faculty members and discussions with faculty regarding research. Provides direction to students planning honors theses.

name: HDFS3090
prerequisites: HDFS 3080;  GPA of 2.5 in HDFS courses and 15 units of 2000 level or above HDFS courses.
description: Supervised participation in settings where purposes and functions are related to the development and welfare of individuals and families.  Cannot be repeated for credit. Cannot be used towards meeting major requirements in HDFS nor towards meeting GPA requirements in HDFS.  Weekly seminar required. Practicum by arrangement.

name: HDFS3092
catalogName: Research Practicum in Human Development and Family Sciences
prerequisites: HDFS 2004W; GPA of 2.5 in HDFS courses.
description: Supervised experience conducting research in human development and family sciences.

name: HDFS3092
catalogName: Research Practicum in Human Development and Family Studies
prerequisites: HDFS 2004W; GPA of 2.5 in HDFS courses.
description: Supervised experience conducting research in human development and family sciences.

name: HDFS3095
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HDFS3098
catalogName: Variable Topics in Human Development and Family Sciences
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change in content this course may be repeated for credit.

name: HDFS3101
prerequisites: HDFS 2100, or PSYC 2400; HDFS 2004, or NURS 3205, or PSYC 2100, or SOCI 3201, which may be taken concurrently; open to juniors or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HDFS 4181.
description: Study of children from birth to three years from an integrated human development perspective; biological and social contextual influences.

name: HDFS3102
prerequisites: HDFS 2100, or PSYC 2400; HDFS 2004, or NURS 3205, or PSYC 2100, or SOCI 3201, which may be taken concurrently; open to juniors or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HDFS 4181.
description: Study of children ages 3-8 years from an integrated human development perspective that focuses on the interdependence of physical growth and cognitive, emotional, and social development.

name: HDFS3103
prerequisites: HDFS 2100, or PSYC 2400; HDFS 2004, or NURS 3205, or PSYC 2100, or SOCI 3201, which may be taken concurrently; open to juniors or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HDFS 3341.
description: Theoretical approaches to adolescence; contextual research findings regarding adolescent development, with an emphasis on evaluating the match between these findings and the lived experience of adolescents; interventions designed to help adolescents meet the challenges of contemporary life.

name: HDFS3110
catalogName: Social and Community Influence on Children in the United States
prerequisites: HDFS 2100 or PSYC 2400; open to juniors or higher.
description: Based on an ecological/contextual perspective students investigate the impact on child development of community characteristics and social groups and organizations on the development of children in the United States. Possible topics include: family, peers, schools, media, economic status, health care, social services, and the legal system. For each topic, focus is on factors related to promoting resilience.

name: HDFS3120
catalogName: Introduction to Programs for Young Children
prerequisites: Must be taken concurrently with HDFS 3180 or 3183; open to juniors or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HDFS 3126 or 4181.
description: Components of early care and education programs. Guided observations are integrated with lecture material. Designed for students who intend to work with infants and young children.

name: HDFS3122
catalogName: Integrated Curriculum Methods and Materials for Infants and Toddlers
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Integration of child development theory with best teaching practices for developmentally appropriate learning for children from birth to three years in specific domains including arts, sensory motor, social/emotional, and physical development.

name: HDFS3123
catalogName: Integrated Curriculum Methods and Materials for Preschool and Kindergarten
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Integration of child development theory with best teaching practices for developmentally appropriate learning for children from preschool through kindergarten in specific domains including cognitive development, mathematical and scientific thinking, social studies, and personal/social development.

name: HDFS3125
catalogName: Emergent Literacy and Language Arts in Early Childhood Education
prerequisites: HDFS 2100 or PSYC 2400; and HDFS 3122 or HDFS 3123; open to juniors or higher.
description: Developmentally and individually appropriate integrated curriculum methods and materials in emergent literacy and language arts for children birth to eight.

name: HDFS3127
catalogName: Professional Development and Advocacy in Early Childhood
prerequisites: HDFS 3120. Consent of the instructor is required. Not open to students who completed HDFS 3126.
description: Historical, philosophical, psychological, and contemporary influences on the field. Comprehensive services, the workforce, quality, funding, and child outcomes. Focus on each student's professional development and on advocacy for change.

name: HDFS3141
catalogName: Developmental Approaches to Intergroup Relations and Victimization
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: HDFS 2001.
description: Developmental, social-ecological, and social psychological theories of the fundamental processes involved in intergroup relations; cognitive, affective, and social underpinnings of intergroup dynamics; critical issues of diversity and social justice in the lives of children and families; experiences of intergroup discrimination and victimization such as bullying and exclusion; theoretical approaches to improving intergroup relations and tolerance. CA 2. CA 4.

name: HDFS3180
catalogName: Programs for Young Children: Introductory Laboratory
prerequisites: Open only to students concurrently enrolled in HDFS 3120.
description: Guided observation and participation in a program for young children.

name: HDFS3181
prerequisites: HDFS 3101, which may be taken concurrently.  Not open to students who have passed HDFS 3182.
description: Observation of children ages 8 weeks to two years in early care and education programs.

name: HDFS3182
prerequisites: HDFS 3102, which may be taken concurrently. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HDFS 3181.
description: Observing young children in early care and education settings.

name: HDFS3183
catalogName: Early Childhood Development and Education: Supervised Fieldwork Practicum
prerequisites: HDFS 3120 and 3180; and both HDFS 3101 and 3181 or both HDFS 3102 and 3182;  HDFS 3122 or 3123, which may be concurrent; open to juniors or higher.
description: Supervised participation with typically developing and special needs children within the Child Development Lab classrooms. Topics include understanding informed observation and how relationships and play guide early learning and development.

name: HDFS3240
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Social gerontology: the role and status of older people in a changing society. May be used only once to meet the distribution requirements.

name: HDFS3240W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Social gerontology: the role and status of older people in a changing society.

name: HDFS3249
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Aging process as it impacts on men and women; historical and cross-cultural perspectives, changing family roles, including grandparenthood and widowhood, and implications of changing gender roles for self-actualization of older persons.

name: HDFS3250
prerequisites: HDFS 1070; open to juniors or higher.
description: Introduction to disabilities, approaching the topic from historical, developmental-lifespan, individual, and family perspectives. Topics include social constructions, models, definitions, and types of disabilities, disability rights, public policy, and philosophies and systems of education and support for individuals and families.

name: HDFS3251
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Politics and ethics of treating and/or preventing disabilities in reproduction and across the lifespan. Family/caregiver experiences analyzed through disability studies, medical sociology, science and technology studies, and bioethics.

name: HDFS3252
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Cultural context of death, personal meaning of death at different stages  in life cycle, and the effect of death upon survivors.

name: HDFS3261
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Men's gender role socialization over the life span; men's developmental issues, gender role, conflicts, and interpersonal dynamics with women. Theory, research, and personal exploration are integrated. CA 4.

name: HDFS3268
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Critical discussion of issues involving gender and sexuality among Latinos, with particular attention to race, class, ethnicity, and  acculturation.

name: HDFS3277
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Contemporary issues concerning human sexuality; impact upon individuals and family units.

name: HDFS3310
catalogName: Parent Child Relations in Cross-Cultural Perspective
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Theory and research on major dimensions of parenting in the U.S.A. and cross-culturally, parental warmth, control and punishment.

name: HDFS3311
prerequisites: HDFS 2100 or PSYC 2400; HDFS 1070 or 2200; open to juniors or higher.
description: Parent behavior and the dynamics of parenthood; interpersonal, familial, and societal roles of parents and variables influencing these roles across the lifespan. CA 2.

name: HDFS3319
catalogName: Risk and Resilience in Individuals and Families
prerequisites: HDFS 2300; open to juniors or higher.
description: Challenges, stresses, and crises experienced by individuals and families; protective factors and resilience; coping strategies; prevention and intervention.

name: HDFS3340
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.  Recommended preparation: HDFS 2300.
description: An introduction to individual, couple, family, and group intervention. Topics include counseling theories, developmentally appropriate interventions, and methods for addressing diversity. Intervention strategies used in a variety of human services settings are examined.

name: HDFS3342
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Decision-making process of families concerning the utilization of financial, personal, environmental and social resources.

name: HDFS3343
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Theory and practice of family life education including program development, implementation, evaluation, and professional ethics.

name: HDFS3420
prerequisites: HDFS 2300; open to juniors or higher.
description: Historical, psychological, sociological and legal issues relating to abuse and family violence across the lifespan, including child maltreatment and elder abuse. Introduction to methods for prevention and remediation.

name: HDFS3421
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Impact of poverty and related problems on development of the child in the context of the family. Family structure, childrearing patterns, early educational and community programs.

name: HDFS3423
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Pre-industrial and industrial family life in Western society since the Middle Ages, with emphasis on the changes in demography, family size and structure, family economy, social expectations, sex roles, sexuality, and affective bonds.

name: HDFS3425
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: HDFS 2004W; PSYC 2100WQ, or equivalent research methods course.
description: Comprehensive and critical examination of how individual characteristics, family factors, community environments, food industry actions, and government food policies work together to influence what Americans eat throughout the lifespan.

name: HDFS3430
prerequisites: HDFS 1070 or 2100 or PSYC 2400; open to juniors or higher.
description: The role of families in the education process. The effective family-school-community partnership in educating children: Communications and the implications of culture, socio-economics, family form, family dynamics, family supports, and public policy.

name: HDFS3431
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Interaction of the world of work with family structure; social psychological dynamics that enhance or impede working families' lives.

name: HDFS3442
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Overview of health and health care issues among Latinos in the United States.  Particular attention is paid to cultural and social factors associated with health and well being (e.g. migration, acculturation, SES).

name: HDFS3473
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Overview of social, cultural, educational, demographic and economic characteristics of Asian-Pacific American families. Examination and critique of values, customs, traditions and beliefs that distinguish families of this heterogeneous ethnic population.

name: HDFS3510
catalogName: Planning and Managing Human Service Programs
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Planning techniques: needs assessment, data collection and analysis, budgeting, and evaluation. Management skills: decision making, management theory and organizational behavior, personnel motivation, accountability, and financial management.

name: HDFS3520
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Overview of historical roots and key aspects of family law.  The case method is used to analyze the causes and effects of contemporary trends.  Topics include: the regulation of marriage, separation, and divorce; procreation and abortion; adoption; child custody and support; and, end-of-life issues.

name: HDFS3530
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Analysis of government programs and policies impacting the family: child care, aging, family law, mental health, family violence, income maintenance, and family impact analysis.

name: HDFS3540
catalogName: Child Welfare, Law and Social Policy
prerequisites: HDFS 2100 or PSYC 2400; HDFS 2004 or PSYC 2100Q; open to juniors or higher.
description: Examines the methods through which empirical social science research can affect law and public policy affecting children and families. CA 2.

name: HDFS3540W
catalogName: Child Welfare, Law and Social Policy
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HDFS3550
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Comparative analysis of government programs and policies impacting families in the United States and other countries. Health and welfare policies, family planning, child care, teen pregnancy, and care of the aged.

name: HDFS4004
prerequisites: HDFS 2004; 12 credits of 2000-level or above HDFS courses; open only to Human Development and Family Sciences majors.
description: Students will work as a research team to conduct a research project through all of its phases, from formulating a research question to final presentation of findings.

name: HDFS4007W
prerequisites: HDFS 2004; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; 12 additional credits of 2000 level or above HDFS courses; open to HDFS majors.
description: Development of advanced written and oral communication skills required for professional careers and graduate studies. Emphasis is placed on appropriate presentation and writing styles for the diverse audiences and purposes encountered in research and practice.

name: HDFS4087W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to students in the Honors Program only.
description: Individual study with student's honors thesis supervisor for the purpose of writing the honors thesis. Student must have a thesis advisor and have an approved thesis topic.

name: HDFS4097
prerequisites: HDFS 3087; open students in the Honors Program with instructor consent.  May be repeated to a maximum of four credits.
description: Prepares students to tackle the honors thesis by covering the basics of the thesis process. Course content will focus on strategies to make the thesis manageable, organizational and writing skills, and discussion of seminar members'  thesis projects and progress. In this seminar, students form a community of scholars to discuss and support each other's work. May be repeated for credit.

name: HDFS4099
prerequisites: HDFS 2004.
description: Students, working with a faculty supervisor, develop plans for an independent research project or review paper, execute the project, and complete a report. May be taken more than one semester.

name: HDFS4181W
catalogName: Early Childhood Development and Education: Supervised Teaching Practicum
description: Supervised teaching experience within the Child Development Labs or approved early education center. Development of advanced written and oral communication skills required for early childhood educators with emphasis on appropriate presentation and writing styles for diverse audiences.

name: HDFS4182
catalogName: Administration and Leadership in Early Childhood Programs: Practicum
prerequisites: HDFS 4181 and a GPA of 2.5 in HDFS courses; open to juniors or higher.
description: Continuation of HDFS 4181. Experience in early childhood program implementation, administration, staff supervising, policy making, and curriculum planning.

name: HDFS4255
catalogName: Living with Chronic or Life-Threatening Illness
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Chronic and/or life-threatening illness from diagnosis through long term management. Psychological, interpersonal, family, and ethical aspects of the chronic illness experience across the life span, in contexts of culture and health policy.

name: HEJS1001
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have had three of more years of Hebrew in high school. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HEJS 1002, 1003, or 1004.
description: Phonetic reading, cursive script, basic conjugations, simple syntax, and vocabulary. Oral and written expression through videos, songs, and exposure to Israeli culture.

name: HEJS1002
prerequisites: HEJS 1001 or equivalent. Not open to students who have had three or more years of Hebrew in high school. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HEJS 1003 or 1004.
description: More complex grammatical structures including the construct state, verb patterns, and more advanced vocabulary. Oral and written expression through study of videos and popular culture. Formerly offered as HEJS 1152.

name: HEJS1003
prerequisites: HEJS 1002 or the equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HEJS 1004. May not be taken for credit after passing HEJS 3251.
description: Building on first-year skills, more advanced grammar, vocabulary, and conversation. Examples from popular media and culture along with short readings continue to enhance students' language acquisition. Formerly offered as HEJS 1153.

name: HEJS1004
prerequisites: HEJS 1003. Not open for credit to students who have passed HEJS 3251.
description: More advanced communicative proficiency using readings and examples from media and popular culture. Focus on grammar, vocabulary, and conversation with more context from the history, culture, and religious traditions of the Jewish people. Formerly offered as HEJS 1154.

name: HEJS1103
catalogName: Who Are the Jews? Jewish Identity through the Ages
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The major concepts, personalities and literary works that inform Jewish identity from the Biblical and Talmudic periods to the present. Taught in English.CA 1. CA 4.

name: HEJS1149
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have had three of more years of Hebrew in high school.
description: An introduction to the biblical language for the student with no previous background. Grammar and drills, using simple texts, prepare the student for independent reading of Hebrew Scripture in the original.

name: HEJS1150
prerequisites: HEJS 1149.  Not open for credit to students who have had three or more years of Hebrew in high school.
description: An introduction to the biblical language for the student with no previous background. Grammar and drills, using simple texts, prepare the student for independent reading of Hebrew Scripture in the original.

name: HEJS1151
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HEJS1152
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HEJS1153
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HEJS1154
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HEJS1193
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program.  May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head required, normally before the student's departure.

name: HEJS2104
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HEJS 1103. Not open for credit for students who have passed HEJS 1104.
description: Nationalism, culture, ethics and philosophy in the writings of the major Jewish thinkers from Spinoza to the present. Emphasis will be placed on the work of Moses Mendelssohn, Hermann Cohen, Franz Rosenzweig, Martin Buber, Mordecai Kaplan, Judith Plaskow, and others. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HEJS2200
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Major themes in Zionist and Israeli history and the development of Israeli art, literature, film, popular music, dance, theater, and popular culture, with a focus on the central questions that have both unified and divided Israeli society and politics. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HEJS2203
catalogName: The Holocaust in Print, Theater, and Film
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Representations of the Holocaust, including first-hand accounts and documentaries; artistic choices in genre, structure, imagery, point of view, and the limits of representation. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HEJS2204
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Representations of the diversity of Jewish culture (historical, religious, secular) in American film. Introduction to film analysis and interpretation. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HEJS2301
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed HEJS 3295 when taught as this topic
description: The history of Jewish humor in modern times with attention given to its various forms, including oral traditions, fiction and humor writing, stand-up comedy, live performance, television, film, and music. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HEJS3201
catalogName: Selected Books of the Hebrew Bible
prerequisites: INTD 3260 or HIST 3301 or HEJS 1103, which may be taken concurrrently, or instructor consent.
description: Literary structure and content of biblical book(s) using modern approaches as well as midrashic and medieval exegesis. Historical and archaeological material. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit  and consent of instructor. A knowledge of Hebrew is not required. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. CA 1.

name: HEJS3202
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Varieties of Jewish expression and belief from Biblical times to the present. Topics include: the Dead Sea Sect, Pharisees, Sadducees, Karaites, Marranos, Hasidism and the Reform, Conservative, Orthodox and Reconstructionist movements of the modern era. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement.

name: HEJS3203
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Origins, development, and legacy of the Holocaust. Topics include the history of modern European anti-Semitism, the creation of the Nazi state, the catalytic role of the Second World War, the actions and attitudes of the perpetrators, victims, and bystanders, and the diverse ways in which scholars and societies have dealt with the legacy of the Holocaust. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement.

name: HEJS3241
catalogName: Jewish Magic: from Late Antiquity through the Early Modern Period
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Jewish magical beliefs and practices from the rabbinic period through the early modern period.  Texts include spells, kabbalistic lore, magical books, incantations, legends, prayers, medical texts, exempla.

name: HEJS3251
prerequisites: HEJS 1004 or instructor consent.
description: Further grammar study. Practice in composition involving the use of everyday vocabulary and idiomatic expressions. Readings and films relevant to Israeli culture and history.   With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HEJS3252
prerequisites: HEJS 3251
description: Further grammar study. Practice in composition involving the use of everyday vocabulary and idiomatic expressions. Readings and films relevant to Israeli culture and history.   With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HEJS3279
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Major themes and literary achievements of modern Israeli writing in translation. Authors range from the pre-Statehood period to the present.

name: HEJS3293
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program.  May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head required, normally granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: HEJS3295
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HEJS3298
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: With a change in topic, may be repeated for credit

name: HEJS3299
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HEJS3301
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of sacred and secular literature in a wide variety of genres produced by Jews in the medieval period from major centers of European settlement. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HEJS3330
catalogName: Palestine Under the Greeks and Romans
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The political, historical and religious currents in Greco-Roman Palestine. Includes the Jewish Revolts, sectarian developments, the rise of Christianity and the Talmudic academies. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. Taught in English. Formerly offered as HEJS 3218.

name: HEJS3330W
catalogName: Palestine Under the Greeks and Romans
description: The political, historical and religious currents in Greco-Roman Palestine. Includes the Jewish Revolts, sectarian developments, the rise of Christianity and the Talmudic academies. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. Formerly offered as HEJS 3218W/CAMS 3256W.

name: HEJS3362
catalogName: The Black Death: Medieval and Modern Responses to Catastrophe
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed HEJS 3295 when offered as The Black Death: Medieval Responses
description: The Black Death (1346-50) from its origins in China through Europe. Institutional, medical, religious, literary, and social responses to the plague; how modern scholars reconstruct medieval experience; and new findings by historians and scientists that shed light on the challenges of past, present and future pandemics. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HEJS3401
description: Interdisciplinary study of literary and artistic productions by and about Jews in the United States. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HEJS3401W
description: Interdisciplinary study of literary and artistic productions by and about Jews in the United States. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HEJS3419
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Interdisciplinary exploration of Jewish responses to the Holocaust. Examines social, religious, theological, political, cultural, psychological, and literary responses both during and after the Second World War. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIND1101
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing HIND 1102, 1103, or 1104.
description: Development of ability to communicate in Hindi, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic communicative needs within a cultural setting.

name: HIND1102
prerequisites: HIND 1101 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HIND 1103 or 1104.
description: Development of ability to communicate in Hindi, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic survival needs within a cultural setting.

name: HIND1103
prerequisites: HIND 1102 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HIND 1104.
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Hindi within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Hindi-speaking world.

name: HIND1104
prerequisites: HIND 1103 or equivalent.
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Hindi within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Hindi-speaking world.

name: HIND3299
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST1100
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Uses historical documents focusing on a single incident in the past to reconstruct what happened and why.  Emphasizes development of historical research skills such as evaluating evidence, explaining cause and effect, and understanding events in their larger social, political, cultural, and economic contexts. CA 1.

name: HIST1100W
description: Uses historical documents focusing on a single incident in the past to reconstruct what happened and why.  Emphasizes development of historical research skills such as evaluating evidence, explaining cause and effect, and understanding events in their larger social, political, cultural, and economic contexts. CA 1.

name: HIST1200
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: A global approach to human history, 1200CE to 1800CE, emphasizing political, intellectual, economic, and social interactions among peoples with diverse cultures, ideas, and values. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST1201
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: A survey of the historical experiences of the world's major civilizations during recent centuries with particular attention to the modernization of the traditional cultures of Asia, Latin America, and Africa. CA 1.

name: HIST1203
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The historical roots of challenges faced by contemporary women as revealed in the Western and/or non-Western experience: the political, economic, legal, religious, intellectual and family life of women. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HIST1206
catalogName: Living Through War in World History Since 1500
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Experiences and perceptions of both military and civilian participants in different kinds of wars around the world over the past 500 years. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST1250
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The sports peoples around the globe have played and watched from ancient Greece to the present and the meanings of athletic performance and spectacle. CA 1.

name: HIST1300
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An analysis of the traditions and changes which have shaped Western political institutions, economic systems, social structures and culture in ancient and medieval times. CA 1.

name: HIST1400
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of political institutions, economic systems, social structures, and cultures in the modern Western world. CA 1.

name: HIST1450
catalogName: Global History of the Second World War
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A study of the origins, development, and legacy of World War II from a global perspective. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST1501
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: Surveys political, economic, social, and cultural developments in American history through the Civil War and Reconstruction. CA 1.

name: HIST1501W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
