description: Surveys political, economic, social, and cultural developments in American history through the Civil War and Reconstruction. CA 1.

name: HIST1502
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: Surveys political, economic, social, and cultural developments in American history from 1877 to the present. CA 1.

name: HIST1502W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: Surveys political, economic, social, and cultural developments in American history from 1877 to the present. CA 1.

name: HIST1503
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: What is an American?  A multi-disciplinary inquiry into the diversity of American societies and cultures. CA 4.

name: HIST1570
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Interdisciplinary honors course on the life and work experiences of contemporary Latin American and Caribbean migrant workers with focus on Connecticut. Integrated service learning component. Field trips required. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HIST1600
catalogName: Introduction to Latin America and the Caribbean
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Multidisciplinary exploration of the historical development of such aspects of Latin America and the Caribbean as colonization and nation formation; geography and the environment; immigration and migration; race, ethnicity, and gender in society, politics, economy, and culture. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST1600W
catalogName: Introduction to Latin America and the Caribbean
description: Multidisciplinary exploration of the historical development of such aspects of Latin America and the Caribbean as colonization and nation formation; geography and the environment; immigration and migration; race, ethnicity, and gender in society, politics, economy, and culture. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST1800
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A survey of the early development and staying power of the traditional cultures from which the major societies of modern Asia have evolved. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST1801
catalogName: History of Asia in the World to 1500
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Development and spread of the Indic and Sinitic civilizations to 1500, with attention to cross-cultural contacts and sources of historical knowledge. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST1805
catalogName: East Asian History Through Hanzi Characters
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: East Asian history taught through analysis of select "hanzi" (Chinese ideographic symbols), focusing on their changing meanings and institutional manifestations in different regions over time. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST1993
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Credits and hours by arrangement. Open only with consent of department head, Normally granted before the student's departure. May be repeated for credit.

name: HIST1995
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Credits, prerequisites and hours as determined by the Senate Curricula and Course Committee.  May be repeated for credit with a change in topic.

name: HIST1998
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A major topic in history through contemporary sources and historical interpretations. With a change in topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: HIST2020
catalogName: Pyramids, Pirates, and the Polis: The Ancient Mediterranean
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Political and intellectual history of the civilizations that emerged around the ancient Mediterranean, including the Near East, Egypt, Greece, and Rome, with emphasis on their interactions and influences. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST2100
prerequisites: Open only to history majors. May not be taken out of sequence after passing passing HIST 4996 or 4997.
description: Learning critical reading, thinking and writing skills by interpreting a variety of primary sources.

name: HIST2101
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 1201 and 2100. Not open for credit to students who have passed AAAS 3998 or HIST 3098 when offered as The Pacific in World History.
description: The Pacific Ocean as a lens for thinking about modern history. Topics include the flow of people, ideas, goods, elements of nature (such as whales and bird guano), and technology among the nations and peoples of the Pacific World; and the impact of colonialism, war, decolonization, and the Cold War on the history of the region and the fortunes of indigenous peoples. Sources include scholarly works, government documents, diaries, and literature. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST2205
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Analysis of the links between personality and power in various countries and across different eras. Formerly offered as HIST 3205. CA 1.

name: HIST2205W
description: Analysis of the links between personality and power in various countries and across different eras. CA 1.

name: HIST2206
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Development of modern science and technology in relation to culture, politics, and social issues.  CA 1.

name: HIST2207
description: How the frontier and overseas ambitions have shaped U.S. institutions and culture. The impact of U.S. expansion on people outside its borders. These topics are explored through literary narratives and historical documents. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HIST2210
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST2210E
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Cultural, environmental, and geopolitical history of the ocean from prehistory to the present. Examines the impact of migration, industrialization, modernization, and globalization on the relationships between people and oceans. CA 1.

name: HIST2222E
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Transformations of the global environment since 1450: the effects of human practices and ideas, especially on energy, landscapes, and commodities. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST2240
catalogName: History of War in the Modern World
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 1400.
description: Selected topics analyzing the interactions of warfare, military theories and practice with social, economic and technological developments since 1815.

name: HIST2350
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A survey of the major developments from the fourth through the fifteenth centuries: religious controversies, the theme system, the Crusades, Byzantine civilization, its law, art, literature, and its impact upon European and Russian civilization. Previously offered as HIST 3350.

name: HIST2401
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 1400.
description: Examines the Restoration, the mid-century revolutions, and the forces of nationalism, liberalism and imperialism. New social and economic movements and currents of thought are described and explored. CA 1.

name: HIST2401W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: HIST 1400.
description: Examines the Restoration, the mid-century revolutions, and the forces of nationalism, liberalism and imperialism. New social and economic movements and currents of thought are described and explored. CA 1.

name: HIST2402
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 1400.
description: Twentieth Century Europe and its world relationships in the era of two world wars, the great depression, and the cold war. CA 1.

name: HIST2402W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: HIST 1400.
description: Twentieth Century Europe and its world relationships in the era of two world wars, the great depression, and the cold war. CA 1.

name: HIST2412
catalogName: From Revolution to Nihilism: Ideas and Ideologies in Nineteenth-Century Europe
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An examination of nineteenth-century European thinkers and their ideas in their social contexts. CA 1.

name: HIST2412W
catalogName: From Revolution to Nihilism: Ideas and Ideologies in Nineteenth-Century Europe
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: An examination of nineteenth-century European thinkers and their ideas in their social contexts. CA 1.

name: HIST2413W
catalogName: From Nietzsche to Neo-liberalism: Ideas and Ideologies in Twentieth-Century Europe
description: An examination of twentieth-century European thinkers and their ideas in their social contexts. CA 1.

name: HIST2421
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Cultural, political, economic, and intellectual development of modern Britain, with special emphasis on changing ideas of national identity. Formerly offered as HIST 3421.

name: HIST2451
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: German political, social, and intellectual history since the Napoleonic Wars. European and world problems as reflected in the emergence of Germany as a pivotal force in international affairs. Formerly offered as HIST 3451.

name: HIST2470
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The development of Russia from the emergence of the Slavs to the reign of Alexander II. Russian political institutions, orthodoxy and cultural traditions, nobility, peasantry, and townsmen. Formerly offered as HIST 3470.

name: HIST2471
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 3470.
description: Continuation of History 3470. Late imperial Russia, the former Soviet Union, and contemporary Russia. Formerly offered as HIST 3471.

name: HIST2530
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of Asian American experiences in the United States since 1850.  Responses by Asian Americans to both opportunities and discrimination.

name: HIST2541
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The development of Urban America with emphasis on social, political, physical, and environmental change in the industrial city. Formerly offered as URBN 3541 and HIST 3541.

name: HIST2541W
description: The development of Urban America with emphasis on social, political, physical, and environmental change in the industrial city. Formerly offered as URBN 3541W and HIST 3541W.

name: HIST2570
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Surveys American Indian History in what is now the United States from precolumbian times up to the present. Cultural diversity among Indian peoples the effects of European contact, tribal sovereignty, and other current issues. Formerly offered as HIST 3570. CA 4.

name: HIST2621
catalogName: Cuba in Local and Global Perspective
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Major themes in Cuban politics and culture. Local and global perspective. Key topics include race, gender, class, cultural movements and practices, slavery, political economy and movements, nationalism. Formerly offered as HIST 3621.

name: HIST2650
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed HIST 3095 when taught as Latin American Urban History.
description: The development of Latin American cities with emphasis on social, political, physical and environmental change, from Spanish conquest to present. Formerly offered as HIST/URBN 3650. CA 1.

name: HIST2810
catalogName: Crime, Policing, and Punishment in the United States
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A survey of political, legal, and cultural development of the American criminal justice system and its social impact from the early republic to the present. CA 1.

name: HIST2832
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Examines the dawn of the modern era to the present day in a place we call Japan. In each of our readings, we will seek to understand what constitutes, as one scholar put it, "history versus the radiant myth of belonging."

name: HIST2841
catalogName: Empire and Nation in Southeast Asia
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Major themes in modern Southeast Asian history from the 17th century to the present: growth of global commerce; western imperialism; nationalism; emergence of independent nation-states; challenges of the post-independence period. Emphasis on the region's largest countries: Burma, Cambodia, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam. Formerly offered as AAAS 3841 and HIST 3841.

name: HIST2993
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Consent of department head required, normally granted before the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of advisor. May be repeated for credit.

name: HIST3095
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HIST3098
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section
description: With a change of topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: HIST3100W
description: What the lives of significant individuals reveal about major historical periods and themes. Variable topics.

name: HIST3101W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: What classic novels and other works of fiction reveal about major historical periods and themes in history. Variable topics. May be offered from an American or European perspective. With a change in topic, this course may be repeated for credit.

name: HIST3102
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Introduction to the field of public history; in-depth study and practice of one selected topic in public history, such as exhibit design, oral history, institutional history, or archive management. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HIST3105
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An exploration of the ways in which film can communicate complex cultural, historical, and political ideas. Topics may include film's ability to translate philosophical and religious ideas, portray accurate or revisionist history, play a role in subverting or critiquing the social and political status quo, and act as a chronicler of change. May be repeated for a maximum of nine credits with a change of topic.

name: HIST3201
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Case studies in the emergence and evolution of human rights as experience and  concept.

name: HIST3202
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Historical and theoretical survey of the evolution of human rights since 1945.

name: HIST3203
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3204W
catalogName: Science and Social Issues in the Modern World
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Social context of science in the United States and Europe since 1850. Genetics and eugenics; ecology and the environment; nuclear issues; gender, race, and science. CA 4.

name: HIST3205
catalogName: Personality and Power in the Twentieth Century
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3206
description: Major themes in recent scholarship of African-descended communities in the Americas and their interconnection beyond geopolitical boundaries; race, gender, sexuality, class, religion, cultural movements and practices, slavery, political economy, political movements, and African consciousness, from historical perspective. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3207
catalogName: Genocide after the Second World War
prerequisites: Rec prep:  HIST 3201
description: Origins of the 1948 Genocide Convention. Several case studies of genocide post WWII: Cambodia, Rwanda, the former Yugoslavia, and Darfur. Causes and underlying dynamics of genocide with an emphasis on the international response. Critical evaluation of military, political, and non-governmental measures to prevent genocidal acts.

name: HIST3208
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: AFRA/HIST/HRTS 3563 or AFRA/HIST 3564 or 3620; or HIST/LLAS 3609.
description: Recent scholarship on the central role played by African-descended communities in shaping the early history of the Americas and their interconnection beyond geopolitical boundaries; race, gender, sexuality, class, religion, cultural movements and practices; slavery, political economy, and political movements.

name: HIST3209
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: ANTH 1500, ANTH 2501, ANTH 2510 or HIST 3544.
description: Archaeological and historical sources to examine the development of seafaring practices, exploration, waterborne trade and economic systems, naval warfare and shipbuilding in the Americas from the fifteenth to the beginning of the twentieth century.

name: HIST3210
catalogName: Archaeology of the Age of Sail
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: ANTH 1500, ANTH 2501, or ANTH 2510.
description: Overview of archaeological and historical sources on the development of seafaring and navigation, exploration, waterborne trade and economic systems, colonialism and empire building, naval warfare and shipbuilding in Europe, Asia and Australia from the fifteenth to the beginning of the twentieth century.

name: HIST3232
catalogName: History of Refugees, Migration, and Statelessness
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Forced and voluntary migration and statelessness in the era of the modern state. Topics include the social and political factors influencing population movement; the experience of migration and statelessness; rights of refugees, migrants, and the stateless; immigration policy; international action; and social and political responses to migration.

name: HIST3300
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: From the earliest hunter-gatherers to the rise of the state: the transition from food-gathering to food-production and the development of complex societies in the Near East.

name: HIST3301
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The history of Near Eastern civilization from the Neolithic period to the Persian Empire. The birth of civilization in Mesopotamia and Egypt. The political, economic, social and cultural achievements of ancient Near Eastern peoples. Taught in English.

name: HIST3320
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The history of Greece from Minoan and Mycenaean times until the Hellenistic Period and Alexander the Great, with special emphasis on the Fifth Century and the "Golden Age" of Athens.

name: HIST3321
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The Eastern Mediterranean (the Greek east) from Alexander to Cleopatra (336-30 BCE), including historical, cultural, social, and religious developments.

name: HIST3325
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: From the beginning of Rome to the growth of the Roman Republic and the onset of Empire. Roman civilization and its influence upon later history.

name: HIST3326
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The Roman Empire, from its beginnings until its transformation (or "fall") under the "barbarian" invasions, and its influence on later history. CA 1.

name: HIST3330
catalogName: Palestine Under the Greeks and Romans
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The political, historical and religious currents in Greco-Roman Palestine. Includes the Jewish Revolts, sectarian developments, the rise of Christianity and the Talmudic academies. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. Taught in English. Formerly offered as HEJS 3218.

name: HIST3330W
catalogName: Palestine Under the Greeks and Romans
description: The political, historical and religious currents in Greco-Roman Palestine. Includes the Jewish Revolts, sectarian developments, the rise of Christianity and the Talmudic academies. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. Formerly offered as HEJS 3218W/CAMS 3256W.

name: HIST3335
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The evolution of Christian institutions, leadership and doctrines in the Roman Empire ca. 50-451 CE. Topics may include gnosticism, prophecy, martyrdom, asceticism, pilgrimage, heresy, orthodoxy. Taught in English.

name: HIST3340
catalogName: World of the Later Roman Empire
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The profound social and cultural changes that redefined the cities, frontiers, and economies of the classical Mediterranean world and led to the Middle Ages. Developments in the eastern and western Mediterranean between the second and seventh centuries.

name: HIST3360
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The history of the medieval West from late antiquity to the eleventh century.

name: HIST3361
catalogName: The High and Later Middle Ages
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The history of the medieval West from the tenth to the fifteenth centuries.

name: HIST3362
catalogName: The Black Death: Medieval and Modern Responses to Catastrophe
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed HEJS 3295 when offered as The Black Death: Medieval Responses
description: The Black Death (1346-50) from its origins in China through Europe. Institutional, medical, religious, literary, and social responses to the plague; how modern scholars reconstruct medieval experience; and new findings by historians and scientists that shed light on the challenges of past, present and future pandemics. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3370
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Europe in the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries.

name: HIST3371
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Europe in the sixteenth century with emphasis on religious developments, rise of the modern state, birth of science, expansion of Europe, and the Commercial Revolution.

name: HIST3400
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Conflict of constitutionalism and absolutism, colonial expansion and rivalry, development of science, and the age of reason, the age of the baroque, the age of Louis XIV.

name: HIST3416
catalogName: Gender and Sexuality in Modern Europe
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The construction of gender difference and ideas about sexuality in western Europe since 1789. Masculinity and femininity; sexuality, identity and the state; European power and personhood in global context.

name: HIST3418
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Origins, development, and legacy of the Holocaust. Topics include the history of modern European anti-Semitism, the creation of the Nazi state, the catalytic role of the Second World War, the actions and attitudes of the perpetrators, victims, and bystanders, and the diverse ways in which scholars and societies have dealt with the legacy of the Holocaust. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement.

name: HIST3419
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Interdisciplinary exploration of Jewish responses to the Holocaust. Examines social, religious, theological, political, cultural, psychological, and literary responses both during and after the Second World War. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3420
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A survey of English history from its origin to the close of the Tudor period. Emphasis is placed on the development of the English nation and the growth of its culture. Recommended to majors in English.

name: HIST3421
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3426
catalogName: Social and Economic History of Modern Britain
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The change from an agrarian to an industrial society.

name: HIST3430
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of Ireland, with emphasis on the modern period. The rise of Irish nationalism, the Irish Literary Revival, and the problems of Northern Ireland.

name: HIST3440
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The disintegration of the monarchical synthesis prior to and during the French Revolution; the attempts to harmonize French society under subsequent regimes.

name: HIST3456
catalogName: The Habsburg Monarchy and Its Peoples, 1740-1918
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 1400.
description: The rise and fall of the multinational, dynastic state of the Habsburgs, with emphasis upon those forces which sustained it through the nineteenth century and those which brought its collapse in 1918.

name: HIST3460
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Italy from the triumph of the city-state and the popolo grosso to the end of the Renaissance. The complex interrelationship between society and culture will be the focus of study.

name: HIST3463
catalogName: The Modernization of Italy from 1815 to Present
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The modernization of Italy's traditional sociopolitical and economic structure; Industrialization, unification, the liberal regime, fascism, and the republic.

name: HIST3502
catalogName: Colonial America: Native Americans, Slaves, and Settlers, 1492-1760
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The legacy of Columbus, creative survival of native Americans in the face of disease and warfare, religious utopianism and the profit motive in colonization.  The growth of a distinctive Anglo-American political culture, gender and family relations, and the entrenchment of a racial caste system.

name: HIST3502W
catalogName: Colonial America: Native Americans, Slaves, and Settlers, 1492-1760
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: The legacy of Columbus, creative survival of native Americans in the face of disease and warfare, religious utopianism and the profit motive in colonization.  The growth of a distinctive Anglo-American political culture, gender and family relations, and the entrenchment of a racial caste system.

name: HIST3504
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Creation of the United States of America from the beginnings of the independence movement through the adoption of the Constitution and Bill of Rights.

name: HIST3510
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The social, economic and cultural forces that shaped the Civil War and its aftermath. Sectional conflict, industrialization, reform and abolitionism, race relations, and class, gender and constitutional issues from the 1830s to the 1880s.

name: HIST3516
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The people and ideas that powered the growth of America's global empire.  Emphasis on the world wars, the Cold War, the Vietnam War, intervention in Latin America, and the global economy.

name: HIST3519
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed HIST 3095 when taught as Contemporary America, 1973-present.
description: American politics, society, and economy from 1973 through the present. Topics include: Conservatism, feminism, gay liberation, the end of the Cold War, Latino immigration, deindustrialization, and the New Economy.

name: HIST3520
catalogName: Social and Cultural History of Connecticut and New England
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Race, class, gender, religion, politics, and economy in New England. Interpretations of the region's culture from the 1600's through the 1800's. Introduces accessible primary sources and interpretive issues at public history sites. Either 3520 or 3522, but not both, may be counted for credit toward the History major.

name: HIST3522
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A survey of Connecticut's history from 1633 to the present from a constitutional and political perspective. Either 3520 or 3522, but not both, may be counted for credit toward the History major.

name: HIST3531
catalogName: Japanese Americans and World War II
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The events leading to martial law and executive order 9066, the wartime experience of Japanese Americans, and national consequences. Formerly offered as AASI 3531. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HIST3540E
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Transformations of one region within the Americas, such as the United States, Caribbean, or South America since 1450: the effects of human practices and policies, varying ideas about nature across cultures and time periods; and the rise of environmental movements. May be repeated for credit once with a change of topic. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HIST3540WE
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Transformations of one region within the Americas, such as the United States, Caribbean, or South America since 1450: the effects of human practices and policies, varying ideas about nature across cultures and time periods; and the rise of environmental movements. May be repeated for credit once with a change of topic. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HIST3541
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3541W
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3542
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3542E
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: ENGL 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800.
description: Interdisciplinary history of New England's terrestrial and marine environmental change.  Links among land, sea, and human natural resource use and management, including precontact patterns, colonial impacts, agricultural decline, industrial pollution, overfishing, re-forestation, and the rise of eco-tourism.

name: HIST3544
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Late medieval and early modern European expansion into the Atlantic and Indian oceans, with particular attention to European, Asian, African, and American contexts within which that expansion took place. Topics include the transatlantic slave trade; technology adoption and adaptation; convergence of trade, racial ideology, imperial expansion, and imperial identity construction; piracy and settlement; historiographical legacies and later imperialism; and decolonization of contemporary understandings.

name: HIST3550
catalogName: Constitutional History of the United States
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The Constitution and the Supreme Court in relation to the political, economic, and intellectual history of the United States.

name: HIST3551
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Introduction to legal culture and appellate case materials from the eighteenth through the twentieth centuries. Topics include: child custody and family law, the courts' role in industrial development, the law of slavery and freedom in the North, and various aspects of civil rights. With change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HIST3551W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Introduction to legal culture and appellate case materials from the eighteenth through the twentieth centuries. Topics include: child custody and family law, the courts' role in industrial development, the law of slavery and freedom in the North, and various aspects of civil rights. With change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HIST3554
catalogName: Immigrants and the Shaping of American History
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: One course in American history.
description: The origins of immigration to the United States and the interaction of immigrants with the social, political, and economic life of the nation after 1789, with emphasis on such topics as nativism, assimilation, and the "ethnic legacy." CA 1. CA 4.

name: HIST3555
catalogName: Work and Workers in American Society
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Changes in work from the 17th through the 20th centuries. Workers' experiences, ideologies, and activities as shaped by gender, race/ethnicity, region, occupation, and industry.

name: HIST3555W
catalogName: Work and Workers in American Society
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Changes in work from the 17th through the 20th centuries. Workers' experiences, ideologies, and activities as shaped by gender, race/ethnicity, region, occupation, and industry.

name: HIST3556W
catalogName: History Workshop: Topics in American Society and Culture
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Techniques of primary historical research based on collaborative research and writing on a topic selected by the instructor. With a change in topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: HIST3559
catalogName: History of Childhood in the United States, 1620-Present
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 1501 or 1502 or 2100.
description: An overview of the history of childhood in America, examining both adults' perception and children's experience. Attention to changes in childhood over time and to the diversity of childhood within each historical moment.

name: HIST3560
catalogName: Constructions of Race, Gender, and Sexuality in U.S. History
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed HIST 3095 when taught as Constructions of Race, Gender, and Sexuality in U.S. History.
description: Examination of historical development, interconnections, and complexities of conceptions of race, gender, and sexuality in U.S. from European conquest to the present.

name: HIST3561
catalogName: History of Women and Gender in the U.S. to 1850
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Gender ideologies of indigenous and settler cultures, changing conditions of women's and men's lives as the U.S. became a nation, while emphasizing intersections with ethnicity, race, class, religion, and region.

name: HIST3562
catalogName: History of Women and Gender in the United States, 1850-Present
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of gender and the lives and cultural representations of women in the U.S., emphasizing intersections with race, sexuality, class, region, and nation.

name: HIST3563
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of African-American people to 1865, from their West African roots, to their presence in colonial America, through enslavement and emancipation. Adaptation and resistance to their conditions in North America. Contributions by black people to the development of the United States.

name: HIST3564
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of African-American people since the Civil war. Contributions by black people to American development. African-American activity in international arenas.

name: HIST3568
catalogName: Hip Hop, Politics and Youth Culture in America
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of hip-hop, its musical antecedents and its role in popular culture. Race, class, and gender are examined as well as hip-hop's role in popular political discourse.

name: HIST3569
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: AFRA/HIST 3206 or 3563 or 3564; or CLCS 1110.
description: Depictions of chattel slavery in cinema and popular media over time. Topics include histories of slavery, race and identity, media studies, and cultural studies.

name: HIST3570
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3575
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Latino/a issues related to human, civil and cultural rights, and gender differences.

name: HIST3607
catalogName: Latin America in the Colonial Period
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Pre-Columbian Civilization in America, the epoch of conquest and settlement, together with a study of the Ibero-Indian cultural synthesis which forms the basis of modern Latin American civilization. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3608W
catalogName: The Hispanic World in the Ages of Reason and Revolution
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: HIST 3607.
description: The transformation of Spanish America from the Bourbons in 1700, through the wars of independence and the struggle to build stable national states in the Nineteenth Century.

name: HIST3609
catalogName: Latin America in the National Period
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Representative countries in North, Central, and South America and the Caribbean together with the historic development of inter-American relations and contemporary Latin American problems. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3618
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The rise and fall of trans-Atlantic slavery. Topics include resistance, migration, antislavery mobilization, abolitionism, empire, revolution, cultural production, political economy, labor, gender, race and identity formation.

name: HIST3619
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Encounter experience; slavery, antislavery mobilization, and abolitionism; colonialism; citizenship and nation building; race and gender; political cultures and movements; migration/immigration; cultural production; and political economy; topics will be examined from a historical perspective. CA 1. CA 4-INT

name: HIST3619W
description: Encounter experience; slavery, antislavery mobilization, and abolitionism; colonialism; citizenship and nation building; race and gender; political cultures and movements; migration/immigration; cultural production; and political economy; topics will be examined from a historical perspective. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3620
catalogName: Cuba, Puerto Rico, and the Spanish Caribbean
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Discovery and settlement, slavery and plantation economy, recent political and economic developments, and United States relations with the Spanish Caribbean.

name: HIST3622
catalogName: History of Gender and Sexuality in Latin America and the Caribbean
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Topics may include: empire and colonialism/anti-colonialism; slavery, science, and the state; cultural practices and institutions; feminisms and masculinities; law and public policies; immigration; forms of labor and political mobilization; sex and reproduction; and human rights from historical perspective.

name: HIST3635
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 3607.
description: The emergence of modern Mexico from independence to the present with emphasis on the Revolution of 1910. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3640
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 3607 or 3609.
description: History of the geographical and social region occupied by the Inca Empire: pre-Columbian cultures, the period of Spanish colonial rule, and the modern Andean republics (primarily Ecuador, Peru, and Bolivia).

name: HIST3643
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 3607 or 3609.
description: Colonial heritage, social and economic transformation of Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay, foreign relations and contemporary turmoil.

name: HIST3650
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3660W
catalogName: History of Migration in Las Americas
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: LLAS 1190, ANTH 3042, HIST 3635, HIST 3609 or HIST 2674/LLAS 3220; LLAS 3210. Spanish useful but not required.
description: Applies broad chronological and spatial analyses of origins of migration in the Americas to the experiences of people of Latin American origin in Connecticut.  Addresses a range of topics from the initial settlement of the Americas to 21st century migrations. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HIST3662
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A consideration of the importance of borderlands in the expansion and consolidation of European empires in the American continent, and later, in the shaping of newly independent republics. Contemporary issues related to Latin American borders, including migration, smuggling, violence, and the role of the state in shaping the borders of national cultures and societies.

name: HIST3674
catalogName: History of Latinos/as in the United States
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Settlement and growth of Hispanic-origin populations in the United States today, from Spanish and Mexican settlement of the western United States to the growth of Latino communities. Student oral history project. CA 1. CA 4.

name: HIST3704
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 1300 or 1400.
description: The social dynamics of faith, culture, and change from the rise of Islam to the Ottoman decline and the Islamic challenge to Greek and Latin Christendom.

name: HIST3705
catalogName: The Modern Middle East from 1700 to the Present
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Tradition, change, modernization and development in the Middle East from the Ottoman decline and rise of successor states to the Arab-Israeli and oil crises. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3710
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.
description: A survey of the arts associated with Islam from the life of Muhammad in the seventh century through the early modern period, with an emphasis upon the Middle East, North Africa, and the Iberian Peninsula. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3710W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: A survey of the arts associated with Islam from the life of Muhammad in the seventh century through the early modern period, with an emphasis upon the Middle East, North Africa, and the Iberian Peninsula. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3712
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Twentieth-century issues in the Middle East heartland with analysis focusing on the Ottoman heritage, nationalism, Arab-Israeli and other conflicts, Islam, oil, water, rapid sociopolitical change, trends in development, super-power rivalries, and the search for identity, independence, and peace with justice.

name: HIST3752
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The history of pre-colonial Africa with particular attention to the rise and fall of African Kingdoms, interaction between different ethnic groups, African trade with other continents, and the impact of foreigners on African societies.

name: HIST3753
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The history of African perceptions of and responses to the abolition of the slave trade, Western imperialism and colonialism, and the development of nationalism and struggle for independence.

name: HIST3760
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Survey of Southern African societies with an emphasis on the socio-economic and political structure of indigenous societies, the imposition of colonial rule, gendered experiences of colonialism, colonial economies, the rise of nationalism and post-independence developments.

name: HIST3770
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.  Recommended preparation: At least one of the following, HIST 3752, 3753, 3563 or 3564.
description: The development of ideas of Pan-Africanism, beginning with the proto-Pan-Africanists in the nineteenth century; examination of the linkages between those ideas in Africa and the evolution of Pan-Africanism as a movement in the African Diaspora.

name: HIST3808
catalogName: East Asia to the Mid-Nineteenth Century
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The major problems and issues of traditional Chinese and Japanese history and historiography. Special emphasis on the "Great Tradition" in ideas of both civilizations.

name: HIST3809
catalogName: East Asia Since the Mid-Nineteenth Century
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The reactions of East Asia to the Western threat, and the rise of Asian nationalism, communism, and fascism. Special attention to the tensions caused by the conflict of ideas.

name: HIST3810
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Not open to students who took HIST 3995 when offered as China and the West.
description: China's political, economic, and cultural encounters with Western Powers from the sixteenth century to 1949.

name: HIST3812
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An introduction to the history of India from the Mughal and European invasions of the 16th Century to the present. India's synthesis of Eastern and Western culture, traditional and new, will be the focus.

name: HIST3820
catalogName: History of Modern Chinese Political Thought
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of Chinese political ideas and ideologies since the nineteenth century, examining the influences of Confucianism and Western conceptions on the revolutionary changes in political thought in China over the last 100 years, including Marxism, liberalism, anarchism, authoritarianism, and democracy. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3822
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of patterns of modern China since 1800. Topics will include reforms and revolutions, industrialization and urbanization, and family and population growth. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HIST3832
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST3842
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Introduction to the history of the Vietnamese from the late Bronze Age to the present: the ancient culture of the Red River delta, the millennium of Chinese rule, the independent kingdom of Dai Viet and its successors, French colonialism, the Vietnam War, and postwar Vietnam.

name: HIST3845
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Origins, evolution, and aftermath of the Vietnamese conflict: the prewar history of colonialism, nationalism, communism, and anticommunism; the formation and development of the three main Vietnamese belligerents; American intervention; culture and politics in wartime Vietnam; escalation and de-escalation of the war; the postwar legacy.

name: HIST3863
catalogName: War and Diplomacy in East Asia
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: European struggle for power in Asia since 1842, in the context of the rise of Japan and the reassertion of Chinese power.

name: HIST3875
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: HIST 3607, 3609, 3610, 3635, 3660W, or 3674.  Not open to students who have passed HIST 3995 Asian Diasporas in the Americas.
description: Transnational history of migration and settlement of Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and South Asian diasporas across South, Central, and North America and the Caribbean, colonial through national period. Emphasis on political economy, racial formations, and constructions of national identity.

name: HIST3890
prerequisites: Instructor consent.
description: Supervised field work within the historical profession such as in archives, historical societies, research libraries and/or museums. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HIST3991
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Internship in applied history. May be repeated for credit up to a maximum of 12 credits. No more than six credits will count toward the department's major or minor requirements.

name: HIST3993
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: May be repeated for credit. Consent of department head required, normally to be granted before the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: HIST4989
prerequisites: Open only to senior history majors.
description: An introduction to research methods and resources in history.

name: HIST4994W
prerequisites: HIST 2100; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to undergraduate history majors in their senior year.
description: These seminars give students the experience of reading critically and in depth in primary and secondary sources, and of developing and defending a position as an historian does.  With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HIST4996
prerequisites: HIST 2100; open only to history majors in the honors program.
description: Preliminary reading in both primary and secondary sources in consultation with a thesis advisor preparatory to writing the thesis in HIST 4997W.

name: HIST4997W
prerequisites: HIST 2100; HIST 4994 or 4999; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to Honors students.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: HIST4999
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HRTS1007
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Exploration of central human rights institutions, selected human rights themes and political controversies, and key political challenges of contemporary human rights advocacy. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: HRTS2100
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the dynamic intersection between human rights and struggles for social change in a variety of contexts. Emphasis on how history, theory, and practice influence the power dynamics that promote or undermine human rights through social change. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: HRTS2100W
description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the dynamic intersection between human rights and struggles for social change in a variety of contexts. Emphasis on how history, theory, and practice influence the power dynamics that promote or undermine human rights through social change. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: HRTS2170W
catalogName: Bioethics and Human Rights in Cross-Cultural Perspective
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to sophomores or higher.
description: Philosophical examination of the ethical and human rights implications of recent advances in the life and biomedical sciences from multiple religious and cultural perspectives. CA 1.

name: HRTS2200
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Interdisciplinary introduction to the study of genocide as an historical, legal, social, political, and conceptual phenomenon, including response, prevention, and commemoration efforts. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: HRTS2203
catalogName: The Holocaust in Print, Theater, and Film
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Representations of the Holocaust, including first-hand accounts and documentaries; artistic choices in genre, structure, imagery, point of view, and the limits of representation. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HRTS2263
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: Any 1000 or 2000 level WGSS course.
description: Discussion of various forms of gendered violence in the United States and in a global context. Physical, sexual, emotional and structural violence; social, political and personal meanings of gendered violence; special emphasis on women.

name: HRTS3028
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: ANTH 2000.
description: An introduction to the study and understanding of Aboriginal ways of life and thought. An exploration of the complexity of contemporary indigenous social orders and land rights issues. CA 4-INT.

name: HRTS3028W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: ANTH 2000.
description: An introduction to the study and understanding of Aboriginal ways of life and thought. An exploration of the complexity of contemporary indigenous social orders and land rights issues. CA 4-INT.

name: HRTS3042
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Various theories of human rights, both historical and contemporary. Conceptual arguments both in favor and critical of the theory and practice of human rights will be considered, with literature taken primarily from philosophy and political theory.

name: HRTS3050
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The study of international and domestic non-governmental organizations in human rights advocacy and campaigns.

name: HRTS3055
catalogName: Theory and Practice of International Criminal Justice
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: International humanitarian and criminal law; genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes and aggression, and theories of individual criminal responsibility.

name: HRTS3139
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Provides a critical study of theatre production as political discourse in global areas of conflict and how that discourse defines, or is defined by, human rights issues.

name: HRTS3149
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Human rights-related issues explored via the cinematic medium. Both the substantive content and the technical aspects of the films will be analyzed through a combination of lecture, viewing, and group discussion.

name: HRTS3149W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Human rights-related issues explored via the cinematic medium. Both the substantive content and the technical aspects of the films will be analyzed through a combination of lecture, viewing, and group discussion.

name: HRTS3153W
description: Human rights, political violence, political and legal anthropology, prosecutions of human rights offenders, truth and memory, reconciliation, international justice. CA 4-INT.

name: HRTS3200
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: HRTS 1007.
description: International and regional human rights law, institutions, and regimes; specialized topics include corporate social responsibility, women's human rights, truth commissions, humanitarian intervention, international criminal law, monitoring, and compliance. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HRTS3200W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: HRTS 1007.
description: International and regional human rights law, institutions, and regimes; specialized topics include corporate social responsibility, women's human rights, truth commissions, humanitarian intervention, international criminal law, monitoring, and compliance. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: HRTS3201
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Case studies in the emergence and evolution of human rights as experience and  concept.

name: HRTS3202
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Historical and theoretical survey of the evolution of human rights since 1945.

name: HRTS3207
catalogName: Genocide after the Second World War
prerequisites: Rec prep:  HIST 3201
description: Origins of the 1948 Genocide Convention. Several case studies of genocide post WWII: Cambodia, Rwanda, the former Yugoslavia, and Darfur. Causes and underlying dynamics of genocide with an emphasis on the international response. Critical evaluation of military, political, and non-governmental measures to prevent genocidal acts.

name: HRTS3209
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Political, socioeconomic, environmental, science and engineering challenges of energy sources; comparison of feasibility and sustainability of energy policies around the world.

name: HRTS3212
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Cultural difference and human rights in areas of legal equality, women's rights, political violence, criminal justice, religious pluralism, global security, and race relations.

name: HRTS3219
catalogName: Topics in Philosophy and Human Rights
prerequisites: One three credit course in Philosophy or instructor consent; open to juniors or higher.
description: What are human rights? Why are they important? Topics may include the philosophical precursors of human rights, the nature and justification of human rights, or contemporary issues bearing on human rights. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HRTS3219W
catalogName: Topics in Philosophy and Human Rights
prerequisites: One three-credit course in Philosophy or instructor consent; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: What are human rights? Why are they important? Topics may include the philosophical precursors of human rights, the nature and justification of human rights, or contemporary issues bearing on human rights. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HRTS3220
description: Ontology and epistemology of human rights investigated through contemporary and/or historical texts. CA 1.

name: HRTS3220W
description: Ontology and epistemology of human rights investigated through contemporary and/or historical texts. CA 1.

name: HRTS3221
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Latino/a issues related to human, civil and cultural rights, and gender differences.

name: HRTS3230
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed ANTH 3098 when offered as Propaganda, Fake News and Hate Speech
description: Draws on current social science research to understand the effects of false information and hate speech on our politics and culture and to evaluate various private and public initiatives to regulate speech. CA 2.

name: HRTS3230W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Not open for credit to students who have passed ANTH 3098 when offered as “Propaganda, Fake News and Hate Speech.”
description: Drawing on recent social science research, this course will seek to understand the effects of false information and hate speech on our politics and culture, and evaluate various private and public initiatives to regulate speech. CA 2.

name: HRTS3232
catalogName: History of Refugees, Migration, and Statelessness
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Forced and voluntary migration and statelessness in the era of the modern state. Topics include the social and political factors influencing population movement; the experience of migration and statelessness; rights of refugees, migrants, and the stateless; immigration policy; international action; and social and political responses to migration.

name: HRTS3250
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: HRTS 1007.
description: The role of new technologies in the fulfillment, protection and enforcement of human rights; technology-related human rights benefits and risks, including privacy, security, and equality; technical and legal innovations for balancing benefits and risks. CA 1.

name: HRTS3250W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: HRTS 1007.
description: The role of new technologies in the fulfillment, protection and enforcement of human rights; technology-related human rights benefits and risks, including privacy, security, and equality; technical and legal innovations for balancing benefits and risks. CA 1.

name: HRTS3252
prerequisites: Open only to non-business students of junior or higher status. Not open to students who have passed or are taking BADM 3252 or BLAW 3252.
description: Social impact and human rights implications related to global operations of multinational corporations; regulatory environment and competitive contexts that govern responsible business conduct on a global scale, how to navigate regulatory mandates and design social responsibility strategies to increase a firm's reputation, reduce costs, and improve its competitive positioning while respecting human rights principles.

name: HRTS3254
prerequisites: Open only to non-business students of junior or higher status. Not open to students who have passed or are taking BLAW/BADM 3254.
description: Market-based solutions to social and human rights challenges; how companies create value both for society and business, including role of for-profit businesses as agents for positive social impact in changing legal, regulatory, policy, and market environments. Regulatory and business strategies for long-term economic viability, sustainability, and human rights. Social innovation, statutory benefit corporations, corporate social certifications, social investment, shared value, strategic philanthropy, and business opportunities serving emerging markets.

name: HRTS3256
catalogName: Politics and Human Rights in Global Supply Chains
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1202 and 1402 and POLS/HRTS 3212.
description: Political and human rights implications of regulating contemporary global supply chains: official regulatory frameworks; non-regulatory approaches to rule-making (such as voluntary corporate codes of conduct and industry standards); social responses to the dilemmas of "ethical" sourcing of goods and services.

name: HRTS3256W
catalogName: Politics and Human Rights in Global Supply Chains
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800, open to Political Science and Human Rights majors and minors; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1202, POLS 1402 and POLS/HRTS 3212.
description: Political and human rights implications of regulating contemporary global supply chains: official regulatory frameworks; non-regulatory approaches to rule-making (such as voluntary corporate codes of conduct and industry standards); social responses to the dilemmas of "ethical" sourcing of goods and services.

name: HRTS3257
catalogName: Assessment for Human Rights and Sustainability
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed ENGR 3257
description: Foundational concepts of human rights and environmental impacts pertaining to global supply chains. Regulations and voluntary standards in engineering-intensive sectors, including infrastructure, biofuels, electronics. Case study analysis of corporate assessment practices for labor rights protection and environmental impacts.

name: HRTS3293
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit. May be taken for a maximum of 15 credits. Consent of the Minor Director required prior to departure.

name: HRTS3295
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HRTS3298
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Issues in human rights, history, law and policy, or practices. Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HRTS3299
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Supervised reading and writing on a subject of special interest to the student. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: HRTS3326
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Theories, methods and controversies in the interconnected fields of global health and human rights.

name: HRTS3327
catalogName: Power and Health in Latin America and the Caribbean
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: History, theories, and concepts about the human right to health and structural inequalities in the region.

name: HRTS3418
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The role of intergovernmental and nongovernmental organizations and international law in world affairs with special attention to contemporary issues.

name: HRTS3420
catalogName: Being International: Geopolitics and Human Rights
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Human rights theories and debates and their historical, institutional and geopolitical contexts.

name: HRTS3421
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Inequality and its consequences in contemporary societies.

name: HRTS3428
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Examination of the usage of torture by state and non-state actors. Questions include, "Why is torture perpetrated?" "What domestic and international legal frameworks and issues related to the use of torture?" "How effective are existing legal prohibitions and remedies?" "Who tortures?" and "How does torture affect transitional justice?"

name: HRTS3430
catalogName: Evaluating Human Rights Practices of Countries
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Examination of the ways in which governments, businesses, NGOs, IGOs, and scholars assess which human rights are being respected by governments of the world. Hands-on experience in rating the level of government respect for human rights in countries around the world.

name: HRTS3445
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed or are taking ECON 2445
description: Economic approaches to gender inequality in political representation, economic opportunities, access to education, and health.

name: HRTS3460
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.
description: Examines the relationship between human rights and armed conflict from a social science perspective. Explores human rights abuses as cause and consequence of armed conflict. Evaluates the effectiveness of the human rights and humanitarian approaches to conflict management

name: HRTS3475
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Microeconomics of economic development and human rights. Impacts of human capital, health, education, on well-being and poverty.

name: HRTS3505
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The origin, nature, and consequences of white racism as a central and enduring social principle around which the United States and other modern societies are structured and evolve. CA 4.

name: HRTS3540
prerequisites: Instructor consent. May be repeated with a change of topic to a maximum of nine credits.
description: Seminar on topics in theoretical and practice-based knowledge and skills related to human rights. Topics vary by semester.

name: HRTS3563
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: History of African-American people to 1865, from their West African roots, to their presence in colonial America, through enslavement and emancipation. Adaptation and resistance to their conditions in North America. Contributions by black people to the development of the United States.

name: HRTS3573
catalogName: Asian Indian Women: Activism and Social Change in India and the United States
prerequisites: SOCI 1001, 1251 or 1501; open to juniors or higher.
description: How gender, class, and ethnicity/race structure everyday lives of Asian Indian women in both India and the United States.

name: HRTS3575
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The problematics of digital media and visual representation in conceptualizing, documenting, and visualizing human rights and humanitarian issues. CA 1.

name: HRTS3619
catalogName: Topics in Literature and Human Rights
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Study of literature from various historical periods and nationalities concerned with defining, exploring, and critiquing the idea of universal human rights. May be repeated for credit with a change of topic.

name: HRTS3631
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to sophomores or higher.
description: Relationships between literature and culture and humanitarian movements, from the eighteenth century to the present.

name: HRTS3710
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Introduction to Islamic law, international human rights, and questions of universalism and relativism, collectivism and individualism.

name: HRTS3807
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The role of the Supreme Court in interpreting the Bill of Rights. Topics include freedoms of speech and religion, criminal due process, and equal protection.

name: HRTS3825
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Social and economic-justice movements, from the beginning of the Civil Rights movement to the present.

name: HRTS3831
catalogName: Human Rights in the United States
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Sociological analyses of human rights issues in the United States, including economic, racial, and gender justice; prisoners' rights and capital punishment; the role of the United States in international human rights agreements and treaties; and struggles on behalf of human rights

name: HRTS3833
catalogName: Topics in Sociology and Human Rights
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit. Variable topics covering theoretical and empirical examination of social, political, economic, legal, and/or cultural issues of human rights from a sociological perspective.

name: HRTS3835
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Social and political challenges of living as a refugee and working in humanitarian settings with a focus on refugee camps, institutional development of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, and alternative approaches to refuge.

name: HRTS3835W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: POLS 1007/HRTS 1007
description: Social and political challenges of living as a refugee and working in humanitarian settings. Refugee camps, the institutional development of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, and alternative approaches to sanctuary.

name: HRTS3837
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Comparative approach to the study of human rights in the United States and elsewhere around the world from a sociological perspective.

name: HRTS3837W
description: Comparative approach to the study of human rights in the United States and around the world from a sociological perspective.

name: HRTS4291
prerequisites: Instructor consent; nine credits of 2000-level or above HRTS courses (six of which may be taken concurrently).
description: Combination of supervised fieldwork within the larger human rights community with regular classroom meetings for reflection/analysis on the application of human rights concepts and practices. Students must secure a satisfactory intern position before the end of the second week of the semester of enrollment in this course; students should be in consultation with the instructor several months in advance.

name: HRTS4996W
description: Research and writing of major project exploring a topic with human rights, with close supervision and production of multiple written drafts.

name: ILCS1001
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students with three or more years of h.s. Italian. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ILCS 1002, 1003, or 1004 or after passing any 2000-level or above course taught in Italian.
description: Elementary Italian grammar. Practice of oral skills through pronunciation and easy conversation. Reading of simple texts and exposure to Italian media and culture. Formerly offered as ILCS 1145.

name: ILCS1002
prerequisites: ILCS 1001 or equivalent. Not open for credit to students with three or more years of high school Italian. Students with questions about placement should contact the head of the Department of Literatures, Cultures and Languages.
description: More elements of grammar and culture with integrated readings. Further practice in conversation and exposure to culture though simple examples from media, politics, and art. Formerly offered as ILCS 1146.

name: ILCS1003
prerequisites: ILCS 1002 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ILCS 1004. May not be taken for credit after passing any 2000-level or above course taught in Italian, or three or more years of high school Italian. Students with questions about placement should contact the head of the Department of Literatures, Cultures and Languages.
description: Intensive oral-aural practice based on selected readings and exposure to a wide range of contemporary cultural themes through materials such as newspaper articles, advertising material, and videos. Emphasis on more complex grammatical structures and vocabulary. Formerly offered as ILCS 1147.

name: ILCS1004
prerequisites: ILCS 1003 or equivalent. May not be taken for credit after passing any 2000-level or above course taught in Italian. Students with questions about placement should contact the head of the Department of Literatures, Cultures and Languages.
description: Intensive oral-aural practice. Practice in speaking through a combination of group-based and individual activities, focusing on grammatical structures, language functions, and vocabulary. Further exposure to a wide range of contemporary cultural themes through materials such as newspaper articles, advertising material, and videos. Formerly offered as ILCS 1148.

name: ILCS1101
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A survey of Italian Renaissance civilization, with emphasis on literature and intellectual life. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. A knowledge of Italian in not required. CA 1.

name: ILCS1145
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ILCS1146
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ILCS1147
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ILCS1148
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: ILCS1149
catalogName: Cinema and Society in Contemporary Italy
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A critical analysis of contemporary Italian society seen through the media of film and literature.  Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. Films in Italian with English subtitles. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ILCS1158
catalogName: Italian American Experience in Literature and Film
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: Focuses on the Italian American experience as represented in a variety of fields, including literature and cinema. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4.

name: ILCS1160
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The way Italian literary and cinematic culture justified, survived, and fought the terrors of the Fascist totalitarian regime.  Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ILCS1168
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of literary genres adapted into film in Italian context. Literary and visual styles, visual literacy, and film criticism. Literary texts cover a range of time periods and cultural considerations. Films represent a variety of cinematic techniques and the new audiences and artistic goals targeted by film adaptations. General film theory and theories of adaptation. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ILCS1170
prerequisites: May be repeated for credit with a change of subject matter for a maximum of nine credits.
description: The diverse culture of Italy, studied through analysis of sociological,  literary, artistic, and cinematic works from and about a single one of the different Italian regions and that region's cultural centers, such as Rome, Naples, Florence, Palermo, or Venice. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. CA 1.

name: ILCS1193
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head required, normally before the student's departure.

name: ILCS3237
prerequisites: ILCS 1004
description: A survey of contemporary Italian political, social, economic and cultural life.

name: ILCS3239
prerequisites: ILCS 1004
description: Practice in written and oral composition. Syntax study.

name: ILCS3240
prerequisites: ILCS 3239 or equivalent
description: Further practice in written and oral composition. Treatment of the finer points in syntax.

name: ILCS3245
prerequisites: ILCS 1004
description: Survey of Italian Literature through the changing images of Italian cities.

name: ILCS3246
prerequisites: ILCS 1004
description: Survey of Italy's women writers from the early modern period to the present. Developments of Italian feminism and gender issues.

name: ILCS3247
catalogName: Jewish Literature and Film in 20th Century Italy
prerequisites: ILCS 1004
description: Italy's literary and cinematic representations of Jews in the 20th Century. Jewish identity under Fascism, during World War II, and beyond. Taught in Italian.

name: ILCS3248
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of the novella from the Middle Ages to the 20th century. The course explores the cross-cultural origins of the genre and the influence of the Italian novella on other European literary traditions. Taught in English (Italian readings optional). CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ILCS3248W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Taught in English (Italian readings optional).
