description: Survey of the novella from the Middle Ages to the 20th century. The course explores the cross-cultural origins of the genre and the influence of the Italian novella on other European literary traditions. Taught in English (Italian readings optional). CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ILCS3250
catalogName: Italian Theatre of the Eighteenth Century
prerequisites: ILCS 3237 or 3239 or 3243 or equivalent
description: Readings from Metastasio, Goldoni, and Alfieri.

name: ILCS3251
prerequisites: ILCS 3237 or 3239 or 3243 or equivalent.
description: Selected readings from the works of Poliziano, Leonardo da Vinci, Lorenzo de'Medici, Michelangelo, Ariosto, Machiavelli, Castiglione, Tasso, and others.

name: ILCS3253
prerequisites: ILCS 3237 or 3239 or 3243 or equivalent.
description: Selected readings from Dante, Petrarch, Compagni, Villani.

name: ILCS3254
prerequisites: ILCS 3237 or 3239 or 3243 or equivalent.
description: Readings from Boccaccio and others with special attention to the problems of social and sexual ethics.

name: ILCS3255W
catalogName: Dante's Divine Comedy in English Translation
description: Dante's poem as a unique synthesis of Medieval culture. Emphasizes its integration of ethics, political thought, and theology with poetic imagination. Taught in English. CA 1.

name: ILCS3256
catalogName: The Literature of the Italian Renaissance
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed ILCS 3251 or 3252
description: A survey, in English, of the major literary and philosophical currents of the Italian Renaissance. Selections from Boccaccio, Petrarch, Pico della Mirandola, Machiavelli, Castiglione, and others. Taught in English.

name: ILCS3258W
description: Cinematic representations of Italian Americans in the works of major directors from the silent era to the present.  Construction of and attempts to dislodge negative stereotypes of Italian American male and female immigrants. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4.

name: ILCS3259
prerequisites: ILCS 1004
description: Major topics in modern and contemporary Italian cinema. Taught in Italian.

name: ILCS3260W
description: Italian cinema from the silent era to the present. Its genres, such as epic film, melodrama, comedy "Italian-style," "Spaghetti-Westerns," and political cinema. Cinema as a reflection on and comment upon the social and political contexts of Italian history from pre-fascist Italy to modernization and beyond. Taught in English. Films in Italian with English subtitles. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: ILCS3261
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: ILCS 3237 or 3239 or 3240.
description: Major trends in twentieth-century Italian Literature from the early modern period to contemporary times.

name: ILCS3262
description: Nineteenth-century Italian drama, poetry, and narrative from the Napoleonic period to the years immediately following the conquest of Rome in 1870.

name: ILCS3270
prerequisites: ILCS 1004
description: Introduction to Italian business culture. Written and oral practice in the language of business Italian.

name: ILCS3291
prerequisites: ILCS 1147 or approval from instructor of record; instructor consent required
description: Supervised experience in a work setting using Italian linguistic skills and cultural competencies. Context may include a specific trade or industry, business, medical or clinical setting, public agency, community-based organization, or research collaboration. May be taken in the context of a study abroad program.

name: ILCS3293
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign language program. May be repeated for credit.  Consent of Department Head required, normally granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: ILCS3295
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. With a change in topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: ILCS3298
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary. With a change in topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: ILCS3299
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: ILCS4279
prerequisites: ILCS 1004
description: Advanced language practicum and integration of studies in Italian Literature and Culture.

name: INDS3210
catalogName: Ancient and Classical Indian Literature in Translation
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Literary achievements of Indian civilization from the ancient and classical periods. Attention given to major genres and their development in both secular and religious texts.

name: INDS3293
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be taken for a maximum of 15 credits. Consent of Coordinator of India Studies required prior to departure.

name: INDS3295
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: INDS3298
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: INDS3299
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Supervised reading and writing on a subject of special interest to the student. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: INDS3375
catalogName: Indian Art and Popular Culture: Independence to the Present
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: An interdisciplinary lecture/studio art course introducing diverse forms of Indian Art from the traditional through the contemporary. Students complete either research or studio art assignments responding to the course content. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: INDS4296W
description: Research and writing of a thesis.

name: INTD1985
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated with a change in topic. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: INTD1993
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Course work undertaken within approved Study Abroad programs.  May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 17 credits.

name: INTD1995
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated with a change in topic.

name: INTD1999
prerequisites: Open to Freshman or Sophomore students only.
description: May be repeated with a change in topic.

name: INTD2245
catalogName: Introduction to Diversity Studies in American Culture
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: An interdisciplinary introduction to comparative multicultural studies in the United States. Topics may include: African American, Asian American, Latino/a, and Native American cultures; gender, feminism, religious and sexual identities; and disability studies. CA 4.

name: INTD3200
prerequisites: Open to Honors students.
description: Major concepts and topics in correctional health.

name: INTD3222
prerequisites: Language skills equivalent to two to four semesters of college course work in a single foreign language (may be completed concurrently).
description: Supplements a three-credit course in a particular discipline by studying selected foreign language texts related to the topic of its companion course. Practice in oral and written expression.   With a change in content this course may be repeated for credit.

name: INTD3260
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The literary, historical, and philosophical content, circumstances and problems of the Old and New Testaments. May be counted toward the related field requirement in History, Philosophy, or English. CA 1.

name: INTD3584
prerequisites: Must be taken concurrently with INTD 3590 and 3594; open to juniors or higher.
description: Discussions based upon assigned readings and led by faculty and invited speakers from outside and within the University. CA 4.

name: INTD3590
prerequisites: Must be taken concurrently with INTD 3584 and 3594; open to juniors or higher.
description: Field experience supervised by the director and an examining committee consisting of the director and two or more faculty members from two departments in the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences.

name: INTD3594
prerequisites: Must be taken concurrently with INTD 3590 and 3584; open to juniors or higher.
description: Students make analytic presentations of their field experiences, relating these to the pertinent available literature. Particular issues are discussed with experts invited from inside and outside the University.

name: INTD3594W
prerequisites: INTD 3590 and 3584, which must be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Students make analytic presentations of their field experiences, relating these to the pertinent available literature. Particular urban problems are discussed with invited experts from outside the University.

name: INTD3985
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.  Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: INTD3993
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Course work undertaken within approved Study Abroad programs. May be repeated for credit (to a maximum of 17).

name: INTD3995
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change in topic; may be repeated for credit.

name: INTD3999
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated for credit.

name: INTD4200
prerequisites: Open to Honors students.
description: Systematic review as a research methodology for translation of clinical evidence into a clinical environment.  Production of a poster for presentation. Two-semester projects are possible for students interested in oral presentation of findings, or co-authored publication.

name: IRIS1001
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing IRIS 1002, 1003, or 1004
description: Development of ability to communicate in Irish, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic communicative needs within a cultural setting.

name: IRIS1002
prerequisites: IRIS 1001 or one year of Irish in high school. May not be taken out of sequence after passing IRIS 1003 or 1004.
description: Development of ability to communicate in Irish, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic communicative needs within a cultural setting.

name: IRIS1003
prerequisites:
IRIS 1002 or two years of Irish in high school. May not be taken out of sequence after passing IRIS 1004.


Not open for credit to students who have passed IRIS 1004.
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Irish-speaking world.

name: IRIS1004
prerequisites: IRIS 1003 or three years of Irish in high school
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Irish-speaking world.

name: JAPN1101
prerequisites: Open only to students with no prior contact with the language. May not be taken out of sequence after passing JAPN 1102, 1103, or 1104.
description: Introduction to elementary Japanese emphasizing speaking, understanding, reading and writing through a communicative approach.

name: JAPN1102
prerequisites: JAPN 1101 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing JAPN 1103 or 1104.
description: Further instruction in elementary Japanese emphasizing speaking, understanding, reading and writing skills using a communicative approach involving simple examples from contemporary media and culture.

name: JAPN1103
prerequisites: JAPN 1102 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing JAPN 1104.
description: Increasing communicative abilities in Japanese using more examples from contemporary Japanese media and culture.

name: JAPN1104
prerequisites: JAPN 1103 or equivalent
description: Increasing communicative abilities in Japanese with stronger emphasis on vocabulary and grammar using examples from contemporary Japanese media, politics, and culture.

name: JAPN1193
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Credits and hours by arrangement. Prerequisite: Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure.

name: JAPN2305
description: Japanese literature across genres from 1868 to the present, studied in English translation. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: JAPN3293
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program

name: JAPN3295
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Prerequisites, required preparation, recommended preparation vary.

name: JAPN3298
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change in topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: JAPN3299
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Credits and hours by arrangement. Open only with consent of Director. With a change in content, may be  repeated for credit.

name: JOUR1002
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing JOUR 3002.
description: The development of American print journalism from 18th century print shops to 21st century corporations; how journalists and their work have evolved and influenced American life. CA 1.

name: JOUR2000W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Cannot be taken out of sequence after passing JOUR 2001, 3005, 3030, 3040, 3045 or 4091.
description: Defining news; exercising news judgment in a diverse society; employing principles of Associated Press style; writing basic news stories. Laboratory offers intensive newswriting exercises.

name: JOUR2001W
prerequisites: JOUR 2000; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Cannot be taken out of sequence after passing JOUR 3000,3012, 3013, 3033, 4091.
description: Live reporting using the university and the surrounding community as a laboratory. Emphasis on fact gathering, interviewing, diversity of sources, news judgment and deadline writing.

name: JOUR2010
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Viewing and analysis of motion pictures featuring journalistic themes; journalistic history, ethics, legal issues, contrasting forms of media, and other issues. CA 1.

name: JOUR2065
prerequisites: JOUR 1002, which may be taken concurrently; open to sophomores or higher.JOUR 1002; open to sophomores or higher.
description: Entry-level photojournalism course that develops aesthetic and technical skills for storytelling using mobile equipment such as smartphones.

name: JOUR2095
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary. With a change in content may be repeated for up to four credits.

name: JOUR2111
prerequisites: JOUR 2000W. Open to Journalism majors, others with permission.
description: Introduction to online and multimedia skills used by journalists; emphasis on ethical practices. Students provided portfolio space on a department-maintained site.

name: JOUR3000W
prerequisites: JOUR 2001W; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: In-depth reporting on state and local government-municipal agencies, boards, commissions, courts, public safety, schools.  Field Trips required.

name: JOUR3002
prerequisites: JOUR 1002. May not be taken out of sequence after passing JOUR 4091.
description: Discussion of such contemporary problems as privacy, good taste, community standards, effectiveness of the press and responsibility of the press.

name: JOUR3005
prerequisites: JOUR 2000.
description: Application of newswriting techniques to online journalism including assembling and producing interactive news stories.

name: JOUR3012W
prerequisites: JOUR 2001W; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011.
description: Emphasis on finding, developing and writing feature stories. Outside stories will be assigned weekly.

name: JOUR3013W
prerequisites: JOUR 2001W; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011.
description: Survey of magazine journalism examining different forms of periodicals and their operation, from mission to final product. Students research, report and write for various publications.

name: JOUR3020
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.
description: Typical subjects: libel, slander, invasion of privacy, obscenity, legal problems of newsgathering, protecting the political process, protecting state secrets, protecting the public welfare.

name: JOUR3030
prerequisites: JOUR 2000W. Recommended preparation: JOUR 2001W.
description: News value; information verification; editing for grammar, spelling, punctuation, and style; content editing; headline writing; search engine optimization; handling visuals; building data visualizations; basic layout and design for print and digital platforms.

name: JOUR3030
prerequisites: JOUR 2000W. Recommended preparation: JOUR 2001W.
description: News value; information verification; editing for grammar, spelling, punctuation, and style; content editing; headline writing; search engine optimization; handling visuals; building data visualizations; basic layout and design for print and digital platforms.

name: JOUR3031
prerequisites: JOUR 3030.
description: Copy and photo selection, copy fitting, photo editing, layout and production for digital and print publications.

name: JOUR3035
prerequisites: JOUR 2000W. Not open for credit to students who have passed JOUR 3095 when offered as Introduction to Podcasting.
description: Researching, recording, writing and producing news podcasts and associated web and social media posts. Ethical considerations.

name: JOUR3040
catalogName: Audio and Video Reporting and Writing
prerequisites: JOUR 2000.
description: Application of newswriting techniques to the broadcast and other media.

name: JOUR3041
prerequisites: JOUR 3040.
description: This is an advanced broadcast journalism class that teaches students how to gather, edit and deliver accurate, newsworthy information for television newscasts. Students develop the skills needed to report  news and organize newscasts through actual experience in and out of class.

name: JOUR3045
prerequisites: JOUR 2000.
description: An introduction to specialized fields such as business, science, education, arts, sports, and entertainment reporting. Students will examine some of the best work in the fields and will consider ethical issues and other problems.

name: JOUR3045W
prerequisites: JOUR 2000W; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011.
description: An introduction to specialized fields such as business, science, education, arts, sports, and entertainment reporting. Students will examine some of the best work in the fields and will consider ethical issues and other problems.

name: JOUR3046E
prerequisites: JOUR 2000W or consent of the instructor. Open to Juniors or higher.
description: Explores specialized coverage of environmental issues by journalists, emphasizing news reporting with the opportunity to produce print, visual and multimedia news reports.

name: JOUR3050
prerequisites: JOUR 2000W, which may be taken concurrently.
description: Journalists discuss the economic, technological, sociological and ethical issues that challenge their profession.

name: JOUR3065
prerequisites:
JOUR 2000W; open to juniors or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing JOUR 4065.JOUR 2000W; open to juniors or higher.

Not open to students who have passed JOUR 4065.
description: Examines current trends in visual digital journalism; develops skills in photojournalism, multimedia and video storytelling. Instructor approved digital camera required.

name: JOUR3087
prerequisites: JOUR 2000, JOUR 2001 and at least three other journalism credits at the 2000-level or above.
description: Honors students choose topics for their theses or projects, develop research proposals and apply for funding if needed. Students work as a community of scholars to discuss and support each other's work. Usually taken the semester before JOUR 3097, Honors Thesis.

name: JOUR3093
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated for credit with permission of Department Head. Consent of Department Head required before the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: JOUR3095
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.
description: With a change in content may be repeated for credit.

name: JOUR3097
prerequisites: JOUR 2000 and 2001; six additional 2000 level or above credits of JOUR.
description: Students in the Honors Program undertake in-depth research and writing under the guidance of a faculty member. Majors must consult with the departmental Honors Advisor and develop a research proposal in the semester before taking the course.

name: JOUR3098
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.
description: With a change in topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: JOUR3111
prerequisites: JOUR 2111
description: Development of online and multimedia skills used by journalists; emphasis on ethical practices. Students will contribute journalism content completed in other courses and develop new content to build a professional portfolio provided on a department-maintained site.

name: JOUR4016
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Students and faculty work together to research, write, edit and produce a publication. May be repeated for credit.

name: JOUR4035
prerequisites: JOUR 2001.
description: Using the Internet, databases, and other computer resources to research and report on the actions of courts, businesses, public agencies, and governments. Consideration of ethical questions.

name: JOUR4065
prerequisites: JOUR 3065; open to juniors or higher.
description: Explores multimedia storytelling through time-based media from a journalistic perspective. Students will develop multimedia narrative skills using photography, videography, and audio to create new media content.

name: JOUR4091
description: Students research, report and write for newspapers, news departments of radio and television stations, and online publications under supervision of professionals.

name: JOUR4099
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Open to qualified students who present suitable projects for independent work in journalism. May be repeated for credit.

name: JOUR4111
prerequisites: JOUR 3111
description: Completion of student journalism portfolios that include examples of journalistic endeavors in print, still and video photography, audio and multimedia packages.

name: KINS1100
prerequisites: Open only to students in Kinesiology programs.
description: Overview of the five pillars of health (exercise, nutrition, sleep, stress and relationships); role of exercise in health promotion and disease prevention across the lifespan; impacts of exercise in leisure time, culture, community, careers and the workplace.

name: KINS1160
prerequisites: This course may be repeated with change of activity and/or skill level,  not  to exceed 3 credits toward graduation of combined AH 1200 and KINS 1160 credits.  Students in the Dept. of Kinesiology may count up to 6 different activities for 6 credits.
description: A variety of lifetime sports and skills are offered. The teaching of each activity will be geared to individual, dual, and team activities. Students who have physical disabilities in the least restrictive environment possible. Participants requiring accommodations should contact the Program Coordinator.

name: KINS2100
prerequisites: Open only to Pre-Athletic Training students who are sophomores or higher
description: A survey class to explore general considerations of recognizing and treating athletic injuries. Covers training and conditioning, nutrition, environment, and legal issues.

name: KINS2110
prerequisites: Open only to Pre-Athletic Training students who are sophomores or higher
description: A survey class to explore general considerations of recognizing and treating athletic injuries. This section covers tissue healing, rehabilitation, modalities, taping, and bandaging.

name: KINS2200
prerequisites: Open only to Exercise Science majors with consent of instructor. May not be taken out of sequence after passing KINS 3212.
description: Basic and essential elements of athletic training. Includes discussion of the sports medicine team, legal and research aspects of athletic training, organizational policies, administrative responsibilities, and policies and procedures.

name: KINS2227
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: KINS 1100.
description: Frequency, Intensity, Time, and Type or FITT principle of exercise prescription for apparently healthy adults; healthy populations with special considerations such as children, older adults, and women who are pregnant; and special populations with chronic disease and health conditions such as overweight and obesity, and cardiovascular, pulmonary, metabolic, and musculoskeletal disease.

name: KINS3091
prerequisites: Students must complete all concentration requirements excluding Athletic Training prior to taking an internship.  Open to Kinesiology majors.
description: Field service or experiences in cooperating agencies.  May be repeated for credit.

name: KINS3098
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated for credit with a change in content.

name: KINS3099
prerequisites: Must be of senior standing
description: Laboratory or library research to expand understanding of a specialized topic in sport, leisure, or exercise sciences.  May be repeated for credit with a change in content.

name: KINS3099W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to seniors with consent of the Department Head.
description: Laboratory or library research to expand understanding of a specialized topic in sport, leisure, or exercise sciences.  May be repeated for credit with a change in content.

name: KINS3100
catalogName: Prevention and Care of Athletic Injuries
prerequisites: Open only to Kinesiology majors.
description: An introductory class to explore general considerations of preventing, recognizing, and treating athletic injuries.

name: KINS3101
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors; must be concurrently enrolled in KINS 3130.
description: Allows students to gain skill competence in the area of medical writing.

name: KINS3102
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Provides students with an integrated approach to treatment of athletic injuries. Evidence based course provides fundamental concepts as well as application of the skills and knowledge learned.

name: KINS3103
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Provides students with an integrated approach to treatment of athletic injuries. Evidence based course provides fundamental concepts as well as application of the skills and knowledge learned.

name: KINS3104
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Covers anatomy, evaluation, pathology of spinal injuries and conditions, diagnosis and management of injuries related to the spine, thorax, and core.

name: KINS3110
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.  Cannot be taken for credit after passing EKIN 3350.
description: Provides students majoring in athletic training hands-on experience dealing with athletic injuries.

name: KINS3111
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Provides students majoring in athletic training hands-on experience dealing with athletic injuries.

name: KINS3112
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Provides students majoring in athletic training hands-on experience dealing with athletic injuries.

name: KINS3113
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Provides students majoring in athletic training hands-on experience dealing with athletic injuries.

name: KINS3114
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Provides students majoring in athletic training hands-on experience dealing with athletic injuries.

name: KINS3115
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.  May be repeated to a maximum of four credits.
description: Experiences in a variety of sports medicine settings that will serve to broaden an athletic-training student's awareness of medical coverage of athletic events and other medical personnel involved in athletic health care.

name: KINS3120
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Provides students majoring in athletic training in-depth knowledge of anatomy related to athletic injuries.

name: KINS3122
catalogName: Gross Anatomy Laboratory for Athletic Trainers
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Develops knowledge of structural and functional anatomy. It includes a comprehensive study of the internal and surface anatomy of the human body with emphasis on body tissues, the systems approach to anatomy, the head, neck, face, the upper extremity, thorax, abdomen, vertebral column, deep back, pelvis, and lower extremity. The relationships of muscular, skeletal, neural, and vascular structures will be discussed and demonstrated in human prosected material in a regional approach. Anatomical relationships to normal movement will be included. Labs will include the study of human prosected material, skeletons, and joint models. Taught with KINS 3120.

name: KINS3125
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors who are sophomores or higher.
description: Provides an overview of the general concepts and principles related to dealing with specific athletic injuries.

name: KINS3130
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors who are sophomores or higher.
description: Techniques and procedures used to evaluate injuries to the extremities. Includes history, observation, palpation, special tests, manual muscle testing, blood flow, nerve function, and other injury specific skills.

name: KINS3140
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Evaluation and treatment skills for athletic injuries to the head, face, neck, trunk, spine, thorax, and abdomen. Acute first-aid considerations in life-threatening situations will also be covered in-depth.

name: KINS3150
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Provides an assessment of athletic injuries experience that integrates the material in previous courses so as to serve as a capstone academic experience related to evaluation skills for athletic injuries.

name: KINS3155W
prerequisites: ENGL 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to Athletic Training majors only.
description: Administrative/Management concerns for the athletic trainer. Insurance, budgeting, counseling, facility design, hiring, record keeping, and other issues will be covered.

name: KINS3156
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Covers concepts pertaining to professional development in athletic training including workshop development, ethics and ethical decision making, organizational structure, work-place culture, and other topics pertaining to the profession.

name: KINS3160
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Counseling concerns for the athletic trainer.  Theory, practical skills, assessment, referral and specific counseling issues in athletic health care.

name: KINS3165W
catalogName: Current Research and Issues in Athletic Training
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Acquaint students with the recent research in the field, the components of conducting and publishing research in the field, and preparation for research endeavors at the graduate level. Important issues relevant to the athletic training profession will be discussed.

name: KINS3170
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Knowledge, skills, and values that a health professional must possess to recognize, treat, and refer, when appropriate, the general medical conditions and disabilities of athletes and others involved in physical activity.

name: KINS3177
catalogName: Pathophysiology and Pharmacology for Athletic Trainers
prerequisites: Open only to Athletic Training majors.
description: Focuses on the pathophysiology and pharmacology as it relates to athletic injuries. Specifically, the injury and repair process of skin, muscle, bone, ligaments, tendons, and cartilage. The pharmacology of therapeutic medications and performance enhancing substances will be covered.

name: KINS3201
catalogName: Research Methods and Statistical Analysis for Kinesiology
prerequisites: Open only to Kinesiology majors.
description: Introduces Kinesiology students to a biopsychosocial model of health and disease. The selection of research methods, including statistical procedures most appropriate for research questions related to prevention, intervention and diagnosis forms the core of the course. Students will gain experiences using software to analyze data germane to Kinesiologists and the interpretation of data through frequentist and Bayesian reasoning.

name: KINS3212
catalogName: Experiences in Athletic Training and Health Care
prerequisites: Instructor consent.
description: A course that allows students who are interested in a career in healthcare (physical therapy, athletic training or related field) a chance to engage in observation opportunities within the various clinical settings of healthcare and sports medicine. This class will also allow for inter professional discussion and dialog in the online environment.

name: KINS3320
prerequisites: Open only to Kinesiology majors.
description: Examines psychological theories and research related to exercise and sport behavior. Explores the study of how personality and situational variables affect motivation, anxiety, and aggression in exercise and sport. Additional topics to be examined include group processes in exercise and sport, performance enhancement and psychological development through sport.

name: KINS3522
prerequisites: PNB 2264 and 2265; basic mathematics skills; open only to students in Kinesiology Programs.
description: Quantitative and qualitative analyses of sport-related injuries and movements during sport, including the study of linear and angular motion, force and torque, momentum, energy, and equilibrium.

name: KINS3530
catalogName: Aerobic and Resistance Training for Performance
prerequisites: KINS 4500; open only to students in Kinesiology programs, others by consent of instructor.
description: Focuses on the knowledge, skills, and understanding of the scientific principles on which to design individualized aerobic training programs needed for optimal performance, health improvement, disease treatment, and injury prevention. Presents analysis techniques of human physiology specific to aerobic training and performing. Laboratory and field methods to evaluate aerobic ability, lactate threshold, economy, anthropometrics, and aerobic performance characteristics will be discussed.

name: KINS3530W
catalogName: Aerobic and Resistance Training for Performance
prerequisites: KINS 4500; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to students in Kinesiology programs, others by consent of instructor.
description: Focuses on the knowledge, skills, and understanding of the scientific principles on which to design individualized aerobic training programs needed for optimal performance, health improvement, disease treatment, and injury prevention. Presents analysis techniques of human physiology specific to aerobic training and performing. Laboratory and field methods to evaluate aerobic ability, lactate threshold, economy, anthropometrics, and aerobic performance characteristics will be discussed.

name: KINS3545
catalogName: Resistance Training Exercise Techniques and Evaluation
prerequisites: KINS 4500; open only to students in Kinesiology programs, others by consent of instructor.
description: Focuses on the knowledge, skills, and understanding of the scientific principles on which to design individualized resistance training programs needed for optimal performance, health improvement, disease treatment, and injury prevention. Presents analysis techniques of human physiology specific to resistance training and performing. Laboratory and field methods to evaluate anaerobic ability, flexibility, muscular strength and power and body composition will be discussed.

name: KINS3545
catalogName: Resistance Training for Health and Performance
prerequisites: KINS 4500; open only to students in Kinesiology programs, others by consent of instructor.
description: Focuses on the knowledge, skills, and understanding of the scientific principles on which to design individualized resistance training programs needed for optimal performance, health improvement, disease treatment, and injury prevention. Presents analysis techniques of human physiology specific to resistance training and performing. Laboratory and field methods to evaluate anaerobic ability, flexibility, muscular strength and power and body composition will be discussed.

name: KINS3545W
catalogName: Resistance Training for Health and Performance
prerequisites: KINS 4500; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to students in Kinesiology programs.
description: Focuses on the knowledge, skills, and understanding of the scientific principles on which to design individualized resistance training programs needed for optimal performance, health improvement, disease treatment, and injury prevention. Presents analysis techniques of human physiology specific to resistance training and performing. Laboratory and field methods to evaluate anaerobic ability, flexibility, muscular strength and power and body composition will be discussed.

name: KINS3610
prerequisites: Open only to Honors Students in Kinesiology Programs.
description: The student will meet with KINS faculty members and attend laboratory/program staff meetings to survey the opportunities available for future Honors Thesis research.

name: KINS3615
prerequisites: Open only to Honors Students in Kinesiology Programs.
description: The student will identify specific Honors Thesis research questions and will write a library research paper that will serve as the thesis Literature Review.

name: KINS3697W
prerequisites: ENGL 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to Honors Students in Kinesiology Programs.
description: The student will collect and interpret data and will write the Honors Thesis, completing work begun during EKIN 3615.

name: KINS4205W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; good academic standing with a minimum of 90 credits and consent of instructor.
description: Participation in a scholarly project (original research, systematic review, or clinical case report) with one or more faculty mentors and students. Students prepare a manuscript meeting professional standards for form and content, and a poster consistent in format with a professional meeting call for abstracts.

name: KINS4500
prerequisites: PNB 2264 and 2265; open only to students in Kinesiology Programs.
description: An organ systems approach to optimal human performance including metabolism, energy transfer, nerve transmission, muscle contraction, endocrine control, and cardiopulmonary physiology.

name: KINS4510
prerequisites: KINS 4500. Open only to students in Kinesiology programs; others by consent of instructor.
description: Fundamental concepts and physiology in Exercise Science with focus on special topics and conditions that challenge the human exercise response. These include stressful environments, use of ergogenic aids and special diets, exercise in special conditions, and advanced topics associated with fatigue, the immune system and stress/sleep deprivation: incorporating current research in these and other select areas.

name: KINS4510W
prerequisites: KINS 4500; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to students in Kinesiology programs.
description: Fundamental concepts and physiology in Exercise Science with focus on special topics and conditions that challenge the human exercise response. These include stressful environments, use of ergogenic aids and special diets, exercise in special conditions, and advanced topics associated with fatigue, the immune system and stress/sleep deprivation: incorporating current research in these and other select areas.

name: KORE1101
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing KORE 1102, 1103, or 1104.
description: Development of ability to communicate in Korean, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic communicative needs within a cultural setting.

name: KORE1102
prerequisites: KORE 1101 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing KORE 1103 or 1104.
description: Development of ability to communicate in Korean, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic communicative needs within a cultural setting.

name: KORE1103
prerequisites: KORE 1102 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing KORE 1104.
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Korean within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Korean-speaking world.

name: KORE1104
prerequisites: KORE 1103 or equivalent.
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Korean within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Korean-speaking world.

name: KORE1193
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: KORE3293
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: KORE3298
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: KORE3299
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: LAND2110
catalogName: Landscape Architecture: Graphics I - Design Drawing
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing LAND 2120 or 2410.
description: Knowledge and theory of graphic representation, exploration and development of design form. Introduction to basic design principles. Application of graphic and design theory through free-hand drawing in a studio environment. Abstraction and transformation of form emphasized.

name: LAND2120
catalogName: Landscape Architecture: Graphics II Design Communication
prerequisites: LAND 2110; open only to Landscape Architecture majors. May not be taken out of sequence after passing LAND 3130 or 3310.
description: Knowledge and theory of visual perception and model making. Application of theory in the creation of various graphic products including plan, section, elevation, paraline and perspective drawings.  Controlled free hand and computer methods in a studio environment.

name: LAND2210E
catalogName: The Common (Shared) Landscape of the USA: Rights, Responsibilities and Values
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing LAND 2220 or 2410.
description: An introduction to the study of vernacular landscapes in the USA with an emphasis on the relationship between societal values and land use patterns. CA 1.

name: LAND2220
catalogName: Landscape Architecture: Theory II - Design History
prerequisites: LAND 2210. May not be taken out of sequence after passing LAND 4340.
description: The development of designed landscapes is followed through time, emphasizing influences on current landscape architecture theory and practice.

name: LAND2410
catalogName: Landscape Architecture: Design I - Site Analysis
prerequisites: LAND 2110 and 2210; open to Landscape Architecture majors only. May not be taken out of sequence after passing LAND 3420 or 3580.
description: Knowledge and theory of site design and site analysis.  Dimensional requirements and appropriate relationships of site elements and systems. Collection and analysis of site data including legal, physical and cultural factors.  Application in a variety of site design projects. Field trips are required.

name: LAND3130
catalogName: Landscape Architecture: Graphics III - Computer Applications
prerequisites: LAND 2120; open only to Landscape Architecture majors. May not be taken out of sequence after passing LAND 3140.
description: Knowledge and theory of computer use in landscape architecture. Computer applications for data gathering, analysis and graphic communication. Application of knowledge and theory to a variety of site planning and design projects.

name: LAND3140
prerequisites: LAND 3130; open only to Landscape Architecture majors or with instructor consent.
description: Knowledge, theory and application of advanced computer applications used in site planning and site design.

name: LAND3230W
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: LAND3230WE
catalogName: Sustainable Environmental Planning and Landscape Design
description: Theories, concepts, and methods for sustainable planning and design of the land to balance and integrate the needs for conservation and development. Literature and case-study based, writing intensive exploration across critical contemporary themes such as climate change, urbanization, health and wellness, and globalization.

name: LAND3310
catalogName: Landscape Architecture: Construction I - Site Engineering
prerequisites: LAND 2120; open only to Landscape Architecture majors. May not be taken out of sequence after passing LAND 3320 or 3330.
description: Theory and practice in manipulating landform in landscape architecture.  Earthwork computation, drainage systems, sedimentation and erosion control, roadway design and low-impact design.

name: LAND3320
catalogName: Landscape Architecture: Construction II - Materials and Methods
prerequisites: LAND 3310; open to Landscape Architecture majors.
description: Knowledge and theory of site construction. Characteristics and installation methods of materials including concrete, masonry, wood and metal.  Application of knowledge and theory through development of construction drawings and related documents for site construction projects.

name: LAND3330
catalogName: Landscape Architecture: Construction III - Planting Design
prerequisites: LAND 3310; open only to landscape architecture majors.
description: Knowledge and theory of the role of plants as visual, spatial, ecological and cultural design elements and systems. Analysis and creation of planting plans that support and develop design concepts and respond to physical site conditions. Application on a variety of project types in a studio environment.

name: LAND3420
catalogName: Landscape Architecture: Design II - Space, Form and Meaning
prerequisites: LAND 2410; open to Landscape Architecture majors. May not be taken out of sequence after passing LAND 3430.
description: Knowledge and theory of spatial form in architecture, landscape architecture and urban design. Application of theory in the creation of 3-dimensional landscape models in a studio environment. Student attitudes about self-expression, environmental issues and social responsibility will be explored.

name: LAND3430
catalogName: Landscape Architecture: Design III - Program Development
prerequisites: LAND 3420; open to Landscape Architecture majors.
description: Knowledge and theory of site design and planning with a focus on program analysis and development.  Design of appropriate form and function through precedent study and research on user and client needs, development regulations and site context.  Application of theory to a variety of project types and scales. Field trips required.

name: LAND3510
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Study abroad course in Florence, Italy or other European location. The study of historical gardens, cityscapes and the critical inquiry of visual form and coherent patterns in cities. Site visits and team design projects.

name: LAND3580
catalogName: Field Studies in the Built Environment
prerequisites: LAND 2410; open only to Landscape Architecture majors or with instructor consent.
description: Travel to examples of landscape architecture, urban design, art installations or other related examples of spaces or places. Three day-long field trips.

name: LAND3582
prerequisites: LAND 3420, which may be taken concurrently; open only to Landscape Architecture majors, others with instructor consent.
description: Travel and participation in a professional conference or meeting related to landscape architecture .

name: LAND4294
prerequisites: Open to Landscape Architecture majors only.
description: Current topics in landscape architecture. This course may  be repeated for credit.

name: LAND4340
catalogName: Landscape Architecture: Theory IV - Professional Practice
prerequisites: LAND 2220; open only to Landscape Architecture majors.
description: Business, legal and professional dimensions of landscape architecture. Modes of practice, licensure and ethics, and contract development and administration. Emphasis on portfolio development and licensure preparation.

name: LAND4440
catalogName: Landscape Architecture: Design IV - Community Planning
prerequisites: LAND 3430; open only to landscape architecture majors. May not be taken out of sequence after passing LAND 4450.
description: Knowledge and theory of design of large scale landscapes such as open space systems, village and town centers and residential subdivisions. Application of theory to a variety of projects including community outreach work. Field trips are required.

name: LAND4450
prerequisites: LAND 4440; open to Landscape Architecture majors.
description: Knowledge and theory of site planning and design.  Application of theory and skills from previous design courses to a single, comprehensive site planning and design project. Field trips are required.

name: LING1010
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Discussion of nature-nurture debate with specific reference to language acquisition. Pros and cons of Chomsky's Innateness Hypothesis. CA 1.

name: LING1020
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Effects of geography, society, and politics on language use and variation (sociolinguistics). The geographical spread, growth and death of languages (language ecology). CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: LING1030
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Overview of world languages and language families. Typological classifications of linguistic properties: what can we expect in the structure of a language? Unity and diversity of language systems. Mechanisms of language change and variation. CA 2. CA 4.

name: LING1793
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program.  May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head or advisor may be required prior to the student's departure.

name: LING1795
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: Credits, prerequisites and hours as determined by the Senate Curricula and Course Committee.  May be repeated for credit with a change in topic.

name: LING2010Q
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing LING 3110.
description: An introduction to the methods and major findings of linguistic research as applied to the sound systems of languages and the structure and meaning of words and sentences. CA 3.

name: LING2793
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Program Director required, normally to be granted before the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor up to a maximum of six credits. May be repeated for credit.

name: LING2850
catalogName: Introduction to Sociolinguistics of the Deaf Community
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Sociolinguistics, demographics of the Deaf community; study of Deaf subgroups with different sociological, linguistic and cultural backgrounds; sociolinguistic integration of community members with the larger population in their cultural/ethnic community. Knowledge of American Sign Language not required. CA 2. CA 4.

name: LING3000Q
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: At least one course in Linguistics or Computer Science.
description: Computational methods in linguistic analysis and natural language processing. Topics include the use of text corpora and other sources of linguistic data; morphological analysis, parsing and language modeling; applications in areas such as information retrieval and machine translation.

name: LING3110
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; LING 2010; open to juniors or higher.
description: Research methods and laboratory techniques for the study of language acquisition and/or sentence processing. Students design and conduct a study using a computer database of child speech.

name: LING3310Q
prerequisites: LING 2010; open to juniors or higher.
description: The analysis of sound patterns in language within a generative framework: distinctive features, segmental and prosodic analysis, word formation, the theory of markedness.

name: LING3410Q
prerequisites: LING 2010Q. Not open for credit for students who have passed LING 3510.
description: Analysis of the semantics of natural languages in a generative framework: truth conditions, compositionality, quantification.

name: LING3510Q
prerequisites: LING 2010Q; open to juniors or higher.
description: The analysis of form and meaning in natural languages in a Chomskyan framework: surface structures, deep structures, transformational rules, and principles of semantic interpretation.

name: LING3511Q
prerequisites: LING 2010. Not open for credit for students who have passed LING 3510.
description: Analysis of the syntax of natural languages in a generative framework: phrase structure, movement, syntactic operations and dependencies.

name: LING3610W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: The study of language, culture, and their relationship. Topics include the evolution of the human language capacity; the principles of historical language change including reconstruction of Indo-European and Native American language families; writing systems; linguistic forms such as Pidgins and Creoles arising from languages in contact; the interaction between language and political systems, the struggle for human rights, gender, ethnicity, and ethnobiology. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: LING3789
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Individual research-related work directed by a faculty member. May be repeated for credit.

name: LING3790
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Experiential learning at an agency or business. May be repeated for credit. Students taking this course will be awarded a grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: LING3793
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program.   May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with the consent of the advisor.

name: LING3795
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.
description: With a change in topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: LING3798
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.
description: With a change in topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: LING3799
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: May be repeated for credit.

name: LING3800
prerequisites: ASLN 1102 or LING 2010Q. Recommended preparation: Both ASLN 1102 and LING 2010Q.
description: Linguistic analyses of American Sign Language focusing on the phonological, morphological, syntactic, and semantic levels.

name: LING3850
catalogName: Cultural and Linguistic Variation in the Deaf Community
prerequisites: LING 2850
description: Language and cultural models used in the Deaf community. Critical examination of demographic subgroups of the Deaf community and their linguistic background.

name: LING4500
prerequisites: LING 3511Q
description: Concepts and tools of current syntactic theory. Syntactic features, lexical and functional categories, representation of phrase structure, argument structure, Case, movement, locality.

name: LING4793
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Program Director required, normally to be granted before the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor up to a maximum of six credits. May be repeated for credit.

name: LLAS1000
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Interdisciplinary examination of the Latina/o experience and impact across the United States. Consideration of behavioral, institutional, and societal perspectives; national and transnational identity; cultural, legal, and educational issues. CA 2. CA 4.

name: LLAS1009
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Critical approaches to Latinos/as and cultural representation, production, and agency, as impacted by globalization and local dynamics. Will engage the value and function of  race, gender and sexuality in popular culture, literature, film, music, digital culture, visual arts, and urban culture.  Taught in English. Knowledge of Spanish is not required. CA 1. CA 4.

name: LLAS1009W
description: Critical approaches to Latinos/as and cultural representation, production, and agency, as impacted by globalization and local dynamics. Will engage the value and function of race, gender and sexuality in popular culture, literature, film, music, digital culture, visual arts, and urban culture. Taught in English. Knowledge of Spanish is not required. CA 1. CA 4.

name: LLAS1190
catalogName: Introduction to Latin America and the Caribbean
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Multidisciplinary exploration of the historical development of such aspects of Latin America and the Caribbean as colonization and nation formation; geography and the environment; immigration and migration; race, ethnicity, and gender in society, politics, economy, and culture. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: LLAS1190W
catalogName: Introduction to Latin America and the Caribbean
description: Multidisciplinary exploration of the historical development of such aspects of Latin America and the Caribbean as colonization and nation formation; geography and the environment; immigration and migration; race, ethnicity, and gender in society, politics, economy, and culture. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: LLAS1193
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Course work undertaken within approved Study Abroad programs, usually focusing on the history, culture, and society of a particular Latin American or Carribean country or countries. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 15 credits. Consent of Director of Latin American and Caribbean Studies required before departure.

name: LLAS1570
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Interdisciplinary honors course on the life and work experiences of contemporary Latin American and Caribbean migrant workers with focus on Connecticut. Integrated service learning component. Field trips required. CA 1. CA 4.

name: LLAS2001
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Introduces issues affecting Latinos in higher education.   Leadership and mentoring training.  Students analyze responsibilities and commitments in context of leadership for the common good and for purposeful change.

name: LLAS2011W
catalogName: Introduction to Latino-American Writing and Research
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or instructor consent; open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: 1000-level introductory course on Latino or Latin American Studies.
description: Students refine writing skills and learn how and where to conduct transnational academic research on the Latino-American experience. Interdisciplinary approaches, historical background of Latino American studies. CA 4.

name: LLAS2012
catalogName: Latinos in Connecticut: Writing for the Community
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: LLAS 2011W.
description: Students partner with Latino agencies to apply research and writing skills to community needs. Community theory, digital literacy, historical background of CT Latinos, contemporary issues that impact the population. Service learning component.

name: LLAS2293
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Course work undertaken within approved Education Abroad programs, usually focusing on the history, culture, and society of a particular Latin American or Caribbean country or countries.

name: LLAS2474
catalogName: Economic Development in Latin America and the Caribbean
prerequisites: ECON 1200 or both ECON 1201 and 1202
description: Survey of the economic history of Latin America and the Caribbean. Analysis of present-day development issues in the region, including economic growth, poverty, education, and health.

name: LLAS2621
catalogName: Cuba in Local and Global Perspective
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Major themes in Cuban politics and culture. Local and global perspective. Key topics include race, gender, class, cultural movements and practices, slavery, political economy and movements, nationalism. Formerly offered as HIST 3621.

name: LLAS2995
catalogName: Special Topics in Latino and Latin American Studies
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change in topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: LLAS3021
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Survey of anthropological contributions to the study of contemporary Mexico, Central America, South America, and the Hispanic Caribbean. Special focus on the comparative analysis of recent ethnographic case studies and local/regional/national/international linkages.

name: LLAS3029
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Comparative perspectives on the cultural formation of Caribbean societies; the region's demographic, economic and political links with the wider world.

name: LLAS3208
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: AFRA/HIST/HRTS 3563 or AFRA/HIST 3564 or 3620; or HIST/LLAS 3609.
description: Recent scholarship on the central role played by African-descended communities in shaping the early history of the Americas and their interconnection beyond geopolitical boundaries; race, gender, sexuality, class, religion, cultural movements and practices; slavery, political economy, and political movements.

name: LLAS3210
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Topics in socio-demographic patterns, cultural identity claims, community organization, migration and citizenship issues of Latino groups in post-WWII United States. Emphasis on comparative analysis and on policy implications. CA 4.

name: LLAS3211
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Students design, execute and write original, library or archival-based research on Latino/a experience using documents, films, literary works, surveys, photographic and newspaper materials.

name: LLAS3220
catalogName: History of Latinos/as in the United States
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Settlement and growth of Hispanic-origin populations in the United States today, from Spanish and Mexican settlement of the western United States to the growth of Latino communities. Student oral history project. CA 1. CA 4.

name: LLAS3221
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Latino/a issues related to human, civil and cultural rights, and gender differences.

name: LLAS3230
description: Feminist topics in contemporary Latina literature and cultural studies.

name: LLAS3231
description: Topics in Latino literature and cultural studies with an emphasis on masculinity and male authors.

name: LLAS3232
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800 or instructor consent; open to juniors or higher.
description: Extensive readings in Latina/o literature from the late nineteenth century to the present. CA 4.

name: LLAS3233
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800 or instructor consent; open to juniors or higher.
description: Advanced study of a theme, form, author, or movement in contemporary Latina/o literature.  May be repeated for credit with a change in topic.

name: LLAS3241
catalogName: Latin American Minorities in the United States
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Emphasis on groups of Mexican, Puerto Rican and Cuban origin, including treatment and historical background, social stratification, informal social relations, ethnic perceptions, relations and the concept of Latino identity.

name: LLAS3250
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Overview of health and health care issues among Latinos in the United States.  Particular attention is paid to cultural and social factors associated with health and well being (e.g. migration, acculturation, SES).

name: LLAS3251
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Critical discussion of issues involving gender and sexuality among Latinos, with particular attention to race, class, ethnicity, and  acculturation.

name: LLAS3264
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The role of ethnicity and race in women's lives. Special attention to communication research on ethnic and racial minority women. CA 4.

name: LLAS3265
catalogName: Literature of Puerto Rico and the Spanish Caribbean
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: SPAN 3178 or instructor consent.
description: Readings and discussions of major authors and works of the Spanish Caribbean with special emphasis on Puerto Rico.

name: LLAS3270
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Latino politics in the United States. Political histories of four different Latino populations: Mexican, Puerto Rican, Cuban and Central American. Different forms of political expressions, ranging from electoral behavior to political art. CA 4.

name: LLAS3271
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: U.S. immigration policy, trans-border politics, and the impact diasporas and ethnic lobbies have on U.S. foreign policy, with emphasis on Latino diasporas.

name: LLAS3293
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Director of Latin American and Caribbean Studies required before departure. May count toward the major with consent of advisor.

name: LLAS3320
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: COMM 1000, 2300 or 2600.
description: Issues of race, ethnicity, culture, class, gender, and sexuality in mainstream and alternative media. Analysis of how diverse groups use the media, are represented in, and interpret media content. Formerly offered as COMM/LLAS 4320.

name: LLAS3322
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: COMM 1000, 2300 or 2600.
description: Socio-cultural functions of soap operas/telenovelas as mediated serials constructed by commercial organizations and consumed by United States and global audiences. Formerly offered as COMM/LLAS 4470.

name: LLAS3327
catalogName: Power and Health in Latin America and the Caribbean
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: History, theories, and concepts about the human right to health and structural inequalities in the region.

name: LLAS3470
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Current issues in the study of Latinx youth and families from a social and developmental psychological perspective. Topics include parenting, youth development and adjustment, risky and healthy behaviors, cultural values, and immigration.

name: LLAS3525
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The economic, social, political, and cultural experiences of Latinos in the United States. CA 2. CA 4.

name: LLAS3525W
description: The economic, social, political, and cultural experiences of Latinos in the United States. CA 2. CA 4.

name: LLAS3575
catalogName: Cinema and Society in Latin America
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The aesthetic, social, and political significance of Latin American film.  With a change in content, this course may be repeated once for credit.

name: LLAS3607
catalogName: Latin America in the Colonial Period
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Pre-Columbian Civilization in America, the epoch of conquest and settlement, together with a study of the Ibero-Indian cultural synthesis which forms the basis of modern Latin American civilization. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: LLAS3609
catalogName: Latin America in the National Period
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Representative countries in North, Central, and South America and the Caribbean together with the historic development of inter-American relations and contemporary Latin American problems. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: LLAS3618
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The rise and fall of trans-Atlantic slavery. Topics include resistance, migration, antislavery mobilization, abolitionism, empire, revolution, cultural production, political economy, labor, gender, race and identity formation.

name: LLAS3619
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Encounter experience; slavery, antislavery mobilization, and abolitionism; colonialism; citizenship and nation building; race and gender; political cultures and movements; migration/immigration; cultural production; and political economy; topics will be examined from a historical perspective. CA 1. CA 4-INT

name: LLAS3619W
description: Encounter experience; slavery, antislavery mobilization, and abolitionism; colonialism; citizenship and nation building; race and gender; political cultures and movements; migration/immigration; cultural production; and political economy; topics will be examined from a historical perspective. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: LLAS3622
catalogName: History of Gender and Sexuality in Latin America and the Caribbean
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Topics may include: empire and colonialism/anti-colonialism; slavery, science, and the state; cultural practices and institutions; feminisms and masculinities; law and public policies; immigration; forms of labor and political mobilization; sex and reproduction; and human rights from historical perspective.

name: LLAS3635
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: HIST 3607.
description: The emergence of modern Mexico from independence to the present with emphasis on the Revolution of 1910. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: LLAS3660W
catalogName: History of Migration in Las Americas
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: LLAS 1190, ANTH 3042, HIST 3635, HIST 3609 or HIST 2674/LLAS 3220; LLAS 3210. Spanish useful but not required.
description: Applies broad chronological and spatial analyses of origins of migration in the Americas to the experiences of people of Latin American origin in Connecticut.  Addresses a range of topics from the initial settlement of the Americas to 21st century migrations. CA 1. CA 4.

name: LLAS3662
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A consideration of the importance of borderlands in the expansion and consolidation of European empires in the American continent, and later, in the shaping of newly independent republics. Contemporary issues related to Latin American borders, including migration, smuggling, violence, and the role of the state in shaping the borders of national cultures and societies.

name: LLAS3667
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Legal and political history of the relationship between Puerto Rico and the United States with an emphasis on the question of United States empire and the politics of cultural resistance.

name: LLAS3875
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: HIST 3607, 3609, 3610, 3635, 3660W, or 3674.  Not open to students who have passed HIST 3995 Asian Diasporas in the Americas.
description: Transnational history of migration and settlement of Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and South Asian diasporas across South, Central, and North America and the Caribbean, colonial through national period. Emphasis on political economy, racial formations, and constructions of national identity.

name: LLAS3990
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Work in cultural community-oriented setting(s). May be repeated for up to six credits.

name: LLAS3998
catalogName: Variable Topics in Latino and Latin American Studies
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: With a change in topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: LLAS3999
catalogName: Independent Study in Latino and Latin American Studies
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated for credit.

name: LLAS4100
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Interdisciplinary examination of the history of social justice organizing in the U.S.; theories, strategies, and practice of community organizing movements such as those for immigration, environmental, reproductive, and racial justice. Includes practice in community organizing and political advocacy.

name: LLAS4212
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Work in cultural community-oriented setting(s). May be repeated for up to 6 credits.

name: LLAS4320
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: LLAS4470
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: LLAS4994W
description: Capstone course in which majors and minors in Latin American Studies design, execute and write up original, library-based research on Latin America. Some readings may be in Spanish or Portuguese.

name: MARN1001
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: MARN1001E
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The relationship of humans with the marine environment. Exploitation of marine resources, development and use of the coastal zone, and the impact of technology on marine ecosystems. Taught at Storrs and Avery Point. CA 3.

name: MARN1002
prerequisites: A background in secondary school physics, chemistry or biology is recommended.  Not open to students who have passed MARN 1003. May not be taken out of sequence after passing MARN 2002 or 3001.
description: Processes governing the geology, circulation, chemistry and biological productivity of the world's oceans. Emphasis is placed on the interactions and interrelationships between physical, chemical, biological and geological processes that contribute to both the stability and the variability of the marine environment. First and second semester Storrs and Avery Point. Students who complete both MARN 1002 and 1004 will receive credit for a CA 3 laboratory course. CA 3.

name: MARN1003
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed MARN 1002. May not be taken out of sequence after passing MARN 2002 or 3001. Recommended preparation: A background in secondary school physics, chemistry or biology.
description: Processes governing the geology, circulation, chemistry and biological productivity of the world's oceans. Emphasis is on the interactions and interrelationships of physical, chemical, biological and geological processes that contribute to both the stability and the variability of the marine environment. Laboratory experiments, hands-on exercises, and field observations including required cruise on research vessel. Fall semester: Storrs and Avery Point. Spring semester: Storrs. CA 3-LAB.

name: MARN1004
prerequisites: MARN 1002 or equivalent.  Not open to students who have passed MARN 1003.
description: Laboratory experiments, hands-on exercises, and field observations (including required cruise on research vessel) that teach fundamental oceanographic concepts emphasizing physical, chemical, and biological processes and their interaction in the marine environment. First semester (Avery Point). First and second semester (Storrs). Students who complete both MARN 1002 and 1004 will receive credit for a CA 3 laboratory course.

name: MARN1160
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Introduction to scuba diving history, physics and physiology of diving, dive planning, open-circuit diving equipment, and marine environments. Open-water diving certification possible with successful completion of course. Approved medical questionnaire and liability waver required.

name: MARN1893
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in an international study program. Consultation with Marine Sciences program coordinator recommended prior to the student's departure. May be repeated for credit with a change of content for a maximum of six credits.

name: MARN1996
prerequisites: Instructor consent required.
description: Investigation of a special problem involving field and/or laboratory observations in marine sciences.

name: MARN2801WE
prerequisites: MARN 1002 or MARN 1003; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011.
description: Scientific analysis of coastal zone issues and interdisciplinary implications for society, including theories, observations, and models of how humans impact the health and well-being of the natural world and how the natural world impacts the health of humans. Topics incorporate public policies, legal frameworks, and moral and/or ethical dimensions regarding the environment. Written analysis and discussion of primary literature.
