prerequisites: PHRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of clinical pharmacy services to patients in an inpatient or outpatient health system setting. Direct patient care.

name: PHRX5173
prerequisites: PHRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.
description: The student will experience academia and leadership opportunities. Experiences will provide opportunities to improve leadership, teaching, mentoring, and communication skills. Non-direct patient care.

name: PHRX5195
prerequisites: PHRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes in a unique professional experience arranged in consultation with the Office of Experiential Education.

name: PHRX5199
prerequisites: PHRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes in a unique research setting.

name: PHRX5260
prerequisites: Open to pharmacy students who have completed the P3 curriculum and are in their P4 year.
description: Provides students with access to school provided review materials to support preparations for licensure exams (NAPLEX and MPJE). Students will demonstrate review completion for various topics and board exam readiness. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: PHRX5265
prerequisites: Open to pharmacy students who have completed the P3 curriculum and are in their P4 year.
description: Provides students with access to school provided review materials to support preparations for licensure exams (NAPLEX and MPJE). Students will demonstrate review completion for various topics and board exam readiness. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: PHYS1010Q
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1201 or 1401 or 1501 or 1601.
description: Basic concepts and applications of physics for the non-science major.  Scientific principles and quantitative relationships involving mechanics, energy, heat and temperature, waves, electricity and magnetism, and the theory of the atom are covered.  A laboratory provides hands-on experience with the principles of physics. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS1020Q
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed PHYS 1025.
description: A basic introductory astronomy course without laboratories, including principles of celestial coordinate systems and telescope design; applications of fundamental physical laws to the sun, planets, stars and galaxies; evolution of stars, galaxies and the universe; recent space probe results, modern cosmology, astrobiology. Night observing sessions are an integral part of the course. CA 3.

name: PHYS1025Q
prerequisites: Not open to students who have passed PHYS 1020.
description: A basic introductory astronomy course including principles of celestial coordinate systems and telescope design; applications of fundamental physical laws to the sun, planets, stars and galaxies; evolution of stars, galaxies and the universe; recent space probe results, modern cosmology, astrobiology. Basic quantitative laboratory techniques relevant to astronomy. Night observing sessions are an integral part of the course. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS1030Q
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Concepts of physics applied to current problems of the physical environment: energy, transportation, pollution. No previous knowledge of physics is assumed. Not applicable to any requirement that specifies a course in "general physics." CA 3.

name: PHYS1035Q
catalogName: Physics of the Environment with Laboratory
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1030.
description: Concepts of physics applied to the physical environment, particularly to current problems related to energy, transportation, and pollution. These relationships will be further explored in the laboratory section.  No previous knowledge of physics is assumed. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS1040QE
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Principles of physics and quantitative reasoning applied to astrobiology, the search for extraterrestrial life, and cosmic, stellar, and atmospheric conditions for habitability. A systems perspective on the impacts of human civilization on habitability. CA 3.

name: PHYS1075Q
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Basic principles of physics and scientific reasoning will be taught in the context of the production and perception of music, emphasizing the historic and scientific interplay between physics and music. Basic quantitative laboratories pertaining to sound, music, and waves. No previous knowledge of physics or music is assumed. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS1201Q
prerequisites: MATH 1060 or 1110 or 1120 or 1125 or equivalent. Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1401Q, 1501Q, or 1601Q. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHYS 1202Q.
description: A non-calculus based course introducing the laws of force and motion applied to mechanical phenomena. Concepts such as work, mechanical energy, linear and angular momentum, and energy conservation are explained. The laboratory offers fundamental training in precise measurements. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS1201Q
prerequisites: MATH 1060 or 1110 or 1120 or 1125 or equivalent. Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1401Q, 1501Q, or 1601Q. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHYS 1202Q.
description: A non-calculus based course introducing the laws of force and motion applied to mechanical phenomena. Concepts such as work, mechanical energy, linear and angular momentum, and energy conservation are explained. The laboratory offers fundamental training in precise measurements. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS1202Q
prerequisites: PHYS 1201Q. Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1402Q, 1502Q, or 1602Q.
description: A non-calculus based course introducing the principles governing electromagnetic phenomena, including electromagnetic radiation and waves and electric circuits. The laboratory offers fundamental training in precise measurements. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS1202Q
prerequisites: PHYS 1201Q. Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1402Q, 1502Q, or 1602Q.
description: A non-calculus based course introducing the principles governing electromagnetic phenomena, including electromagnetic radiation and waves and electric circuits. The laboratory offers fundamental training in precise measurements. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS1230
prerequisites: PHYS 1202Q, and MATH 1122 or 1132Q, any of which may be taken concurrently. Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1401Q, 1501Q or 1601Q.
description: Physics problems, emphasizing applications of calculus, dealing with topics in general physics. Intended for those students who have taken or are taking PHYS 1202Q and who desire to have a calculus-based physics sequence equivalent to PHYS 1401Q-1402Q or 1501Q-1502Q

name: PHYS1300
prerequisites: MATH 1121Q or 1126Q, either of which may be taken concurrently, or MATH 1131Q or 1151Q.  Not open to students who have passed PHYS 1230, 1401Q, 1402Q, 1501Q, 1502Q, 1601Q, or 1602Q.
description: Survey of the principles of physics and their application to the pharmaceutical sciences. Basic concepts of calculus are used. Examples from mechanics, electricity and magnetism, thermodynamics, fluids, waves, and atomic and nuclear physics.

name: PHYS1401Q
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: MATH 1121Q or 1131Q. Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1501Q or 1601Q. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHYS 1402Q. May be taken for not more than two credits, with the permission of the instructor, after passing PHYS 1201Q.
description: Quantitative study of the basic facts and principles of physics with an emphasis on mechanical phenomena. Concepts such as work, mechanical energy, linear and angular momentum, and energy conservation are explained. The laboratory offers fundamental training in physical measurements. Recommended for non-engineering students who desire to have a calculus-based physics sequence. It is also recommended for science majors for whom a one year introductory physics course is adequate. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS1401Q
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: MATH 1121Q or 1131Q. Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1501Q or 1601Q. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHYS 1402Q. May be taken for not more than two credits, with the permission of the instructor, after passing PHYS 1201Q.
description: Quantitative study of the basic facts and principles of physics with an emphasis on mechanical phenomena. Concepts such as work, mechanical energy, linear and angular momentum, and energy conservation are explained. The laboratory offers fundamental training in physical measurements. Recommended for non-engineering students who desire to have a calculus-based physics sequence. It is also recommended for science majors for whom a one year introductory physics course is adequate. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS1402Q
prerequisites: PHYS 1401Q. Recommended preparation: MATH 1122Q or 1132Q. Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1502Q or 1602Q. May be taken for not more than two credits, with the permission of the instructor, by students who have passed PHYS 1202Q.
description: Quantitative study of the basic facts and principles of physics with an emphasis on electromagnetic phenomena, including electromagnetic radiation and waves and electric circuits. The laboratory offers fundamental training in physical measurements. Recommended for non-engineering students who desire to have a calculus-based physics sequence. It is also recommended for science majors for whom a one year introductory physics course is adequate. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS1402Q
prerequisites: PHYS 1401Q. Recommended preparation: MATH 1122Q or 1132Q. Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1502Q or 1602Q. May be taken for not more than two credits, with the permission of the instructor, by students who have passed PHYS 1202Q.
description: Quantitative study of the basic facts and principles of physics with an emphasis on electromagnetic phenomena, including electromagnetic radiation and waves and electric circuits. The laboratory offers fundamental training in physical measurements. Recommended for non-engineering students who desire to have a calculus-based physics sequence. It is also recommended for science majors for whom a one year introductory physics course is adequate. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS1501Q
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: PHYS 1010Q or high school physics; CE 2110; MATH 2110Q or 2130Q, which may be taken concurrently. Not open for credit after passing PHYS 1401Q or 1601Q. May not be taken out of sequence after passing 1502Q. May be taken for not more than two credits, with the permission of the instructor, by students who have passed PHYS 1201Q.
description: Introduction to Newton's laws, their extensions and applications. Concepts such as work, mechanical energy, linear and angular momentum, and energy conservation are explained. Basic concepts of calculus are used. Recommended for prospective Engineering majors. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS1502Q
prerequisites: PHYS 1501Q. Not open to students who have passed PHYS 1402Q or 1602Q. May be taken for not more than two credits, with instructor's permission, by students who have passed PHYS 1202Q.
description: Introduction to principles of electromagnetism and Maxwell's equations, including electric circuits, electromagnetic wave propagation, optics, and other relevant applications to engineering. Basic concepts of calculus are used. Recommended for prospective Engineering majors. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS1600Q
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: MATH 1060, which may be taken concurrently, or a qualifying score on the mathematics placement assessment.
description: Quantitative exploration of the structure of matter, including gas laws, electric and magnetic forces, the electron, x-rays, waves and lights, relativity, radioactivity, and spectra. This course is recommended for prospective Physics majors. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS1601Q
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: MATH 1121Q or 1131Q or 1151Q (1151Q is preferred for physics majors). Not open to students who have passed PHYS 1401Q or 1501Q. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHYS 1602Q. May be taken for not more than three credits, with instructor's permission, by students who passed PHYS 1201Q.
description: Foundational principles of mechanics: kinematics, forces, energy, momentum, angular momentum, torque, gravitation, waves, harmonic motion and nonlinear dynamics. Basic concepts of calculus are used. Recommended for prospective Physics majors, this course is taught integrating theory, experimental activities, and collaborative problem solving in an active learning setting. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS1602Q
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: PHYS 1601Q; MATH 1122Q or 1132Q or 1152Q (1152Q preferred for Physics majors). Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1402Q or 1502Q. May be taken for not more than three credits, with instructor's permission, after passing PHYS 1202Q.
description: Foundational principles of electromagnetism: electrostatics, magnetostatics, electrodynamics, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic wave propagation, and optics, including some of their relevant applications to physics. Basic concepts of calculus are used. Recommended for prospective Physics majors, this course is taught integrating theory, experimental activities, and collaborative problem solving in an active learning setting. CA 3-LAB.

name: PHYS2200
prerequisites: PHYS 1230 or 1402Q or 1502Q or 1530 or 1602Q, any of which may be taken concurrently; MATH 2410Q, which may be taken concurrently.
description:
A basic introduction to numerical and mathematical methods required for the solution of physics problems using currently available scientific software for computation and graphics.
GEOC
 

SM-2/9/04

name: PHYS2300
prerequisites: PHYS 1230 or 1402 or 1502 or 1530 or 1602 , which may be taken concurrently; or PHYS 1202  with consent of instructor. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHYS 3300, 3401, 4300, or 4900.
description: The inadequacies of classical physical concepts in the submicroscopic domain. The revision of physical principles that led to special relativity and modern quantum theory. Application to topics chosen from atomic and molecular physics, solid state physics, nuclear physics and elementary particle physics.

name: PHYS2400
catalogName: Mathematical Methods for the Physical Sciences
prerequisites: PHYS 1230 or PHYS 1402 or PHYS 1502 or PHYS 1530 or PHYS 1602; and MATH 2110; either or both may be taken concurrently; or instructor consent.
description: Theoretical mathematical methods required for physical science courses.

name: PHYS2501W
description: Experiments in classical and/or quantum phenomena with an emphasis on acquiring, analyzing, and interpreting experimental data. Extensive writing in the style of experimental reports and/or journal articles.

name: PHYS2701
prerequisites: PHYS 1401 or 1501 or 1601; MATH 1131 (or 1151) and 1132 (or 1152). Prerequisite or corequisite: PHYS 1402 or 1502 or 1602; MATH 2110. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHYS 2702 or PHYS 4740.
description: The conceptual framework describing astronomical objects. Topics include orbits, light, and stars. Concepts of statistical mechanics, quantum mechanics, and relativity as needed for astrophysical topics.

name: PHYS2702
prerequisites: PHYS 2701. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHYS 4710, 4720, or 4740.
description: Observational astronomy and applications to astrophysical phenomena. Topics include telescopes and astronomical instrumentation, production of chemical elements and molecules, distance scales, black holes and compact objects, gravitational lensing, galaxy kinematics and structure, dark matter, dark energy, cosmic rays, gravitational waves, and Big Bang cosmology.

name: PHYS3101
prerequisites: PHYS 1230 or 1402 or 1502 or 1530 or 1602; MATH 2110 or 2130 which may be taken concurrently.
description: Newton's Laws of motion applied to mass points, systems of particles, and rigid bodies.

name: PHYS3102
prerequisites: MATH 2410 or 2420; PHYS 3101 or CE 2120.
description: Further applications of Newton's Laws; continuous media; Lagrange's and Hamilton's formulation of dynamics.

name: PHYS3150
prerequisites: PHYS 1230 or 1402 or 1502 or 1530 or 1602 or instructor consent.
description: The principles of devices and their applications to instrumentation in science and engineering. Rectification, filtering, regulation, input and output impedance, basic transistor circuits, operational amplifiers, preamplifiers for photodiodes and other transducers, logic gates, and digital circuits.

name: PHYS3201
prerequisites: PHYS 1602 or with consent of instructor PHYS 1230 or 1530 or 1402 or 1502 or 3104; MATH 2110 and 2410 or MATH 2130 and 2420.
description: Advanced theory and applications of electrostatics, magnetostatics, potentials, and electromagnetic fields in matter.

name: PHYS3202
prerequisites: PHYS 3201.
description: Advanced theory and applications of electromagnetic fields. Gauge transformations, electromagnetic waves and radiation, and relativistic corrections to electrodynamics.

name: PHYS3300
prerequisites: PHYS 1230 or 1402 or 1502 or 1530 or 1602; PHYS 2300; MATH 2110 and 2410, or MATH 2130 and 2420. Recommended preparation:  PHYS 3201 and 3401.
description: The laws of thermodynamics and their microscopic statistical basis; entropy, temperature, Boltzmann factor, chemical potential, Gibbs factor, and the distribution functions.

name: PHYS3401
prerequisites: PHYS 2300; MATH 2110 and 2410 or MATH 2130 and 2420.
description: Elementary Principles of quantum mechanics; solutions to the Schrödinger equation for bound states and scattering in one dimension; general solution for central forces in two and three dimensions, orbital angular momentum and spin, and other fundamental quantum mechanical principles.

name: PHYS3401
prerequisites: PHYS 2300; MATH 2110 and 2410 or MATH 2130 and 2420.
description: Elementary Principles of quantum mechanics; solutions to the Schrödinger equation for bound states and scattering in one dimension; general solution for central forces in two and three dimensions, orbital angular momentum and spin, and other fundamental quantum mechanical principles.

name: PHYS3402
prerequisites: PHYS 3401.
description: Applications of quantum mechanics, useful approximation methods, the variational method, the WKB method, scattering and other advanced topics.

name: PHYS3501
prerequisites: PHYS 1202Q or 1402Q or 1502Q or 1602Q; and 2501W
description: In-depth exploration of classical and quantum phenomena through advanced experimentation using contemporary methods.

name: PHYS3989
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Introduction to original investigation performed by the student under the guidance of a faculty member. The student is required to submit a brief report at the end of each semester. May be repeated for credit.

name: PHYS4093
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program.   May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: PHYS4095
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: PHYS4096W
description: Research investigation for the advanced undergraduate. Research and writing of a Thesis are required. Final public presentation is recommended.

name: PHYS4098
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: With a change of topic, this course may be repeated for credit.

name: PHYS4099
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change of topic, this course may be repeated for credit.

name: PHYS4100
prerequisites: PHYS 1230 or 1402Q or 1502Q or 1530 or 1602Q, any of which may be taken concurrently; MATH 1122Q or 1126Q or 1131Q any of which may be taken concurrently.  Recommended preparation: MATH 1132Q.
description: The composition, structure, and dynamics of the Earth's core, mantle, and crust inferred from observations of seismology, geomagnetism, and heat flow.

name: PHYS4130
prerequisites: PHYS 1230 or 1402Q or 1502Q or 1530 or 1602Q, any of which may be taken concurrently; MATH 1122 or 1126Q or 1131Q, any of which may be taken concurrently.
description: Evolution of the solar system, celestial mechanics, tidal friction, internal composition of planets, black-body radiation, planetary atmospheres.

name: PHYS4140
prerequisites: PHYS 3202 and 3401.
description: The physics of lasers, including optical pumping and stimulated emission, laser rate equations, optical resonators, Gaussian beam propagation, Q-switching, mode-locking and nonlinear optics. Applications to gas, solid-state and tunable laser systems.

name: PHYS4150
prerequisites: PHYS 1230 or 1402 or 1502 or 1530 or 1602 or instructor consent.  Recommended preparation:  PHYS 3103 or 3201.
description: An introduction to geometrical and physical optics. Thick lenses, stops, aberrations, interference, diffraction, polarization.

name: PHYS4210
description: Crystal lattices, lattice waves, thermal and electronic properties, imperfections in solids.

name: PHYS4350
prerequisites: PHYS 3401.
description: Properties of nuclei and particles, conserved quantities, isospin, quark model, Fermi gas model, electroweak interaction, high energy scattering.

name: PHYS4710
prerequisites: PHYS 2701 and 2702; MATH 2410Q
description: The structure and evolution of stars. Gravitational collapse, hydrostatic equilibrium, novae and shocks, and compact objects with degenerate matter.

name: PHYS4720
prerequisites: PHYS 2701 and 2702; MATH 2410Q. Recommended preparation: proficiency in calculus.
description: Galaxy formation and evolution in the hierarchical expanding Universe. Properties of the interstellar medium, including star formation and radiative transfer; stellar populations, structure, kinematics and dynamics of galaxies.

name: PHYS4730
prerequisites: PHYS 2300, 3101, and 3201; or instructor consent.
description: Gravity and the problem of motion from the ancient Greeks to Newton to Einstein. Special relativity. General relativity. Curvature. Classic tests of general relativity. Gravitational waves. Black holes. Newtonian cosmology. Big Bang theory. Inflation. Dark matter. Dark energy. Accelerating universe.

name: PHYS4740
prerequisites: PHYS 2701 and PHYS 2702.
description: Basic principles and techniques of observational and computational astrophysics. Statistical techniques for data analysis and interpretation of astronomical data. Data mining, visualization, and numerical techniques in simulations of astrophysical systems. Includes short research projects using data from observations and/or simulations.

name: PHYS4900
prerequisites: PHYS 2300 or 3101 or 3102; PHYS 3202; PHYS 3401, which may be taken concurrently; PHYS 2501W or 2502 or MSE 4003.
description: Experiments in modern and classical physics are independently designed, performed, and evaluated. Experiments are chosen from the areas of atomic, solid state and thermal physics, as well as from acoustics and optics. Computers are utilized for control of the experimental process, data acquisition and analysis. A written description of the proposed method must be submitted and approved before each experiment, and a subsequent written critical evaluation of each experiment is required.

name: PNB1000
prerequisites: Open to first-year students, others with consent of instructor.
description: An introduction for declared and prospective Physiology and Neurobiology majors. Introduces key discoveries, current research areas, and technological innovations in physiology and neurobiology, and develops familiarity with the PNB department.

name: PNB2250
prerequisites: BIOL 1107. Recommended preparation: BIOL 1108.
description: An introduction to comparative animal physiology, emphasizing the evolutionary impacts of diverse physical, chemical, and environmental factors on vertebrates and invertebrates.

name: PNB2264
prerequisites: BIOL 1107; CHEM 1122 or 1124Q or 1127Q. Not open to students who have passed PNB 2274. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PNB 2265. Repeat restrictions apply; see advising.uconn.edu/repeat-policy for more information.
description: Fundamentals of human anatomy and physiology, for students in human health and human performance related majors. Topics covered include the musculoskeletal system, membrane potential, neurophysiology, the central nervous system, sensation, and the endocrine system. May not be counted toward the Biological Sciences or PNB majors.

name: PNB2265
prerequisites: PNB 2264. Not open to students who have passed PNB 2275. Repeat restrictions apply; see advising.uconn.edu/repeat-policy for information.
description: Fundamentals of human anatomy and physiology, for students in human health and human performance related majors. Topics covered include the cardiovascular, immune, respiratory, digestive, renal, and reproductive systems. May not be counted toward the Biological Sciences or PNB majors.

name: PNB2274
prerequisites: BIOL 1107; CHEM 1124Q or 1127Q. Not open for credit to students who have passed PNB 2264. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PNB 2275, 3264, or 4162. Repeat restrictions apply; see advising.uconn.edu/repeat-policy for details.
description: Fundamentals of human physiology and anatomy enhanced through inquiry-based laboratories.

name: PNB2275
prerequisites: PNB 2274. Not open to students who have passed PNB 2265. Must be taken after PNB 2274 to count for credit. Repeat restrictions apply; see advising.uconn.edu/repeat-policy for information.
description: Fundamentals of human physiology and anatomy enhanced through inquiry-based laboratories.

name: PNB3120W
prerequisites: One 2000-level course in PNB; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to Physiology and Neurobiology majors.
description: Strategies for effective public communication of science, focusing on accessibly conveying physiological concepts, and considering the role of life scientists as public communicators. Student work may include storytelling, blogging, data visualization, and videography.

name: PNB3180
catalogName: Field Study in Physiology and Neurobiology
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Supervised field work at an off-campus research organization or business.  Activities that meet objectives consistent with a major in Physiology and Neurobiology must be planned and agreed upon in advance by the job site supervisor, the faculty coordinator and the student. May be repeated for a total of up to 6 credits. One credit may be earned for each 42 hours of pre-approved activities up to a maximum of 4 credits. May be applied towards the major with permission of department head subject to the PNB major's 3-credit research group limitation. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: PNB3251
prerequisites: One 2000 level course in PNB or consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher.
description: Brain functions, from molecular and cellular to overall central nervous system organization. Topics of current scientific interest.

name: PNB3252
prerequisites: PNB 2250 or both PNB 2274and 2275 or instructor's consent; open to juniors or higher.  Recommended preparation:  an undergraduate class in basic comparative animal physiology.
description: Advanced, in-depth examination of animal comparative physiology.

name: PNB3255
prerequisites: PNB 2264 or 2274; open to juniors or higher.
description: Anatomy of the human brain and spinal cord; emphasis on the structure and functions of major regions in the central nervous system.

name: PNB3260
prerequisites: PNB 2250 or PNB 2274.  Recommended preparation: MCB 2000 or MCB 2210 or MCB 2410, any of which may be taken concurrently.
description: Principles of stem cell biology and the use and applications of stem cells in research and therapy. Emphasis on molecular, cellular and physiological properties of stem cells, mechanisms of differentiation, use of recombinant DNA technology and application of stem cells in disease models.

name: PNB3262
prerequisites: One 2000 level course in PNB or consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher.
description: Functions of hormones in mammalian physiology emphasizing humans.

name: PNB3263WQ
prerequisites: PNB 2250 or PNB 2274-2275; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800; open to juniors or higher.
description: Experimental investigations in neurobiology. Emphasis on designing and carrying out independent research projects, and on communicating the results.

name: PNB3264W
prerequisites: PNB 2274, MCB 2210 or 2410 or 3010; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher; instructor consent required.
description: Case study of a disease: genetics and inheritance patterns; molecular defects, including transcription and post-transcription defects; physiological defects; therapeutic approaches.

name: PNB3265
prerequisites: A 2000-level course in PNB or instructor consent. Open to juniors or higher.
description: The evolution of hormonal signaling systems in invertebrates and vertebrates.

name: PNB3270
prerequisites: BIOL 1107; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: PNB 3262.
description: Molecular mechanism(s) of hormone action in vertebrates and invertebrates. Molecular and genetic characterization of hormones, receptors, and signal transduction, and hormone actions at the molecular, cellular, and organismal levels. Includes student presentations on selected papers.

name: PNB3275
prerequisites: One 2000-level course in PNB or instructor consent; open to juniors or higher. Not open to students who have taken PNB 3276. Recommended preparation: MCB 2000 or 3010.
description: Various neurotransmitter systems in the brain including anatomy, physiology, cell biology and biochemistry. Neurotransmitters, receptors and transporters at synapses. Synaptic signaling pathways and molecules. Meets during the first nine weeks of the semester.

name: PNB3278
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Introductory grounding and experience for students interested in the healing professions in how patients and families experience illness, and what it's like to be a professional health provider.

name: PNB3293
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head or Key Advisor required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of Department Head or Key Advisor.

name: PNB3294
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: With a change of topic, this course may be repeated for credit.

name: PNB3295
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary; Open only to juniors or higher.
description: With a change in content, this course may be repeated for credit.

name: PNB3296
catalogName: Undergraduate Research in Physiology and Neurobiology
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Students may apply up to a maximum of three credits of PNB 3296 or PNB 4296 toward the credits-in-major requirement.

name: PNB3298
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.
description: With a change of topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: PNB3299
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Designed for the advanced undergraduate student who desires to pursue a special problem as an introduction to independent investigation.  With a change of topic, this course may be repeated for credit.

name: PNB3340
catalogName: Non-coding RNAs in Human Physiology and Disease
prerequisites: MCB 2400 or 2410; MCB 2000 or 3010; MCB 2210 or PNB 2275; open to juniors or higher.
description: Non-coding RNAs: discovery, major classes, regulatory pathways, physiology, disease, research methodology.

name: PNB3350
catalogName: Membrane Transport in Health and Disease
prerequisites: One 2000 level course in PNB or consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher.
description: Fundamental mechanisms by which water and small molecules are transported across biological membranes. Biophysical and biochemical analysis of transport by diffusion, osmosis, channels, carriers and pumps in health and disease.

name: PNB3500
prerequisites: One 2000 level course in PNB or consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher.
description: Cellular and molecular mechanisms controlling cardiovascular and respiratory function in health and disease.

name: PNB3700
prerequisites: PNB 2274 or 3251 or instructor consent; open to juniors or higher.
description: Cellular and molecular mechanisms supporting the detection of sensory stimuli in vertebrates, invertebrates and other organisms. Detection of chemicals, touch, temperature, pain, sound, light, heat, magnetic fields, and electricity.

name: PNB4296
catalogName: Honors Undergraduate Research In Physiology and Neurobiology
prerequisites: Instructor consent.
description: Students may apply up to a maximum of three credits of PNB 3296 or 4296 toward the credits-in-major requirement. Not restricted to students in the Honors program.

name: PNB4296W
catalogName: Senior Research Thesis in Physiology and Neurobiology
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: PNB4297W
catalogName: Senior Research Thesis in Physiology and Neurobiology
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Three credits of PNB 3299, which may be taken concurrently; open to juniors or higher. Open only with consent of instructor and departmental honors committee. Not limited to honors students.
description: Special research or independent investigaton for advanced undergraduates. Involves research and writing a thesis. Formerly offered as PNB 4296W.

name: PNB4400
prerequisites: PNB 2274 or 3251; one course from MCB 2000, 2210, 2400, 2410, or 3010; or instructor consent.
description: Basic principles of genetics, molecular and cell biology, and physiology as applied to the mechanisms of disease and repair processes in the nervous system.  Topics include established concepts and areas of current research on chronic neurodegenerative, synaptic, and demyelinating disorders, acute trauma and cerebrovascular disorders, and plasticity and repair.

name: POLS1002
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: Major themes of political theory such as justice, obligation, and equality, and their relevance to contemporary political concerns. CA 1.

name: POLS1202
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: A survey of institutions, politics, and ideologies in democratic and non-democratic states. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: POLS1207
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: A survey of institutions, ideologies, development strategies, and the political processes in nonwestern culture. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: POLS1402
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: The nature and problems of international politics. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: POLS1402W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: The nature and problems of international politics. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: POLS1602
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description:
Analysis of the organization and operation of the American political system. 
CA 2.

name: POLS1602W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: Analysis of the organization and operation of the American political system. CA 2.

name: POLS2023
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1002.
description: Exploration of political theoretical questions through essays and films. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: POLS2023W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1002.
description: Exploration of political theoretical questions through essays and films. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: POLS2062
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Honors course providing a thematic overview of privacy from a variety of disciplinary perspectives. Public policy, legal and ethical debates surrounding privacy and the impact of technology and scientific advances on how privacy is conceptualized, valued, enacted, and protected.

name: POLS2062W
description: Provides a thematic overview of privacy from a variety of disciplinary perspectives. Public policy, legal and ethical debates surrounding privacy and the impact of technology and scientific advances on how privacy is conceptualized, valued, enacted, and protected.

name: POLS2072Q
prerequisites: Recommended preparation:  High School Algebra II and a mathematics course.
description: Explanation of the quantitative methods used in political science. Application of these methods for the analysis of substantive political questions.

name: POLS2073Q
catalogName: Advanced Quantitative Methods in Political Science
prerequisites: POLS 2072Q or STAT 1000Q or SOCI 3211Q or equivalent.
description: Explanation of advanced quantitative methods used in political science. Application of these methods and relevant statistical software for the analysis of substantive political questions.

name: POLS2222
catalogName: Political Institutions and Behavior in Western Europe
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Comparative analysis of the governments and politics of Western Europe.

name: POLS2222W
catalogName: Political Institutions and Behavior in Western Europe
description: Comparative analysis of the governments and politics of Western Europe.

name: POLS2450
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: POLS 1402. Not open for credit to students who have passed POLS 2998 when offered as "Nuclear Security."
description: The development of nuclear weapons and their consequences. Topics include the science and history of nuclear weapons, as well as nuclear proliferation, terrorism, and strategy.

name: POLS2602W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Not open for credit to students who have passed POLS 2998 when taught as Religion and Politics. Recommended preparation: POLS 1602.
description: The interaction and relationship between religion and politics in the U.S. political system. CA 4.

name: POLS2607
prerequisites: POLS 1602.
description: An analysis of the aims, organization, and growth of parties in the United States.

name: POLS2607W
description: An analysis of the aims, organization, and growth of parties in the United States.

name: POLS2622
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The practical working of democracy and the role of state and local governments.

name: POLS2998
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An exploration of the fundamental nature of political conflicts on the national and international levels.   May be repeated for credit with a change in subject matter.

name: POLS2998W
description: An exploration of the fundamental nature of political conflicts on the national and international levels.

name: POLS3002
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: An examination of Greek, Roman and early Judeo-Christian political ideas and institutions, and their relevance to the present.

name: POLS3012
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Major political doctrines of the modern period up through the end of the 19th century, and their influence upon political movements and institutions as they are reflected in the democratic and nondemocratic forms of government.

name: POLS3012W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Major political doctrines of the modern period up through the end of the 19th century, and their influence upon political movements and institutions as they are reflected in the democratic and nondemocratic forms of government.

name: POLS3017
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Major political writings from 1900 to the present.

name: POLS3019
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher; Recommended preparation: POLS 1002 and AFRA 2211.
description: Exploration of black U.S., Caribbean, and African political thought, with a focus on processes of and resistance to racialization, enslavement, and colonization.

name: POLS3019W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011, open to juniors or higher.
description: Exploration of black U.S., Caribbean, and African political thought, with a focus on processes of and resistance to racialization, enslavement, and colonization.

name: POLS3022W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Exploration of the social and political theories of Marx and Engels, and of later interpretations and modifications of their ideas.

name: POLS3023
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher. Freshmen and sophomores by permission.
description: An examination of major works of literature that either describe governing systems and institutions, interpret political processes and clashes, or address perennial themes in political philosophy and theory. CA 2.

name: POLS3023W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher, first year students and sophomores by permission.
description: An examination of major works of literature that either describe governing systems and institutions, interpret political processes and clashes, or address perennial themes in political philosophy and theory. CA 2.

name: POLS3027
prerequisites: rerequisite: Open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1002. Not open to students who have passed POLS 2998W when offered as "Historical Women Political Thinkers."
description: Critical study of the writings of several historical women political thinkers.

name: POLS3027W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011, open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1002. Not open to students who have passed POLS 2998W when offered as "Historical Women Political Thinkers."
description: Critical study of the writings of several historical women political thinkers.

name: POLS3030
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1002. Not open to students who have passed POLS 2998W when offered as "Settler Colonialism/Indigenous Thought and Practice."
description: Exploration of political theoretical works engaging settler colonialism and historic and contemporary American indigenous thought and practice.

name: POLS3030W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011, open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1002. Not open to students who have passed POLS 2998W when offered as "Settler Colonialism/Indigenous Thought and Practice."
description: Exploration of political theoretical works engaging settler colonialism, and historic and contemporary American indigenous thought and practice.

name: POLS3032
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: American political thought from the colonial to the contemporary period. Political thought discussed as the ideological expression of the larger sociopolitical situation.

name: POLS3040
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.
description: A study of power and politics through a survey of major political ideologies and their expression in art and architecture, in various past and present cultures, both as a means of political socialization and a tool of resistance and protest.

name: POLS3042
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Various theories of human rights, both historical and contemporary. Conceptual arguments both in favor and critical of the theory and practice of human rights will be considered, with literature taken primarily from philosophy and political theory.

name: POLS3062
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1002, 3002 or 3012.
description: Survey of theories of democracy from classical times to the present; analysis of defenders and critics of democracy.

name: POLS3062W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: POLS 1002, 3002 or 3012.
description: Survey of theories of democracy from classical times to the present; analysis of defenders and critics of democracy.

name: POLS3072
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Variants of major ideologies such as liberalism, socialism, communism, anarchism, fascism, and feminism in their socio-historical context, as well as alternative visions from the Third World.

name: POLS3082
catalogName: Critical Race Theory as Political Theory
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1002.
description: Interdisciplinary scholarship on racial identity, legal decisions, and political action from the perspective of political science and political theory. Topics include interactions between states and social movements, the intersections of race, class, gender, and membership, and the problems with both post-racialism and identity politics.

name: POLS3202
catalogName: Comparative Political Parties and Electoral Systems
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: A focus on political party and electoral systems around the world, including advanced industrial nations, transitional nations, and less developed nations.  Issues such as the relationship between electoral and party systems, democratic reform, voting behavior, and organization of political parties are examined.

name: POLS3202W
catalogName: Comparative Political Parties and Electoral Systems
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: A focus on political party and electoral systems around the world, including advanced industrial nations, transitional nations, and less developed nations. Issues such as the relationship between electoral and party systems, democratic reform, voting behavior, and organization of political parties are examined.

name: POLS3203
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Development of environmental policies and institutions and their effects on the motivations and the actions of individuals and groups with implications for questions of equity, justice, and sustainability. Draws on approaches from comparative politics, public policy, and international relations.

name: POLS3205
catalogName: Voting Behavior and Public Opinion Around the World
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1202 or POLS 1207.
description: How voting behavior differs across countries. Topics may include turnout, class voting, the electoral role of religion, accountability for the economy, vote buying, ethnic politics, attitudes toward welfare, support for democracy, and anti-Americanism.

name: POLS3206
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Introduction to overlapping themes in economics and political science including the substantive and emperical relationship between these two in advanced industrial democracies.

name: POLS3208
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher. Recommended  preparation:  POLS 1202 or 1207.
description: Historical and contemporary role of oil in comparative politics and international relations. CA 2.

name: POLS3208W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; Recommended preparation: POLS 1202 or 1207.
description: Historical and contemporary role of oil in comparative politics and international relations. CA 2.

name: POLS3209
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Political, socioeconomic, environmental, science and engineering challenges of energy sources; comparison of feasibility and sustainability of energy policies around the world.

name: POLS3210
catalogName: Ethnic Conflict and Democracy in Comparative Perspective
prerequisites: Open to juniors of higher. Recommended preparation:  POLS 1202 or 1207.
description: Conflicts among ethno-national groups in democratic and democratizing states and conflict management strategies. Theoretical approaches to understanding origin-of-identity conflicts.

name: POLS3210W
catalogName: Ethnic Conflict and Democracy in Comparative Perspective
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; Recommended preparation: POLS 1202 or 1207.
description: Conflicts among ethno-national groups in democratic and democratizing states and conflict management strategies. Theoretical approaches to understanding origin-of-identity conflicts.

name: POLS3211
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1202 or 1207.
description: The role of water in state building, state-society relations, and economic and political development. Draws on approaches from comparative politics and international relations. CA 2.

name: POLS3211W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1202 or 1207.
description: The role of water in state building, state-society relations, and economic and political development. Draws on approaches from comparative politics and international relations. CA 2.

name: POLS3212
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Cultural difference and human rights in areas of legal equality, women's rights, political violence, criminal justice, religious pluralism, global security, and race relations.

name: POLS3214
prerequisites: POLS 1202 or 1207 or instructor consent; open to sophomores or higher.
description: Institutional structures of modern welfare states, including systems of social insurance, healthcare, and education. Assessment of leading political explanations for their growth and cross-national differences among them.

name: POLS3214W
prerequisites: POLS 1202 or 1207 or instructor consent; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: coursework in economics and sociology.
description: Institutional structures of modern welfare states, including systems of social insurance, healthcare, and education. Assessment of leading political explanations for their growth and cross-national differences among them.

name: POLS3216
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher, others by consent
description: How women and gender circumscribe political life and generate relationships of inequality and justice on a global scale.   Topics may include conflict and security, development, human rights and legal systems, labor and migration, nation building, political economy, and transnational justice.

name: POLS3218
prerequisites: Open to juniors of higher. Recommended preparation:  POLS 1202 or 1207.
description: Governments, political behavior, human rights and constitutional rights of indigenous peoples of North America and Latin America. Impact of international law and globalization on indigenous peoples.

name: POLS3218W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: POLS 1202 or 1207.
description: Governments, political behavior, human rights and constitutional rights of indigenous peoples of North America and Latin America. Impact of international law and globalization on indigenous peoples.

name: POLS3228
catalogName: Politics of Russia and the Former Soviet Union
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The social and political structure of the former Soviet Union, the causes and outcome of efforts to reform it, and the development of democratic politics in Russia and other former Soviet republics.

name: POLS3235
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Theories and institutions of Latin American politics, with emphasis on issues of stability and change.

name: POLS3237
catalogName: Democratic Culture and Citizenship in Latin America
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The development of democratic attitudes, norms, and behavior in Latin America. CA 2.

name: POLS3237W
catalogName: Democratic Culture and Citizenship in Latin America
description: The development of democratic attitudes, norms, and behavior in Latin America. CA 2.

name: POLS3239
catalogName: Politics of the Environment and Development
prerequisites: Open to juniors and higher.  Recommended preparation: POLS 1202 or 1207
description: Politics of the environment and development with a focus on environmental issues in developing countries.

name: POLS3239W
catalogName: Politics of the Environment and Development
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors and higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1202 or 1207.
description: Politics of the environment and development with a focus on environmental issues in developing countries.

name: POLS3240
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: POLS3240E
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.
description: Introduction to major debates about environmental and climate justice and the related policies and programs. Implications for the ongoing efforts to promote environmental stewardship and the design of global, national, and subnational institutions of climate governance. CA 2.

name: POLS3245
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: a 1000-level course in Economics.
description: Chinese political structure and policymaking process, attempts at democratization, process and outcome of economic reforms, development challenges in contemporary China.

name: POLS3247
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Gender aspects of war. Masculinities and militaries; gender-based war violence; laws of war and post-war conditions for male and female soldiers and civilians.

name: POLS3249
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Construction of gender in Islamic texts and history, the religion's interaction with other patriarchal cultures and systems, western interventions and their impact, male leaders' reform efforts, women's movements.

name: POLS3250
catalogName: The Political Economy of East Asia
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: 1000-level courses in political science and economics.
description: Economic, political, and social development of East Asia. CA 2.

name: POLS3250W
catalogName: The Political Economy of East Asia
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: 1000-level courses in political science and economics.
description: Economic, political, and social development of East Asia. CA 2.

name: POLS3252
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The political systems in contemporary Africa; the background of the slave trade, imperialism, colonialism, and the present concerns of nationalism, independence, economic development and military rule. Emphasis on sub-Saharan Africa.

name: POLS3255
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Internal development of the South African state and the external response to apartheid policies, with special attention to both white and African politics, U.S. policy, and other selected topics.

name: POLS3256
catalogName: Politics and Human Rights in Global Supply Chains
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1202 and 1402 and POLS/HRTS 3212.
description: Political and human rights implications of regulating contemporary global supply chains: official regulatory frameworks; non-regulatory approaches to rule-making (such as voluntary corporate codes of conduct and industry standards); social responses to the dilemmas of "ethical" sourcing of goods and services.

name: POLS3256W
catalogName: Politics and Human Rights in Global Supply Chains
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800, open to Political Science and Human Rights majors and minors; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1202, POLS 1402 and POLS/HRTS 3212.
description: Political and human rights implications of regulating contemporary global supply chains: official regulatory frameworks; non-regulatory approaches to rule-making (such as voluntary corporate codes of conduct and industry standards); social responses to the dilemmas of "ethical" sourcing of goods and services.

name: POLS3402
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Problems in international relations with emphasis on changing characteristics of international politics.

name: POLS3406
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Origins and contested definitions of globalization, and its impact on national, regional and international institutions and political processes. Designed for upper-level undergraduate students with a solid grounding in comparative politics and international relations.

name: POLS3406W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Origins and contested definitions of globalization, and its impact on national, regional and international institutions and political processes. Designed for upper-level undergraduate students with a solid grounding in comparative politics and international relations.

name: POLS3410
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Politics of international economic relations: trade, finance, foreign direct investment, aid.

name: POLS3412
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Politics of how humans and natural systems interact. Managing the global environment, regulating resource commons, and coordinating to solve environmental problems.

name: POLS3414
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Key American national security issues as integral parts of the larger problem of global security.

name: POLS3418
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The role of intergovernmental and nongovernmental organizations and international law in world affairs with special attention to contemporary issues.

name: POLS3418W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: The role of intergovernmental and nongovernmental organizations and international law in world affairs with special attention to contemporary issues.

name: POLS3422
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: A comparative study of foreign policy making. Use of computer-assisted simulation provides realistic experience in foreign policy decision making and international negotiation.

name: POLS3426
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Lectures and films from several nations serve to illustrate techniques and effects of propaganda, analyzing the pervasive impact that propaganda has on our lives. The course concentrates on the World War II era.

name: POLS3428
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Examination of the usage of torture by state and non-state actors. Questions include, "Why is torture perpetrated?" "What domestic and international legal frameworks and issues related to the use of torture?" "How effective are existing legal prohibitions and remedies?" "Who tortures?" and "How does torture affect transitional justice?"

name: POLS3429
prerequisites: Open to Juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1402.
description: Nature and origins of violence, including torture, genocide, terrorism, and civil war, on the part of individuals, non-state groups, and states.

name: POLS3429W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors and above. Recommended preparation: POLS 1402
description: Nature and origins of violence, including torture, genocide, terrorism, and civil war, on the part of individuals, non-state groups, and states.

name: POLS3430
catalogName: Evaluating Human Rights Practices of Countries
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Examination of the ways in which governments, businesses, NGOs, IGOs, and scholars assess which human rights are being respected by governments of the world. Hands-on experience in rating the level of government respect for human rights in countries around the world.

name: POLS3432
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: A chronological examination of the foreign relations of the United States from 1776 to the first World War.

name: POLS3434
catalogName: Honors Core: Excavating the International in Everyday Practices
description: Examination of daily international practices utilizing an everyday objects lens, with attention to ethical implications for activism, change, and social justice.

name: POLS3434W
catalogName: Honors Core: Excavating the International in Everyday Practices
description: Examination of daily international practices utilizing an everyday objects lens, with attention to ethical implications for activism, change, and social justice.

name: POLS3437
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The foreign relations of the United States from the first World War to the present.

name: POLS3438W
catalogName: Writing Seminar in Recent American Diplomacy
prerequisites: POLS 3437, which may be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: POLS3442
catalogName: The Politics of American Foreign Policy
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Instructions, forces and processes in the making of American foreign policy. Emphasis will be on contemporary issues.

name: POLS3447
catalogName: American Diplomacy in the Middle East
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The strategic, political, and economic interests that have shaped U.S. policy in the Middle East. U.S. responses to regional crises, peace efforts, arms transfers, covert operations and military intervention.

name: POLS3450
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: POLS 1402. Not open for credit to students who have passed POLS 2998 when offered as Technology and Security.
description: Exploration of how technological developments affect the causes, conduct, and outcomes of war.

name: POLS3457
catalogName: Foreign Policies of the Russian Federation and the Former USSR
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The Soviet Union's role in world affairs as background for studying the international consequences of the breakup of the USSR; the foreign policies of the former soviet republics among themselves, and of Russia and selected other republics.

name: POLS3462
catalogName: International Relations of the Middle East
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The foreign policies and security problems of Middle Eastern States; sources of regional conflict and competition - oil, water, borders, religion, ideology, alliances, geopolitics, refugees, and superpower intervention.

name: POLS3464
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Political relations between Arabs and Israelis with an emphasis on war and diplomacy.

name: POLS3464W
description: Political relations between Arabs and Israelis with an emphasis on war and diplomacy.

name: POLS3472
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Relations among countries of South Asia and between this region and the rest of the world. Problems of development and security confronting South Asian countries. CA 4-INT.

name: POLS3472W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Relations among countries of South Asia and between this region and the rest of the world. Problems of development and security confronting South Asian countries. CA 4-INT.

name: POLS3476
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Theory and practice of political leadership. Comparison of leaders in different political systems. Leadership in foreign and domestic politics. Case studies of great leaders.

name: POLS3600
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed POLS 2998 when taught as "Making the Modern American Presidency." Recommended preparation: POLS 1602.
description: Developments in the presidency from the constitutional era through President Hoover.

name: POLS3601
prerequisites: Not open for credit to students who have passed POLS 2998 when taught as Modern American Presidency. Recommended preparation: POLS 1602 and 3600.
description: Developments in the presidency from President Franklin Roosevelt to the present.

name: POLS3602
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The contemporary Presidency and its interactions with the Congress in the formation of public policy.

name: POLS3603WQ
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: POLS 1602; POLS 2072Q or STAT 1000Q or STAT 1100Q. Not open for credit to students who have passed POLS 2998W when offered as "Congressional Apportionment and Redistricting."
description: Empirical analyses and reporting of research on these fundamental democratic processes. CA 2.

name: POLS3604
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: In-depth analysis of the U.S. Congress, including representation, elections, policy formation, law making, and organization.

name: POLS3604W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: In-depth analysis of the U.S. Congress, including representation, elections, policy formation, law making, and organization.

name: POLS3606
prerequisites: POLS 1602.
description: An analysis of the politics of election administration. Topics include: the roles of state and local governments; the participation of candidates, political parties, and voters; convenience-voting options, new technologies, voter turnout, and voter errors; redistricting; voter suppression and voter fraud; and prospects for reform.

name: POLS3608
catalogName: The Art, Science, and Business of Political Campaigns
prerequisites: POLS 1602.
description: An analysis of strategy, communications, fundraising, and voter mobilization in contemporary political campaigns.

name: POLS3610
prerequisites: POLS 1602.
description: An examination of films that describe the development of American political institutions, norms, and values; that portray the processes exhibited in contemporary political institutions or the behaviors that characterize modern-day politicians; or that interpret recurring clashes in American politics. CA 2.

name: POLS3610W
prerequisites: POLS 1602 and ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011
description: An examination of films that describe the development of American political institutions, norms, and values; that portray the processes exhibited in contemporary political institutions or the behaviors that characterize modern-day politicians; or that interpret recurring clashes in American politics. CA 2.

name: POLS3612
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Explaining elections and the basis for voters' decisions.

name: POLS3613
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher; freshmen and sophomores by permission. Recommended preparation: POLS 1602.
description: Campaign organization, strategy, and election outcomes in Congressional elections. Topics include candidates and nominations, the roles of political parties and interest groups, campaign communications, campaign finance, and electoral reform.

name: POLS3613W
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher; first year students and sophomores by permission; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: POLS 1602.
description: Campaign organization, strategy, and election outcomes in Congressional elections. Topics include candidates and nominations, the roles of political parties and interest groups, campaign communications, campaign finance, and electoral reform.

name: POLS3615
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Theoretical and empirical examination of electoral realignment in the United States. CA 2.

name: POLS3615W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Theoretical and empirical examination of electoral realignment in the United States. CA 2.

name: POLS3617
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Theoretical foundations of the American political economy. Examination of selected public policy issues, including interaction between economic factors and incentives, and democratic institutions and processes.

name: POLS3618
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Relationship between democracy and inequality. Economic inequality and its causes, poverty, public opinion, inequalities in political voice and representation, public policy, the role of money in politics.

name: POLS3622
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Study of American political leadership as it relates to political culture, institutions and democratic principles.

name: POLS3625
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.
description: Concepts, theories, structure, and substance of public opinion.

name: POLS3627
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: An examination of contemporary Connecticut politics on the state and municipal levels.

name: POLS3632
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Political systems and problems confronting urban governments.

name: POLS3632W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Political systems and problems confronting urban governments.

name: POLS3633
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Examination of contemporary public policy through the lens of race.

name: POLS3642
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Political behavior, theory, and ideology of African-Americans, with emphasis on contemporary U.S. politics. CA 4.

name: POLS3647
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Black leadership, emphasizing the principles, goals, and strategies used by African-American men and women to secure basic citizenship rights during the civil rights era.

name: POLS3652
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: An introduction to major philosophical and theoretical debates at the core of black feminist thought, emphasizing the ways in which interlocking systems of oppression uphold and sustain each other.

name: POLS3662
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Latino politics in the United States. Political histories of four different Latino populations: Mexican, Puerto Rican, Cuban and Central American. Different forms of political expressions, ranging from electoral behavior to political art. CA 4.

name: POLS3667
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Legal and political history of the relationship between Puerto Rico and the United States with an emphasis on the question of United States empire and the politics of cultural resistance.

name: POLS3672
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: An introduction to feminist thought, the study of women as political actors, the feminist movement and several public policy issues affecting women.

name: POLS3710
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: International relations theory and speculative fiction as interpretations and interrogations of war, peace, politics, knowledge, and imagination.

name: POLS3720
catalogName: Heroes and Villains in American Politics
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: An exploration of how conventional understandings of heroism and villainy influence American politics and, reciprocally, how reigning trends in American politics influence widely shared conceptions of heroism and villainy.

name: POLS3802
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The role of the Supreme court in expounding and developing the United States Constitution. Topics include judicial review, separation of powers, federalism, and due process.

name: POLS3807
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The role of the Supreme Court in interpreting the Bill of Rights. Topics include freedoms of speech and religion, criminal due process, and equal protection.

name: POLS3812
prerequisites: POLS 1602; open to juniors or higher.
description: The Supreme Court in the Political Process.

name: POLS3817
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.  When students intend to take several courses in the Judicial Process field, it is recommended that 3817 be taken first.
description: Leading schools of legal thought, fundamental principles and concepts of law, the basic framework of legal institutions, and judicial procedure.  Particular attention is devoted to the general features of American law as it affects the citizen, and primary emphasis is placed on the function of law as a medium for attaining a balance of social interests in a politically organized society.

name: POLS3822
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Exploration of themes in the study of law and courts by contrasting scholarly work against representations of such themes in movies, televisions, and other media of popular culture.

name: POLS3822W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Exploration of themes in the study of law and courts by contrasting scholarly work against representations of such themes in movies, televisions, and other media of popular culture.

name: POLS3827
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Criminal justice in the United States, with emphasis on the links between law, politics, and administration.

name: POLS3832
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: International and domestic legal concepts concerning jurisdiction in a maritime setting.

name: POLS3834
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: U.S. immigration policy, trans-border politics, and the impact diasporas and ethnic lobbies have on U.S. foreign policy, with emphasis on Latino diasporas.

name: POLS3837
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Strategies used by interest groups to achieve civil rights recognition through the legal system and legislative process.

name: POLS3837W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Strategies used by interest groups to achieve civil rights recognition through the legal system and legislative process.

name: POLS3842
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The politics of public administration. Role of administrative agencies and officials in American national, state, and local governments.

name: POLS3847
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Introduction to the study of policy analysis. Consideration of description and prescriptive models of policy-making. Examination of several substantive areas of national policy in the United States.

name: POLS3850
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Relationship between power and ethics in political life.  Examination of ethical perspectives on political decisions and issues.

name: POLS3857
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Analysis of interactions among educational policy, politics, and other social forces. Insights and concerns from politics and other social sciences disciplines applied to different levels and types of schooling.

name: POLS3991
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: POLS3993
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted before the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: POLS3995
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: POLS3999
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated for credit with a change in subject matter. Open only with consent of instructor and department head.

name: POLS4894
