description: Faculty research presentations demonstrating current topics of investigation within the department, literature review skills, and research design techniques. Recommended for sophomore and junior Honors students who are beginning their thesis research. May be repeated for up to two credits. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: POLS4994
prerequisites: POLS 4894; open only to juniors or higher; instructor consent required.
description: Required for students in the Honors Program. Weekly seminar on selected topics in political science. Students must complete this course prior to their final semester.

name: POLS4997W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: All honors students writing an honors thesis in Political Science must take this course in each of their last two semesters. Course may be repeated once for credit.

name: PORT1101
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Development of ability to communicate in Portuguese, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic survival needs within a cultural setting.

name: PORT1102
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Development of ability to communicate in Portuguese, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic survival needs within a cultural setting.

name: PORT1103
prerequisites: PORT 1102 or equivalent.
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Lusophone world.

name: PORT1104
prerequisites: PORT 1103 or equivalent.
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Lusophone world.

name: PORT1193
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head required, normally before the student's departure.

name: PORT3293
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: PORT3295
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.  With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: PORT3298
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.  With a change of topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: PORT3299
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: PP1001
prerequisites: Ratcliffe Hicks students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: Public policy history and institutions, government administration and systems, policy analysis, contemporary policy issues, polling and influences on policy making. CA 2.

name: PP2100
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Theory and practice of surveys, including overall project design, questionnaire development, sampling, methods of data collection and data analysis.

name: PP3001
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The public policy process in the United States and frameworks for understanding and evaluating contemporary policy problems.

name: PP3010
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing PP 3011.
description: Research design for policy analysis, impact analysis, implementation analysis, program evaluation.

name: PP3011Q
prerequisites: PP 3010; STAT 1000Q or 1100Q; or consent of instructor.
description: Data analysis for program evaluation, public policy and management research including data description, probability theory, statistical inference, multiple regression and time series analysis.

name: PP3020
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Exploration of policy analysis using case studies on various contemporary policy topics.

name: PP3020W
description: Exploration of policy analysis using case studies on various contemporary policy topics.

name: PP3030
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher.
description: Concepts, theories, structure, and substance of public opinion.

name: PP3031
catalogName: Public Administration in Theory and Practice
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Overview of public administration theory, systems and practices as they have developed in the United States. Explores the roles of public officials in the context of a pluralistic democratic society.

name: PP3032
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Introduction to the policy and management issues surrounding how governments budget and spend the money they raise.

name: PP3033
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Examination of contemporary public policy through the lens of race.

name: PP3082
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Policy workshop on the practical application of making public policy.

name: PP3091
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: PP3098
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An exploration of fundamental issues in public policy, public management and public opinion.  May be repeated for credit with a change in subject matter.

name: PP3099
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated for credit with a change in subject matter.

name: PP3203
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Development of environmental policies and institutions and their effects on the motivations and the actions of individuals and groups with implications for questions of equity, justice, and sustainability. Draws on approaches from comparative politics, public policy, and international relations.

name: PP4031
catalogName: Financial Management for Public and Nonprofit Organizations
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher, others by consent
description: Management of financial resources in public service organizations. Topics include variance analysis, cost analysis, public sector and nonprofit accounting, financial statement analysis, and forecasting.

name: PP4032
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher, others by consent
description: An examination of the municipal bond market, capital budgeting techniques, and related public policy issues.

name: PP4033
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Analytical tools and concepts to evaluate policies related to government revenues, the delivery of public services, and intergovernmental relations.

name: PP4034
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher, others by consent
description: Examination of the concepts and principles of public policy analysis, with applications to important  social issues.

name: PP4095
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: Credits and hours by arrangement. May be repeated for credit with a change in subject matter.

name: PP4346
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher, others by consent
description: Theory and practice of child and family policy. Topics may include marriage and divorce, fertility, employment, and human capital.

name: PP4365
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher, others by consent
description: The structures, processes, and principles of human resource management in public service and examination of contemporary human resource policies and challenges.

name: PSYC1100
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Basic principles that underlie mental processes and behavior; research methodology, biopsychology, sensation, perception, learning, memory and language. Ordinarily this course should be taken in the fall semester. CA 3.

name: PSYC1101
prerequisites: PSYC 1100. PSYC 1101 and 1103 may not both be taken for credit.
description: Psychology as a social science. Research methodology, developmental, personality, clinical, abnormal and social psychology. CA 2.

name: PSYC1103
prerequisites: PSYC 1100;  Not open for credit to students who have passed PSYC 1101.  May not be taken concurrently with PSYC 1101.
description: Psychology as a social science. Research methodology, developmental, personality, clinical, abnormal and social psychology. Applications of theory, writing, and demonstrations during discussion periods. CA 2.

name: PSYC2100Q
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103; STAT 1000 or 1100 or Statistics Q 1000 level. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PSYC 3250, 3251, 3450, 3550, 3551, 3552, or 3899.
description: Design, analysis, and reporting of psychological research. Experimental and quasi-experimental designs, laboratory and correlational techniques, research ethics.

name: PSYC2100WQ
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103; STAT 1000 or 1100 or STAT Q 1000 level; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PSYC 3250, 3251, 3450, 3550, 3551 or 3552.
description: Design, analysis, and reporting of psychological research. Experimental and quasi-experimental designs, laboratory and correlational techniques, research ethics.

name: PSYC2101
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103.
description: General introduction to cross-cultural and multicultural issues and the role psychology has played in understanding the experiences of diverse groups. CA 4.

name: PSYC2110
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: PSYC 1100
description: Sexuality from across psychological science, highlighting relevant theoretical perspectives, methodology, and empirical research.

name: PSYC2200
description: Physiological processes related to motivation, emotion, sensory processes, motor skills, learning, and psychiatric conditions.

name: PSYC2201
prerequisites: PSYC 1100 or BIOL  1107.
description: An overview of drug effects on chemical transmission in the nervous system, with an emphasis on the behavioral/psychological effects of drugs.

name: PSYC2208
prerequisites: PSYC 1100 or BIOL 1107 or BIOL 1108
description: Cellular, circuit, and neural systems basis of sensation and perception including evolutionary and ecological differences among mammals.

name: PSYC2209
catalogName: Learning and Memory: From Brain to Behavior
prerequisites: PSYC 1100 or  BIOL 1107 or 1108. Recommended preparation: PSYC 2200.
description: Neurobiological basis of learning and memory, including topics in genetics, evolution and ethology.

name: PSYC2300
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103.
description: Nature of abnormal behavior, theories and data regarding symptoms, etiology, treatment and prevention of mental disorders.

name: PSYC2300W
description: Nature of abnormal behavior, theories and data regarding symptoms, etiology, treatment and prevention of mental disorders.

name: PSYC2301
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103.
description: Theories, methods, and research in both clinical and experimental approaches to personality.

name: PSYC2400
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103.
description: Social behavior, personality, perception, cognition, language, intelligence, learning, biobehavioral processes, and research methodology in developmental perspective.

name: PSYC2500
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103.
description: Learning and memory principles found in animal research and their relationship to human behavior. Human and other species' specific types of unique learning abilities.

name: PSYC2501
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103.
description: Different views of mental representation and processes involved in memory, language comprehension, perception, attention, and problem solving. Historical development of models in cognitive psychology.

name: PSYC2502
catalogName: Science of Learning and Art of Scientific Communication
prerequisites: Instructor consent required. Not open for credit to students who have passed PSYC 3884 when offered as "Science of Learning and Art of Communication."
description: Lecture, discussion, and team-based presentations related to the principles of learning and the essentials of scientific communication.

name: PSYC2600
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103.
description: Applications of psychology in the workplace: Measurement, personnel decisions, performance appraisal, training, motivation, worker attitudes, leadership, ergonomics and job design, workplace health and safety.

name: PSYC2700
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103.
description: Attitudes, social cognition, social influence, interpersonal relations, group dynamics.

name: PSYC2701
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103.  Recommended preparation:  PSYC 2700.
description: Introduction to theoretical perspectives and behavioral research that seek to explain the nature and mechanisms of intergroup relations and the psychology of culture, prejudice, and biased behavior. CA 4.

name: PSYC3100
catalogName: The History and Systems of Psychology
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103; PSYC 2300 or PSYC 2300W or PSYC 2301 or PSYC 2400 or PSYC 2600 or PSYC 2700; PSYC 2200 or PSYC 2500 or PSYC 2501 or PSYC 3201 or PSYC 3500 or PSYC 3501.
description: Philosophical and scientific origins and major schools, including structuralism, functionalism, behaviorism, gestalt, and psychoanalysis.

name: PSYC3100W
catalogName: The History and Systems of Psychology
description: Philosophical and scientific origins and major schools, including structuralism, functionalism, behaviorism, gestalt, and psychoanalysis.

name: PSYC3101
prerequisites: PSYC 2100Q.
description: Practical and theoretical interpretation of common personality, industrial, educational, cognitive, and attitude tests. Evaluating utility, test bias, and error. Using tests in clinical, educational, and workplace settings.

name: PSYC3102
prerequisites: Three credits of 2000 or 3000 level psychology.
description: Gender roles, socialization, women and work, women's relationships, violence against women, and other topics. Theory and research. CA 4.

name: PSYC3103
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: PSYC3104E
prerequisites: PSYC 1100 and 1101 or 1103.
description: Reciprocal relationships between built and natural environments and human behavior.

name: PSYC3105
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103.
description: The interface between psychology and health is examined using a biopsychosocial model. Topics include stress and coping, health promotion, adjustment to chronic illness, and the psychology of health behaviors

name: PSYC3106
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103.
description: Empirical and theoretical literature on psychological experiences of African Americans. Impact of race, culture, and ethnicity on psychological development. CA 4.

name: PSYC3150
prerequisites: PSYC 3105
description: Introduction to experimental design and research methods in health psychology. Includes a class research project.

name: PSYC3200
prerequisites: PSYC 1100 or BIOL 1102, 1103, 1107 or 1108; open to juniors or higher.
description: Methods, concepts and findings of behavioral genetics in animals and humans.

name: PSYC3200W
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; BIOL 1102 or both 1107 and 1108; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Methods, concepts and findings of behavioral genetics in animals and humans.

name: PSYC3201
prerequisites: BIOL 1102 or 1107; PSYC 1100.
description: Principles of animal behavior derived from a review of descriptive and analytic studies in laboratory and field. Sometimes offered in multimedia format.

name: PSYC3241
prerequisites: PSYC 1100, and 1101 or 1103; open to juniors or higher.
description: Cognition, brain mechanisms, biofeedback, aggression, sex, competence, social influence, and conformity. Formerly offered as COMM/PSYC 3103.

name: PSYC3250W
catalogName: Laboratory in Animal Behavior and Learning
description: A laboratory course to supplement PSYC 3201.

name: PSYC3251
prerequisites: PSYC 2100; PSYC 2200, which may be taken concurrently.
description: Techniques employed in experimental investigation of the anatomical and physiological bases of behavior.

name: PSYC3252
prerequisites: PSYC 2100 and 2201.
description: Techniques employed in the experimental investigation of drug action. Laboratory exercises illustrate behavioral and neural effects of various psychoactive pharmacological agents such as stimulants, antipsychotics, antidepressants, antiparkinsonian drugs, anxiolytics, sedative/hypnotics.

name: PSYC3253
prerequisites: PSYC 2100 and 3501.
description: Techniques employed in the experimental investigation of sensory neuroscience. Laboratory exercises in psychophysics and assessment of human and animal sensory abilities. Elementary computer programming is used to synthesize and process sound files and analyze psychophysics data.  A one-hour lecture and two two-hour labs each week.

name: PSYC3270
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Selected topics vary with each offering (e.g., The Neurobiology of Memory and Decision-Making, Sensory Coding and Decoding, Animal Models of Basal Ganglia Dysfunction, Animal Models of Developmental Disorders). With a change in topic, course may be repeated for credit.

name: PSYC3300
prerequisites: PSYC 2400.
description: Theory, research, treatment, and prevention in developmental psychopathology from infancy through adolescence.

name: PSYC3301
prerequisites: PSYC 2300.
description: History of clinical psychology as a profession; graduate training and ethical responsibilities; assessment and treatment of psychological disorders; and clinical sub-specialities.

name: PSYC3302W
prerequisites: PSYC 2300; PSYC 2400; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011.
description: Identification, treatment, education, and support of individuals with developmental concerns, particularly autism spectrum disorders.

name: PSYC3350W
prerequisites: PSYC 2100 or STAT 1100; PSYC 2301; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011.
description: Experimental design and methodology in personality research, followed by a class project written individually by each student.

name: PSYC3370W
description: May be repeated for credit with a change of topic.

name: PSYC3400
prerequisites: PSYC 2400.
description: Historical and contemporary theories of development. Includes Piaget, Vygotsky, Freud, Erikson, social-learning theory, ethological theory, and information-processing theory.

name: PSYC3405
prerequisites: PSYC 1100, 1101 or 1103; and PSYC 2400 or HDFS 2100.
description: Social development in infancy, childhood, and adolescence. Theoretical approaches and practical applications. Special emphasis on critically evaluating empirical research.

name: PSYC3440
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Survey of current research and methods in developmental cognitive neuroscience, an interdisciplinary scientific field at the boundaries of neuroscience, developmental psychology, and cognitive science.

name: PSYC3450W
prerequisites: PSYC 2100 and PSYC 2400; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011.
description: The techniques necessary for performing psychological research on young children; advanced topics.

name: PSYC3470
prerequisites: PSYC 2400.
description: Selected topics (e.g., infant development, peer relations, cognitive development, and developmental psychobiology) that may vary with each offering.  With a change of topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: PSYC3470W
description: Selected topics (e.g., infant development, peer relations, cognitive development, and developmental psychobiology) that may vary with each offering.

name: PSYC3500
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103.
description: Those aspects of language that make it a uniquely efficient vehicle for communication and thought.

name: PSYC3501
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103.
description: Sensory and perceptual processes in vision, hearing, touch, taste, and smell.

name: PSYC3502
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; open to sophomores or higher.
description: The role of consciousness in human cognition is examined by comparing the conscious and unconscious operation of mental faculties including perception, memory, learning, and thought.

name: PSYC3503
prerequisites: PSYC 2501 or 3501.
description: Symbolic and connectionist approaches to modelling vision, problem solving, planning, deduction, language understanding, learning, and memory.

name: PSYC3550W
prerequisites: PSYC 2100Q; PSYC 2500 or 2501, which may be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011.
description: Selected experiments from the following topics: memory processes, categorization, language comprehension and problem solving.

name: PSYC3551W
prerequisites: PSYC 2100Q; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: PSYC 2501 or 3500, which may be taken concurrently.
description: Introduction to the experimental study of language understanding and use. Topics selected from among speech perception, word recognition, sentence processing, language production, and corpus phenomena.

name: PSYC3552
prerequisites: PSYC 2100;  PSYC 3501, which may be taken concurrently.
description: Techniques for the study of sensory capacities and perceptual processes.

name: PSYC3600
prerequisites: PSYC 2600.
description: Social psychological phenomena in the workplace.  Social perceptions, personality, stress, work-related attitudes, motivation, team decision-making, and effectiveness, leadership and influence, organizational culture.

name: PSYC3601
prerequisites: PSYC 1100.
description: Application of information about human abilities and limitations to the design of systems, products, tools, computer interfaces, tasks, jobs, and environments for safe, comfortable and effective human use.

name: PSYC3644
prerequisites: PSYC 1101 or 1103; and PSYC 2600 or consent of instructor
description: Models, research methods, and research-to-practice applications in the interdisciplinary field of occupational health psychology, and how these are used to enhance the safety, health and well-being of workers in all occupations and to create healthier workplaces and organizations.

name: PSYC3670
prerequisites: PSYC 2600 or 3601 or instructor consent.
description: May be repeated for credit with a change of  topic.

name: PSYC3670W
prerequisites: PSYC 2600 or 3601 or instructor consent; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: PSYC3750
prerequisites: PSYC 2100 or STAT 1100Q; PSYC 2700.
description: Methods and techniques of research in social psychology. Supervised research investigations.

name: PSYC3750W
prerequisites: PSYC 2100 or STAT 1100; PSYC 2700; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011.
description: Methods and techniques of research in social psychology. Supervised research investigations.

name: PSYC3770
prerequisites: PSYC 2700.
description: Selected topics (e.g., social influence, person perception, pro-social behavior) vary with each offering.  With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: PSYC3770W
description: Selected topics (e.g., social influence, person perception, pro-social behavior) vary with each offering.

name: PSYC3880
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103.
description: Supervised field work in clinical, community, or organizational settings.  Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory.)  With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: PSYC3883
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head or advisor may be required prior to the student's departure.

name: PSYC3884
prerequisites: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or 1103.
description: Recent developments in psychology. Topics vary with each offering.  With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: PSYC3885
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: PSYC3889
description: Participant activities related to research.  With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: PSYC3899
prerequisites: PSYC 2100.
description: Students are expected to develop their own plan for a research project, conduct the research, and write-up this research, consulting periodically with a faculty member.  With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: PSYC4197W
prerequisites: Three credits of PSYC 3889 or 3899; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open only to Honors students with consent of instructor and Department Head.
description: Hours by arrangement.

name: PUBH1001
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: A basic foundation in public health principles and practices. Individual and group field assignments required. CA 2.

name: PUBH3001
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Provides overview of epidemiological concepts and methods for examining the distribution and causes of health and illness across populations. Stresses the application of epidemiology in advancing health research, disease prevention efforts, and medical care delivery. Primarily suited for, but not limited to, juniors and seniors interested in public health.

name: PVS1000
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: This introductory course focuses on current global issues of health and disease to describe fundamental topics in pathobiology. Global biomedical concerns regarding infectious diseases, population, cancer, biotechnology and environmental health will be addressed. Course content will provide examples of the impact of veterinary and human pathology on world health issues.

name: PVS2095
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
description: Credits, prerequisites and hours as determined by the Senate Curricula and Course Committee.  May be repeated for credit with a change in topic.

name: PVS2100
prerequisites: BIOL 1107 or equivalent.
description: A study of the anatomy and physiology of animals with reference to pathological changes of the component parts of the body.

name: PVS2301
catalogName: Health and Disease Management of Animals
description: Designed for students who plan to own and work with domestic animals. Its purpose is to develop student competence in disease management and to foster an intelligent working relationship with their veterinarian. The course will cover a systematic study of infectious and noninfectious diseases of domestic animals from the standpoint of economy and public health.

name: PVS3093
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit.

name: PVS3094W
description: May be repeated for credit. Majors may take this course in each semester of the senior year.

name: PVS3095
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Topics and credits to be published prior to the registration period  preceding the semester offerings.   With a change of  topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: PVS3099
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special problems in connection with departmental research programs and diagnostic procedures for diseases of animals. Some suggested topics are histopathologic laboratory procedures, clinical hematology, diagnostic bacteriology, diagnostic parasitology.  May be repeated for credit.

name: PVS3100
prerequisites: Open to juniors or higher; open only with consent of instructor.  Recommended preparation: PVS 2100 or PNB 2264-2265 or PNB 2274-2275 or an equivalent course in vertebrate anatomy and physiology.
description: Designed for students in biologic, paramedical and animal sciences; its purpose is to integrate histologic and cellular structure with function, utilizing human tissues and those from other vertebrates.

name: PVS3201
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Structure and classification of viruses, cultivation and multiplication, pathogenesis and epidemiology of viral infections, host response, oncogenic viruses, immunization against, and laboratory diagnosis of viral diseases.

name: PVS3201W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: Structure and classification of viruses, cultivation and multiplication, pathogenesis and epidemiology of viral infections, host response, oncogenic viruses, immunization against, and laboratory diagnosis of viral diseases.

name: PVS3341
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: A systematic study of metabolic, nutritional, genetic, and infectious diseases of commercial poultry, avian wildlife, and caged pet birds. Emphasis is placed upon diagnosis and disease prevention. For each system of the body, pertinent anatomy, physiology, histology, pathology, and histopathology will be discussed.

name: PVS3501
catalogName: Diagnostic Techniques for the Biomedical Sciences
prerequisites: MCB 3414; open to juniors or higher; open to Agricultural Biotechnology minors.  Recommended preparation:  MCB 2000.
description: Theoretical basis and practical exposure to modern laboratory methods used in the biomedical sciences for disease diagnosis.

name: PVS3700
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Mechanisms of emergence that different pathogens have used to cause disease in new hosts.

name: PVS4000
catalogName: Bioinformatics in Molecular Epidemiology of Infectious Diseases
prerequisites: ANSC 3121, MCB 2400, or MCB 2410.
description: Basic concepts and terminologies in bioinformatics and infectious disease epidemiology. Hands-on, practical experiences in sequence analysis: database, alignment, phylogenetic analysis, and visualization of data.

name: PVS4203
prerequisites: MCB 2610, or an equivalent course in general microbiology or bacteriology with consent of the instructor. Open to juniors or higher.
description: Designed to cover important concepts and pioneering strategies currently being used to develop novel antibacterials.

name: PVS4300
prerequisites: PVS 2100 or PNB 2264-2265 or PNB 2274-2275 or an equivalent course in vertebrate anatomy and physiology; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: PVS 3100 or equivalent course in histology or cell biology.
description: The body's response to chemical, physical, and microbial injuries including the functional and morphologic alterations in disease of the major organ systems.

name: SAAG 250
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Designed to assist incoming students in adjusting to college and improving their academic performance. First year students will learn about university resources and facilities, and strategies relating to study skills, problem solving, time management, and setting and achieving academic and personal goals. Field trips may be required.

name: SAAG 316
catalogName: Introduction of Agricultural Mechanics and Safety
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Small gas engines, welding and other applications of agricultural equipment in animal science and horticultural operations.

name: SAAG 350
catalogName: Hispanic Culture and Communication in Agriculture
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Covers everyday conversations in Latin American Spanish needed at the workplace in agriculture and natural resources.  It aims at emphasizing dialogues, commands and directions to improve the relationship and understanding of workers and employers in several fields of agriculture. Course prepares students in landscape, horticulture, animal science and agriculture economics with basic communication skills in Spanish and familiarizes students with Latin American cultural traditions.  Taught with AGNR 3350. Not intended for students with advanced Spanish language skills.

name: SAAG 699
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An independent study project is mutually arranged between a student and an instructor. Course may be repeated for credit. Total credits allowed toward graduation requirements are restricted as outlined in the Ratcliffe Hicks section of the Undergraduate Catalog.

name: SAAS 101
prerequisites: Not open to students in an undergraduate program.
description: The biological, physical and social factors that influence animal production and utilization. Taught with ANSC 1001.

name: SAAS 111
catalogName: Anatomy and Physiology of Domestic Animals
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A study of the anatomy and physiology of the animal body including characteristics that impact animal production systems. The physiology of reproduction and digestion will receive emphasis. Management practices and techniques used to maximize production efficiency will be included.

name: SAAS 112
catalogName: Anatomy and Physiology of Domestic Animals
prerequisites: SAAS 111.
description: A study of the anatomy and physiology of the animal body including characteristics that impact animal production systems. The physiology of reproduction and digestion will receive emphasis. Management practices and techniques used to maximize production efficiency will be included.

name: SAAS 113
catalogName: Principles of Animal Nutrition and Feeding
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Focuses on digestive anatomy of various species and the classes of nutrients including their digestion, metabolism and sources. Nutrient requirements and feeding standards for various classes of livestock for reproduction, lactation, growth, work and maintenance are included as well as companion animals, exotics and aquatics.  Classes of feedstuffs, their characteristics and proper utilization will be discussed.  Attention will also be given to characteristics of common feedstuffs and to formulating rations and nutritional programs for animal enterprise. Taught with ANSC 1111.

name: SAAS 121
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The principles of genetics, chemistry of nucleic acids, replication, transcription, translation and regulation of genes, population and quantitative genetics, and modern molecular genetics approaches as tools for breeding, and improving livestock production.

name: SAAS 202
catalogName: Behavior and Training of Domestic Animals
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: SAAS 101.
description: Application of behavior of cattle, horses, sheep, goats, swine, companion animals and poultry to their management, training and welfare. Basic principles of genetics and physiology of behavior, perception, training, learning, motivation, and stress with consideration of integrated behavioral management and animal welfare. Students must have access to an animal that they can train throughout the semester. Taught concurrently with ANSC 1602.

name: SAAS 243
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An introduction to meat, dairy and poultry products. Issues concerning regulatory standards, nutritive value, safety and quality assessment will be emphasized. Laboratories will emphasize the production and processing of these animal food products. Taught with ANSC 3343.

name: SAAS 251
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Includes horse types and breeds and their nutrition, breeding, evaluation, behavior, care and management with attention given to detailed studies of the problems and practices of horse production and use. Taught with ANSC 2251.

name: SAAS 252
catalogName: Management of the Horse Breeding Farm
prerequisites: SAAS 251
description: Designed to develop technical and managerial skills necessary for operating horse farms. Programs for herd health, hoof care, nutrition, breeding, foaling and record keeping will be included.

name: SAAS 256
prerequisites: SAAS 251.
description: Includes instruction in the breaking and training of young horses.

name: SAAS 257
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The techniques and procedures of teaching equitation including the theories of riding and teaching methods. Practice teaching will be required under the supervision of the instructor. Taught with ANSC 4457.

name: SAAS 261
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Management of dairy cattle including milking procedures, sanitation, selection, nutrition, reproduction, physiology and anatomy of milk secretion and record keeping. Field trip required. Taught with ANSC 3261.

name: SAAS 262
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The organization and management of dairy farms with emphasis upon business and economic decision making. Management programs in the areas of nutrition, disease control, waste management, selection, reproduction and milking will be evaluated. Field trips are required.

name: SAAS 271
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A practical application of scientific principles in the poultry industry. It will include classification, selection methods, breeding, incubation and chick development, brooding, nutrient requirements, processing and management practices.

name: SAAS 272
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An introduction to sustainable agriculture, as related to alternative farm animal production. Basic economics will be discussed in preparation for the creation of a farm business plan. Laboratory/discussion periods will include student presentations and hands-on activities. Field trips required.

name: SAAS 273
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Biological and economic aspects of beef, sheep, and swine production. Field trips required. Taught with ANSC 3273.

name: SAAS 274
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Classification, form to function relationships, grades and value differences of livestock are included. Objective and subjective methods of appraisal are used to evaluate beef cattle, sheep and swine. Taught with ANSC 3674.

name: SAAS 275
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Intensive training in the evaluation of selected species of farm animals or their products. Type standards and the relation of anatomical features to physiological function are emphasized. Evaluation skills including justification of decisions will be developed. Students enrolled in this course will have the option to participate on intercollegiate animal and product evaluation teams. Field trips are required, some of which may occur prior to the start of the semester.   May be repeated once for credit. Taught with ANSC 3675.

name: SAAS 276
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Basic concepts of the nutrition, physiology, health and management of companion animals. Taught with ANSC 1676.

name: SAAS 290
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A multiple day field trip format. Students in this course will travel with the instructor to visit and tour agri-businesses that represent commercial aspects of different animal science activities. Students will interview agri-business personnel and gain an understanding of how agricultural principles are applied in the field. Each student must submit a formal written report for evaluation and meet all other course requirements as specified by the instructor. Field trip is required. May be repeated with a change of topic. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: SAAS 291
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Open only for third semester students with consent of instructor and Department Head. Total credits allowed toward graduation requirements are restricted as outlined in Ratcliffe Hicks section. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: SAAS 294
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A discussion of current employment opportunities in animal agriculture. In addition, students will prepare resumes and give oral presentations.

name: SAAS 295
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated for credit with a change of topic. Total credits allowed toward graduation requirements are restricted as outlined in Ratcliffe Hicks section. Contact Department Main Office for list of current topics and instructors.

name: SAAS 299
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An independent study project is mutually arranged between a student and an instructor. Students are advised to read the Ratcliffe Hicks regulation limiting the number of credits which may be applied to the minimum graduation requirements. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory.) May be repeated.

name: SAAS 358
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Practical experience in common management practices is offered by working in the University facilities under supervision. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).  May be repeated once for credit.

name: SAAS 363
catalogName: Management Skills and Practices - Dairy Cattle I
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing SAAS 364.
description: Practical experience in common management practices is offered by working in the University facilities under supervision. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: SAAS 364
catalogName: Management Skills and Practices - Dairy Cattle II
prerequisites: SAAS 363
description: Continued practical experience in common management practices is offered by working in the University facilities under supervision. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: SAAS 373
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Practical experience in common management practices is offered by working with livestock species in the University facilities under supervisor. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: SAAS 375
prerequisites: May be repeated to a maximum of two credits. Open only to students in the Ratcliffe Hicks School of Agriculture. Instructor consent required.
description: Practical experience in common management practices is offered by working in the University facilities under supervision. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: SANR 215
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: SAPL 120 and SAPL 300.
description: Identification, taxonomic classification, silvics, and distribution of trees and woody shrubs of the United States with emphasis upon Northeastern species. Focus is on field-based identification skills in natural forest, woodland and shrubland settings. Lab sessions take place primarily outdoors. Field trips are planned. Taught with NRE 2415.

name: SANR 255
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: SANR 215.
description: Forest structure and functional processes and their relation to physical environment (light, temperature, water, soil); the influence of time (succession, disturbance, stand dynamics) and space (landscape ecology, ecosystem management). Laboratory will be in the field or computer lab. Taught with NRE 2455.

name: SANR 310
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Basic wildlife techniques including habitat evaluation and identification signs.  Emphasis will be placed on keeping a wildlife field journal. Field exercises and laboratory provide an opportunity to use and evaluate techniques for wildlife management.

name: SANR 325
prerequisites: SANR 215, which may be taken concurrently.
description: Theory, science, and practice of evaluating, growing, managing and safe removal of trees within or in close proximity to built environments. Laboratories are field-based and will take place in outdoor conditions. Taught with NRE 3425.

name: SAPB 301
catalogName: Health and Disease Management of Animals
prerequisites: SAAS 111 and 112 and a college course in biology
description: Designed for students who plan to own and work with domestic animals. Its purpose is to develop student competence in disease management and to foster an intelligent working relationship with their veterinarian. The course will cover a systematic relationship of infectious and noninfectious diseases of domestic animals from the standpoint of economic and public health.

name: SAPL 101
catalogName: Environmental Sustainability of Food Production in Developed Countries
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Foundations of modern systems that produce the majority of food calories consumed in North America and other developed countries. Benefits and environmental risks associated with modern food production systems. Alternative food production systems and sustainability. Local food production and food security. Food production and climate change.

name: SAPL 110
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing SAPL 315.
description: An overview of turfgrass adaptation, selection, and management. Topics include turfgrass growth, physiology, soil interactions, establishment, and maintenance. Cultural system practices for lawns, golf courses, athletic fields, and other turf areas. Turfgrass pest management practices for weeds, insects and diseases.

name: SAPL 115
prerequisites: SAPL 110, which may be taken concurrently.
description: Grass establishment, grass identification, athletic field turfgrass playability evaluations, soil testing, turfgrass pest identification, turfgrass pest monitoring techniques and fertilizer spreader and sprayer calibration.

name: SAPL 120
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A general course designed to give students a broad view of the field of horticulture as well as a working knowledge of the fundamentals of plant growth.

name: SAPL 210
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Discussion of the specialized field of golf course management. Topics: cultural techniques including soil aeration, topdressing, mowing, and thatch removal; grass or species selection, fertilization, irrigation, personnel, golf course pest management and equipment and inventory management. Field trips required.

name: SAPL 230
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Turfgrass irrigation systems, principles of hydraulics, irrigation components, design, installation and repair.  Students will design irrigation systems for various turf areas.  Field trips and fieldwork will be required. Taught with SPSS 3300.

name: SAPL 300
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing SAPL 315 or 352.
description: Physical and chemical properties of soils; nature and use of fertilizer and lime materials; management of soils for crop production including soil testing, tillage and fertilization practices, and conservation practices.

name: SAPL 315
prerequisites: SAPL 110 and 300
description: Effects of environmental stresses and turfgrass management practices on growth, development and physiology of turfgrasses. Implementation of proper management practices to promote optimal turfgrass health under stress conditions. Taught with SPSS 3150.

name: SAPL 410
catalogName: Woody Plants: Common Trees, Shrubs and Vines
prerequisites: SAPL 120.
description: Taxonomy, identification, ornamental characteristics, cultural requirements and landscape use of deciduous and evergreen woody plants most often utilized in landscapes of the northeastern United States and similar environs.

name: SAPL 430
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Identification, nomenclature, cultural requirements and landscape uses of herbaceous perennials, ornamental grasses, ferns, annuals and bulbs. Study of live plants is required.

name: SAPL 440
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The commercial production of small fruits and grapes in the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic regions including varieties, fruit-growing systems and pruning, site requirements, harvesting methods, post-harvest requirements, marketing, pest complexes and IPM strategies of the major berry crops. Field trips required.

name: SAPL 500
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Application of ecological processes to modern agricultural production practices. Crops and their environment. Soil quality and maintenance of soil productivity. Sustainability of agroecosystems.

name: SAPL 520
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The study of flower arrangement as an art form with emphasis on historical background, artistic principles, color harmony, and care of perishable media. Individual expression is encouraged in the creation of floral composition.

name: SAPL 540
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Techniques and concepts essential in managing and operating a garden center. Topics include goal setting, retailing, finance, business planning and pricing.

name: SAPL 550
catalogName: Urban Plant Systems: Construction and Maintenance
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: SAPL 120,410,430. Not open for credit to students who have passed SAPL 740.
description: Technical information on the effective construction and maintenance of planted systems. Structural and functional components of plant systems. Provision of ecosystem services. Overviews of a wide spectrum of planted systems including streetscaping, green roofs and green walls, rain gardens and bioretention, and phytoremediation systems. Techniques of soil modification. Plant selection. Establishment and maintenance of woody and herbaceous plants: planting, preservation, pruning, mulching, irrigation, and fertilization. Taught with SPSS 3550.

name: SAPL 620
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Fundamentals of soil management and crop plant husbandry as applied to commercial vegetable production and home gardening. Horticultural principles of crop growth. Focus is on sustainable practices. Field laboratory will consist of field trips (some outside designated laboratory time) during the early part of the semester to organic and conventional farms to observe production and marketing practices. Field trips required.

name: SAPL 640
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Theory and practice in sexual and asexual propagation of horticultural plants, emphasizing the anatomical, physiological, and ecological principles involved. Laboratories provide practical experience with seeds, division, cuttings, budding, grafting, layering and tissue culture.

name: SAPL 660
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Priniciples of field and container production of nursery stock.  Emphasis on production practices for woody nursery stock from propagation to sales.

name: SAPL 670
prerequisites: SAPL 120.
description: Introduction to greenhouse crop management with emphasis on structures, environmental control systems, and management techniques used to control crop response.

name: SAPL 675
prerequisites: SAPL 670, which may be taken concurrently.
description: Students will be introduced to greenhouse crop production techniques and methodologies. Course follows a travel-course format, in which students participate in regularly scheduled field trips to commercial greenhouse operations in Connecticut and neighboring states. Students will make observations on the mechanical systems, management considerations, and crop production practices employed by commercial businesses.

name: SAPL 810
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: A practical survey of practices used for insect, disease and weed pests of turf, flowers, shrubs, trees and food crops. Consideration will be given to quarantine, mechanical, biological and chemical means of control. Field trips may be required.

name: SAPL 840
prerequisites: SAPL 800 or 810.
description: Principles of integrated pest management covering insect, disease, and weed problems with emphasis on turfgrass, ornamentals, and greenhouse production. Environmental impacts and pest control strategies will be covered.

name: SAPL 991
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Students will work with professionals in an area of their interest. Written reports, daily logs, and/or evaluations by professional supervisors may be required. Open to qualified students with consent of advisor and Department Head. May be repeated provided that the sum total of credits does not exceed six.

name: SAPL 995
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: May be repeated for credit with a change of topic. Total credits allowed toward graduation requirements are restricted as outlined in Ratcliffe Hicks Section.

name: SAPL 999
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An independent study project is mutually arranged between a student and an instructor.  Course may be repeated for credit. Total credits allowed toward graduation requirements are restricted as outlined in the Ratcliffe Hicks section of the Undergraduate Catalog.

name: SARE 450
catalogName: Principles of Agricultural and Resource Economics
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An introduction to microeconomic analysis with applications to food, nutrition, health, natural resources, and the environment. Topics include consumer and firm behavior, supply, demand, markets, and economic policy. Taught with ARE 1150.

name: SARE 460
catalogName: Fundamentals of Accounting and Management for the Agribusiness Firm
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: An analysis of basic business principles, fundamentals and concepts for business entrepreneurs.

name: SLHS1150
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: Introduction to normal communicative processes and to disorders of communication. CA 2. CA 4.

name: SLHS1150W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: Introduction to normal communicative processes and to disorders of communication. CA 2. CA 4.

name: SLHS2156Q
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: MATH 1060 or the equivalent.  Not open to students who have passed CDIS 1155Q or SLHS 3247.
description: Fundamentals of acoustics specifically oriented to voice, speech production, and hearing. Human response to sound and its measurement. Introduction to acoustic instrumentation and software used in communication sciences. Examples of concepts to be covered include frequency, intensity, decibels, filters, pitch, loudness, formants, critical bands, and masking.

name: SLHS2203
catalogName: Anatomy and Physiology of Speech and Hearing
prerequisites: Open to soph or higher.  No open for credit for students who have passed SLHS 3247.
description: Anatomical, neurological and physiological principles fundamental to the understanding of speech, hearing, and swallowing.

name: SLHS2203
catalogName: Anatomy and Physiology of Speech, Hearing, and Swallowing
prerequisites: Open to soph or higher.  No open for credit for students who have passed SLHS 3247.
description: Anatomical, neurological and physiological principles fundamental to the understanding of speech, hearing, and swallowing.

name: SLHS2204
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: How children learn their first language, the effects of language on their thinking and behavior.

name: SLHS3247
prerequisites: SLHS 2156 and 2203; open to juniors or higher.
description: The analysis of speech through the application of phonetic theory.

name: SLHS3248
prerequisites: SLHS 2156 and 2203; open to juniors or higher.
description: An introduction to the nature, causation, assessment and management of hearing impairment and the principles and techniques of public school conservation programs.

name: SLHS3293
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: Special topics taken in foreign study program. May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head required, normally granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: SLHS3295
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit.

name: SLHS3298
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.
description: With a change in topic, may be repeated for credit.

name: SLHS3299
prerequisites: Open only to juniors or higher.
description: The course, for superior students, includes independent reading, periodic conferences, and such other work as desired by the instructor. With a change of content, may be repeated for credit.

name: SLHS4123
catalogName: Bilingualism in Typical and Atypical Populations: Language and Cognition
prerequisites: Instructor consent, open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: basic phonetic principles or phonology courses, language development and language disorders.
description: Biological and cognitive factors associated with language acquisition, cognitive reserve, Developmental Language Disorders in bilinguals. Emphasis on diagnosis, cognitive factors in language selection, and differences in reading opaque vs. transparent languages.

name: SLHS4245
catalogName: Neuroscience of Cognitive and Communication Disorders
prerequisites: SLHS 2203 and 2204; open to juniors or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing SLHS 4335.
description: Anatomy and physiology of the central nervous system. Brain mechanisms that underlie speech, language, hearing, and cognition. Neurogenic communication disorders.

name: SLHS4245W
catalogName: Neuroscience of Cognitive and Communication Disorders
prerequisites: SLHS 2203 and 2204; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing SLHS 4335.
description: Anatomy and physiology of the central nervous system. Brain mechanisms that underlie speech, language, hearing, and cognition. Neurogenic communication disorders.

name: SLHS4249
prerequisites: SLHS 3248; open to juniors or higher.
description: An introduction to the effects of hearing impairment on communication. Communication strategies for adults and children with impaired hearing are discussed.

name: SLHS4249W
prerequisites: SLHS 3248; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher.
description: An introduction to the effects of hearing impairment on communication. Communication strategies for adults and children with impaired hearing are discussed.

name: SLHS4251
catalogName: Introduction to Articulation, Voice, and Fluency Disorders
prerequisites: SLHS 2156, 2203, 2204, and 3247; open to juniors and higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing SLHS 4335.
description: Communication problems resulting from disorders of speech, voice, and fluency. Assessment and management strategies in settings including public schools, hospitals, and rehabilitation centers.

name: SLHS4254
catalogName: Introduction to Language Disorders in Children
prerequisites: SLHS 2204; open to juniors or higher.
description: Development, measurement, and function of language in children. Emphasis on child language disorders and their causes. Assessment and management strategies in settings including public schools and private clinics.

name: SLHS4254W
catalogName: Introduction to Language Disorders in Children
prerequisites: SLHS 2204; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to juniors or higher. Not open for credit for students who have passed CDIS 4253.
description: Development, measurement, and function of language in children. Emphasis on child language disorders and their causes. Assessment and management strategies in settings including public schools and private clinics.

name: SLHS4296W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to junior or higher Honors students.
description: Preparation of a thesis and its presentation to the department.

name: SLHS4335
catalogName: Introduction to Clinical Methods in Speech-Language Pathology
prerequisites: SLHS 4245 and 4251; open to juniors or higher.
description: Clinical methods of treatment in speech-language pathology. Professional interaction, development of client-focused treatment goals, construction of lesson plans, collection and analysis of client data, and daily SOAP note documentation.

name: SLHS4376
prerequisites: SLHS 2204, SLHS 3247, and SLHS 4254.
description: A research seminar covering the theories, assessment, and treatment of children with reading disabilities from a language-based perspective.

name: SOCI1001
prerequisites: May not be taken out of sequence after passing SOCI 3203. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: Modern society and its social organization, institutions, communities, groups, and social roles: the socialization of individuals, family, gender, race and ethnicity, religion, social class, crime and deviance, population, cities, political economy, and social change. CA 2.

name: SOCI1001W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Cannot be taken for credit after passing SOCI 3203. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: Modern society and its social organization, institutions, communities, groups, and social roles: the socialization of individuals, family, gender, race and ethnicity, religion, social class, crime and deviance, population, cities, political economy, and social change. CA 2.

name: SOCI1251
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: Major social problems, their sources in the organization of society, public policies for their alleviation, and questions of ethics and social justice: alcohol and drug abuse, physical and mental illness, sexual variances, poverty and inequality, ethnic and racial prejudice and discrimination, women and gender, the changing family, violence, crime and delinquency, the environment, urban problems, and population planning and growth. CA 2. CA 4.

name: SOCI1251W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: Major social problems, their sources in the organization of society, public policies for their alleviation, and questions of ethics and social justice: alcohol and drug abuse, physical and mental illness, sexual variances, poverty and inequality, ethnic and racial prejudice and discrimination, women and gender, the changing family, violence, crime and delinquency, the environment, urban problems, and population planning and growth. CA 2. CA 4.

name: SOCI1501
prerequisites: RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses
description: Race, class, and gender, as they structure identities, opportunities, and social outcomes. CA 2. CA 4.

name: SOCI1501W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011 or 3800. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
description: Race, class, and gender, as they structure identities, opportunities, and social outcomes. CA 2. CA 4.

name: SOCI1701
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Economic, political, social and cultural processes in globalization. The world economy, the autonomy of nation-states, the role of the media, and the social and environmental problems of societies in a world context. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: SOCI1993
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Special topics taken in an Education Abroad program.

name: SOCI1996
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Introduction to conducting sociological research.

name: SOCI2101
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Sports as an institution and its impact on society. Gender, race, and class inequality in sports. Cultural, economic, political, and legal influences on sports at the professional, intercollegiate, scholastic, and recreational levels.

name: SOCI2200
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: one introductory AAAS or SOCI course.
description: An introduction to the historical, political, social, economic, and cultural diversity of India. Topics may include: cultural diversity in languages, religions, and regions; socio-political challenges; power relations that construct patterns of privilege and marginalization; and contemporary human rights issues.

name: SOCI2250
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Social determinants of health. Racial differences in health outcomes. Social, economic, and political structures and their impacts on health organization and inequalities in care delivery. Patient-provider interactions; meanings of illness. CA 2.

name: SOCI2271
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Happiness as a social construction that shapes and is shaped by human societies and their social structures and processes. The social causes, nature, and consequences of the pursuit of happiness as a socially defined and organized phenomenon.

name: SOCI2275
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Socially-embedded facets of well-being. Definitions and levels of well-being; relationship of well-being to social situations, social interactions, and social institutions.

name: SOCI2275W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to sophomores or higher.
description: Socially-embedded facets of well-being. Definitions and levels of well-being; relationship of well-being to social situations, social interactions, and social institutions.

name: SOCI2301
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Theories and research on crime, criminal law, and the criminal justice system.

name: SOCI2301W
description: Theories and research on crime, criminal law, and the criminal justice system.

name: SOCI2305
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: How society defines a behavior as deviant, how and why members of society react to those who act this way, why people engage in deviant behavior, their experiences when labeled as deviants, and how they manage the stigma. May consider extreme body modification, drug abuse, mental illness, prostitution, suicide, and unconventional beliefs within the above context. Formerly offered as SOCI 3311.

name: SOCI2305W
description: How society defines a behavior as deviant, how and why members of society react to those who act this way, why people engage in deviant behavior, their experiences when labeled as deviants, and how they manage the stigma. May consider extreme body modification, drug abuse, mental illness, prostitution, suicide, and unconventional beliefs within the above context. Formerly offered as SOCI 3311W.

name: SOCI2310
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The criminal justice system from a sociological perspective, including crime, police and law enforcement, courts and adjudication, corrections and juvenile justice. CA 2. CA 4.

name: SOCI2411
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Occupations, jobs, careers, and the professions, and their effects on the division of labor, on the workplace, and on individuals in the labor force.

name: SOCI2461
catalogName: Race, Gender, and U.S. Health Care
prerequisites: Recommended preparation: AFRA/SOCI 1001.
description: Factors of race and gender at work in U.S health care. Focus on African Americans and Black immigrants as care recipients and care providers in health care institutions. CA 2. CA 4.

name: SOCI2501
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Sociological concepts of intolerance and injustice and how they affect members of marginalized groups; case studies may consider social class, race/ethnicity, gender, sexuality, age, religion, and disability. CA 4.

name: SOCI2501W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to sophomores or higher.
description: Sociological concepts of intolerance and injustice and how they affect members of marginalized groups; case studies may consider social class, race/ethnicity, gender, sexuality, age, religion, and disability. CA 4.

name: SOCI2503
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher.
description: Sources and consequences of racial and ethnic prejudice and discrimination. CA 4.

name: SOCI2503W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to sophomores or higher.
description: Sources and consequences of racial and ethnic prejudice and discrimination. CA 4.

name: SOCI2509W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011; open to sophomores or higher.
description: Sources and consequences of anti-Semitism in society. CA 4-INT.

name: SOCI2651
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: The American family, its changing forms and values, and the social conditions influencing it: mate selection, marital adjustment, the responsibilities and opportunities of parenthood, and resolving family crises. CA 4.

name: SOCI2651W
description: The American family, it's changing forms and values, and the social conditions influencing it:  mate selection, marital adjustment, the responsibilities and opportunities of parenthood and resolving family crises. CA 4.

name: SOCI2701
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: SOCI2701E
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: SOCI 1001, SOCI 2709.
description: Sociological perspectives on the concepts of sustainability, focusing on issues of climate change mitigation and adaptation, including questions of social transitions based on concepts of social justice, biomimicry, permaculture and the future of life on earth. CA 2.

name: SOCI2705
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: SOCI2705E
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher. Not open for credit to students who have passed SOCI 3271 when offered either as Food or as Sustainability. Recommended preparation: SOCI 1001.
description: Social factors shaping the industrial food system, as well as a social analysis of viable alternatives. CA 2.

name: SOCI2709W
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: There is no description provided for this course.

name: SOCI2709WE
prerequisites: Open to sophomores or higher; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011.

CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: SOCI3833
catalogName: Topics in Sociology and Human Rights
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit. Variable topics covering theoretical and empirical examination of social, political, economic, legal, and/or cultural issues of human rights from a sociological perspective.

name: SOCI3835
prerequisites: There are no prerequisites for this course.
description: Social and political challenges of living as a refugee and working in humanitarian settings with a focus on refugee camps, institutional development of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, and alternative approaches to refuge.

name: SOCI3835W
prerequisites: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Recommended preparation: POLS 1007/HRTS 1007
description: Social and political challenges of living as a refugee and working in humanitarian settings. Refugee camps, the institutional development of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, and alternative approaches to sanctuary.

name: SOCI3837

description: Comparative approach to the study of human rights in the United States and elsewhere around the world from a sociological perspective.

name: SOWK3000
catalogName: The Social Work Profession and Practice
prerequisites: Open only to Bachelor of Social Work students
description: Overview of the social work profession and generalist social work practice at micro, mezzo and macro levels.

name: SOWK3100
catalogName: Human Behavior and Social Environment I
prerequisites: Open only to Bachelor of Social Work students
description: Examines theories of human behavior in the social environment from a "person-in-environment" approach. Focuses macro contextual factors that shape human experience.

name: SOWK3101
catalogName: Human Behavior and Social Environment II
prerequisites: Open only to Bachelor of Social Work students
description: Examines theories of human behavior of individuals, families, communities, groups, and organizations and lifespan development. Students complete shadowing requirement for an additional credit.

name: SOWK3200
prerequisites: Open only to Bachelor of Social Work students
description: Provides an overview of social welfare and social policy in the United States and the emergence of the social work profession in a historical perspective.

name: SOWK3201
prerequisites: Open only to Bachelor of Social Work students
description: Provides a basis to understand the process of social policy development and conceptual frameworks for social policy analysis. Engage in policy practice to address social and economic well-being.

name: SOWK3250
catalogName: Understanding Social Justice and Diversity through Intergroup Dialogue
prerequisites: Open only to Bachelor of Social Work students
description: Examines the mechanisms of human oppression on various levels and focuses on engaging diversity and differences in social work practice and advancing human rights and social and economic justice. Students participate in intergroup dialogue.

name: SOWK3350
catalogName: Research Methods for Social Work Practice
prerequisites: Open only to Bachelor of Social Work students
description: Introduces students to basic concepts and procedures of social work research. Includes research design, ethics, and culturally sensitive research practice.

name: SOWK3501
catalogName: Social Work Practice with Individuals and Families
prerequisites: Open only to Bachelor of Social Work students
description: Develops generalist social work practice knowledge, values, and skills from a strengths-based, empowerment model at the micro level. Prepares students to practice with individuals and families from differing backgrounds.

name: SOWK3502
prerequisites: Open only to Bachelor of Social Work students
description: Focuses on the mezzo-level of social work practice, primarily formal groups. Theory, knowledge, and analyses of group dynamics and the development of effective group work skills are emphasized.

name: SOWK3503
catalogName: Social Work Practice with Communities and Organizations
prerequisites: Open only to Bachelor of Social Work students
description: Prepares students to work with organizations and communities. Practice skills are developed that promote social work ethics and values, including advancing human rights and social, economic, and environmental justice.

name: SOWK3700
prerequisites: Open only to Bachelor of Social Work students
description: Students will be placed in field units in the community. They will engage in 200 hours of supervised field experience in generalist social work practice in the fall semester of their senior year.

name: SOWK3701
prerequisites: Open only to Bachelor of Social Work students
description: Students continue their field placement in a field unit in the community. They will engage in 200 hours of supervised field experience in generalist social work practice in the spring semester of their senior year.

name: SOWK3800
prerequisites: Open only to Bachelor of Social Work students
description: Concurrent with their field placement, students attend field seminar led by their faculty advisor. Focus on critical thinking and integrating field practice experiences with theories and evidence-based research, the development of professional identity, self-reflection, cultural competence, and identifying ethical issues.

name: SOWK3801
prerequisites: Open only to Bachelor of Social Work students
description: Concurrent with their field placement, students attend field seminar led by their faculty advisor. Focus on critical thinking and integrating field practice experiences with theories and evidence-based research, further development of professional identity, self-reflection, problem solving ethical issues, and cultural competence.

name: SOWK3993
prerequisites: Consent of BSW Director required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure. Open only to BSW students.
description: Special topics may be taken in a foreign study program. May count for elective credit. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: SOWK3995
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary; open only to BSW students
description: With a change in content, may be repeated for credit. May count for elective credit.

name: SOWK3998
prerequisites: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary; open only to BSW students
description: With a change in content, this course may be repeated for credit. May count for elective credit.

name: SOWK3999
prerequisites: Open only with consent of instructor; open only to BSW students.
description: With a change in content may be repeated for credit.

name: SOWK4100W
prerequisites: Open only to Bachelor of Social Work students.
description: Capstone course integrating and analyzing social work theory and practice through research, writing, and discussion of advanced texts.

name: SPAN1001
prerequisites: Not open to students who have had three or more years of high school Spanish. May not be taken out of sequence after passing SPAN 1002, 1003 or 1004, or any 2000 level  or above course taught in Spanish. RHAG students cannot take more than 22 credits of 1000 level courses.
